reviewText: just what I needed
love it

Cell phones lead hard lives and they need all the protection they can get.  This case is much sturdier than most cell phone cases and it has tough rubber casing which gives added protection to the ends and the corners.  In other words, where you need it the most.  I'm not suggesting that you put this on and use your phone as a frisbee, but if it slips out of your hand (or pocket or purse) and takes a fall, it has a much better chance of survival with this cover protecting it.

It's easy to snap on and all the buttons and ports are still accessible.  The "kickstand" feature would be useful if you watch TV or movies on your phone.  I think the credit card/ID holder is an inspired idea.  If you're going someplace that you don't want to carry a purse or backpack, your cards would be much safer inside your cell phone cover than loose in a pocket or even stuffed down your bra.

Free sample provided for review.

I've had this phone about a month now. I'm a heavy user that's your normal talk, text and Facebook/netflix/music with some games thrown in the mix. I've owned many different types of phones (I like seeing the new features different manufacturers come out with) and decided why not take a 100 buck plunge into checking out Blu phones, seen their specs and prices and was curious. Comes with a case and screen protector, and both fit perfect. The phone itself has a nice feel to it (my buddy has an s6 and was checking out my Blu phone and commented on how he liked the way it felt) and has the right weight and build to make it feel solid. I love the battery life on it. I work 10 hour shifts, have 2 hours of commute time and still have plenty of battery left when I get home. I knew what the specs were before I got it and have owned flagship phones in past (along with some lower and midrange) so I knew what to expect wasn't anything near those that cost me 5xs or more. But saying that this little hundred dollar phone surprised me. Screen is nice but it doesn't have a true automatically adjusting screen. You set its brightness and then it varies it slightly from there (which can be disabled easily). Good in a way because some phones screens are set too high/low on the presets. BUT with that being said, a few times I adjusted it a little too low with the option turned on and it made screen go blank, it was on but unreadable. First time I had to factory reset phone, second I happened to pull down the settings bar and touched in right area to adjust screen back up. Blu released an update a week after contacting them and haven't had an issue again. There is a little delay at times with the phone, but honestly what 100 dollar phone out doesn't. I get great 4g signal on cricket (att towers) and phone was easy to set up, that is once I realized the settings that automatically are installed on phone for cricket was wrong (actually aiowireless.net instead of cricketwireless.net). I stream Netflix no problem even with a couple apps open in back. 8 gigs isn't a lot but lollipop let's you move to SD again, the 1 gig ram is actually holding its own better than I thought (probably because it's almost pure stock Android). It can be rooted, haven't found a permanent one yet but I just run the root program if I ever have to reboot phone (which is rare).  Pictures turn out pretty good, have taken some great ones with the camera. The only issue I've ran into with the phone besides lack of cases  and screen protectors available is the headphone  jack. If I don't use the supplied headphones (whether it is aux cable, stereo headset, mic headset) the music plays out of speaker on phone (and speaker gets loud) while playing thru the headset. I almost sent it back but really didn't affect my using phone 99% of time as I use Bluetooth everywhere from home to car to work and only found out on accident so I kept it and happy I did. To some may be a deal breaker because the headset supplied is fragile feeling, but my set has survived a good bit of use and I'm hard on wired devices. I would definitely recommend this device to someone who doesn't need lte (4g streams everything I want) and wants a good unlocked phone. Has just enough of all the right ingredients to make this phone one of he better phones at the 150 or less mark.
summary: Only 1 problem I've found with the Studio C

reviewText: In my opinion the best smartphone on the market.

I LOVE THIS PHONE! I went from an HTC Evo to this phone and it is LEAPS and BOUNDS faster and just more amazing! I have TONS of storage space, room for an SD card if I want to add another one, LTE is amazing. Love that it's purple. That made me so happy to find a purple phone. The battery life is pretty incredible...if I keep my data turned off, other than when I need it, I wouldn't have to charge it but maybe every other day. If I use a lot of data, it's dead in a few hours...but still leaps and bounds better than my Evo. I would suggest a strong protective case and screen cover though, as this model is very fragile, and will crack, chip and break if dropped on any hard surface. I have dropped mine a few times and the corners of the phone now look like something was chewing on it, but luckily, since it has been protected, no cracked screens or broken phone. It does get hot when plugged in, so be careful where you lay it as it charges. All in all, a great little mini computer ;)

Great Quality! Great Price! Will buy again.

Pros
-Smooth Performance
-All Day Battery Life
-Excellent Build Quality
-Good Quality Screen
-NFC (Android Pay Compatible)
-Decent Camera
-MicroSD Expansion
Cons
-Awkward Button Placement
-Squeaky Vibrating Motor
-Updates not guaranteed
-No Gorilla Glass
Should you buy: YES
Actual Value: $220

I loved my Moto G. It made me always question why people spend over $600 on phones when a $200 could work just as well. With the new Moto G, I was willing to buy it right on the spot. But what turned me off was the nearly 3 weeks Id have to wait for one to be delivered. So I started my search for the next best phone under $200, which lead me to this phone. Ive had some experience with Alcatel phones, so I didn't have much expectations with this phone. That being said, Ive had a couple of days with it and I can say with absolute confidence that I love it.

-Design-

This is one light phone. Im starting with that because you have no idea how light it is until you hold it in your hand. I actually thought for a moment that the battery wasn't inside it yet. But it is pleasant to hold in the hand. The design is all plastic, so don't expect anything premium on this phone like metal. But it is solidly built, rivaling even the Galaxy S5 in build quality. Speaking of which, this phone is lighter and slimmer than the S5. If the phone were sold for more money, Id still be satisfied. Its not just good build quality for the price. Its excellent build quality. Period. The chrome accent is a nice touch and the speaker grills are slightly angled towards the phone, which add a bit of sparkle to an otherwise black phone. No soft touch plastic on this phone, but it does land on a middle ground where the plastic is nice to touch and is resistant to fingerprints. The design is completely symmetrical, which is important for a certain feature that is unique to it. Id love it even more if it were available in a different color such as white, but that is personal preference. Overall, I cant find much to complain; especially for the low $180 price.

-Performance-
If you have seen the Moto Gs specs, you're pretty much getting the same hardware. It uses a Snapdragon 410, 720p display, microSD expansion, Android Lollipop, and even the same camera module (Sony IMX 214). However, there are a few key difference that make this a better phone than the Moto G. For instance, this phone has 1.5 GB of RAM (Moto G=1GB), actual front facing stereo speakers, a 4.7 compared to the 5, NFC, and 16GB of storage(Moto G=1GB). In benchmarks, I have gotten similar results to the Moto G in both CPU and graphic performance. But benchmarks are only one side of the performance experience. The other is daily user experience. Based on the couple of days with it and after installing many apps, I can tell you that this phone is snappy. Its not as fast as the current flagship lineup, but it never lags or clips the graphics. Apps open relatively quickly and the animations are smooth, as well as the transitions from one app to another. In my testing of multitasking ability, it opened Chrome, Angry Birds, Pokemon Puzzle, and YouTube with no lag and each app open where I left them off. Opening more will force the phone to suspend one of those apps to save RAM, but 4 apps at once without closing is pretty good for the cost. Games also perform good, as long as you have reasonable expectations. 2D games such as Angry Birds, Pokemon Puzzle, and Clash of Clans run smoothly and without an issue. Other games like Asphalt 8 and Real Racing 3 will run smooth, but not at the highest quality setting. But thats to be expected from a midrange phone. Signal quality is good. I was able to get 62 Mbps download speed and 8 Mbps upload on T-Mobiles 4G LTE around Pasadena, CA. Thanks to band 12 support, cell signal in buildings is good with the signal almost never going under 3 bars. The speakers are also amazingly good and loud, coming close to matching HTCs Boomsound phone speakers thanks to the help from JBL. Overall, it performs close to flagship specs, albeit a bit slower. Most people should be happy with this phone.

-Display-

The phone itself has a beautiful HD display with a 312 PPI (note that the iPhone 6 has a 324 PPI) and it is advertise as being calibrated by Technicolor. While they aren't at the S6s quality display, it does come close. The display has a nice color calibration, with vivid colors and nice blacks and whites. It is also bright enough for using even in direct sunlight and the good contrast means you can clearly see what you are doing. It isn't perfect since there are a couple of issues. The colors do have a VERY slight cool tone, meaning that the whites do have a TINY bit of blue to them. Another small issue is that there is a slight amount of light bleed on one side of the displace. But it isn't noticeable in daily use and it is good for the price of the phone. One crucial one is the fact that they aren't using Gorilla glass on this display, opting for the more discreet Dragontrail Glass. Since this is going to be my daily driver, I didn't want to test the toughness (if Alcatel provides me a unit, Id gladly test it) but Ive looked into it and it trades scratch resistance for toughness. It might be easier to scratch it, but it is more resistant to shock. Only time will tell and I will update this review as time moves on.

-Camera-
The camera is a back-facing 13 MP camera and a front, wide angle 5 MP camera. The rear camera uses a Sony Exmor IMX 214, which is the same unit found in the new Moto G and the more expensive Nexus 6. The results are mixed though. On one side, outdoor pictures are good. Whenever there is good lighting such as outside or a well lit room, the pictures do come out high quality with colors mostly accurate and the camera absorbing a lot of details. However, during the night, the picture quality takes a hit, with the camera struggling to get any details from the lack of light. It will get some details if they is ANY type of light, but not much. The lack of OIS also contributes to this issue, but there is no phone with OIS at this price range at the moment. The flash is okay, but since it isn't a dual tone unit, the light tends to overflow and photos tend to lose their details. Videos are also a similar story, with good lighting providing good results and the opposite being true. There is EIS, but the effect isn't that noticeable and it doesnt really help with the quality. This isn't a camera you're going to use for important, memorable moments. But for things that most people use, like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, it works great. This is especially true for the  front facing camera, with the selfie cam grabbing a lot of details, provided there is good amount of light.

-Software-

This is basically running a close to stock version of Android Lollipop. It is running version 5.0.2 with a Stagefright patch already added to protect the phone from foreign attacks. There are a few changes to the software. For instance, the icons look like similar to the iPhone, which can be both a good and bad thing, depending on whether you love or hate that style. Other than that, everything works just like stock Android. Except for one feature that Im surprised isn't universal to all phones. That is the fact that this phone is reversible. It doesnt sound as exciting as fingerprint sensor, but it is a rather practical  and underrated feature. Ive answered the phone to test the sound quality and it wasn't until after I hung up that I realized the phone was upside down. It sounds equally good on either orientation and it is brilliant. Of course, if you don't like this (for some reason) there is always the option to turn it off. Overall, the light touch that Alcatel added onto Android hasn't hurt it much and any problems can be easily fixed.

-Conclusion-

I wasn't expecting to get a high quality phone, especially after my experience with an old model that I cant even remember the name. But Alcatel did deliver a high quality experience and an astonishing device. It does have some compromises, but Alcatel chose them wisely and the overall result is great. There is a couple of phones that compete in this range, but the biggest one is the Moto G. Is this better? Yes and no. For power users, I would still recommend the high end Moto G because of the extra RAM or even a OnePlus One, which is on sale now for $299. But if it must be under $200, like for college students like me, this beats the $179 low end Moto G due to the higher quality speakers, display, NFC, and the slightly more RAM. This phone helps to answer the question: Do people really need to spend over $800 on a phone to get a high quality experience? The answer for most people is no. They dont. There is a market for people who need to have the latest and greatest with all the new extras like fingerprint sensor and DSLR-like quality cameras. But for the rest of us, there are phone that does what we ask from it and reasonably well not just for the price, but just overall. If you are on the fence and frustrated from searching like I was, let me help you. Go for this phone and you won't be disappointed.
summary: Looking for the Best Budget Phone? Look no further.

reviewText: bought for my friends white iPhone 5, looks super cute, and is moderately sturdy. great case if you're not dropping your phone every 5 minutes..

Meets expectations, efficient size and value

EDIT: After using these headphones for a total of about ~40 hours of international flight time, I can recommend these without reservation. They performed flawlessly, cutting cabin noise to almost nothing, and they also allowed me to use my MP3 player without having to turn up the volume above my usual setting. Both the airplane cabin and engine noise were almost completely suppressed while still allowing me to clearly hear in-flight announcements.

In short, these are a *great* set of noise cancelling headphones that work extremely well and are priced very affordably. These are as good or better than the Bose headphones which cost 3 or 4 times as much.
-----------------------

Wow. Simply put, these are great noise cancelling headphones, well-made and inexpensive. They knock out about 90% of common low-end, cyclical noise like fans, engines, compressors, etc and cost less than a 1/3 of the Bose noise cancelling headphones. I'll be testing these more against some high-end Bose headphones and also on a long airplane trip shortly, but my first impression is that they work very well. Turn them on and everything...just...gets...quiet. Standing next to a refrigerator and turning them on makes it sound like the refrigerator just stopped running.

They come in a nice travel case with 2 patch cords, a 1/4" adapter, an airplane adapter, and a battery. The little pouch that holds the cords and  stuff detaches from the carrying case so you can put in a bag separately if you don't want to lug the carrying case around.

The instructions are a hoot- very spacey. For example, the instructions start off with this little bit of Zen prose:

------------------------------------------
9,000m in the sky, 7-hour time difference,
over 7,000 miles apart.
The cabin mix with the travel tiredness and the unique smell,
the soul inside the body can finally relax.
This moment, rare and precious.
Changing a pose and choosing an old song,
Put on my headphone.

A short rest,
for getting rid of the plane roaring,
for escaping preciseness and all the worries,
finding the real me and this moment of satisfaction,
Pursuit of a lifetime, mixed in the hubub and noise,
I finally know the meaning of content in calmness,
233621 grants you the best quiet space.
Silence is Golden.
------------------------------------------

Lol, what's not to like about that? :) The translation of the directions are a little bit shaky but still completely understandable. Plugging an MP3 player into them results in good, clear sound, no complaints there. The headband seems sturdy and is well-padded and the earcups also seem very comfortable- much better than the "on-ear" style.

Two very minor gripes: 1) I wish that the headphone cups would fold in (swivel) to store a little more compactly, but this is a very minor gripe.  2) The audio input jack on my pair is a little loose, but that's probably just this pair. If it gets too loose I'll return them for the exact same model, that's how much I like these so far.

All in all, I'm impressed with these and looking forward to using them and putting them up against the $350 Bose headphones. My guess is that there will hardly be any noticeable difference, and I'll update this to let you know what I find. But so far these seems to be an outstanding deal for the money.
summary: Work EXTREMELY well and are priced right!

I already owned a couple of battery cases, so when I was offered this one to review, I knew that I would have something with which to compare it.  It's a shame-- if I didn't know what else was out there, I could have given it more stars.

GPEL describes this as a Qi Wireless Charging Battery Case.  Unfortunately, while it's a decent as a case, it's pretty weak as a battery case-- it only contains a 590mAh battery.  On the GPEL Amazon webpage's "Compare to Similar Items", the first battery case listed, also a Qi Wireless Charging Case offers a 3000mAh battery for four cents less.  That's five times better.  A brief and incomplete survey of Qi Wireless Battery cases on Amazon shows cases varying from 2200mAh to 10000mAh, but no other brand was under 1000.

The case is attractive. The back is sleek and silver-colored.  It adds barely more than half an inch to the length of iPhone 6 and 6s, and less than three-tenths of an inch each in width and depth. I wear a leather belt holster designed for the iPhone 6, and this case fits it with minimal snugness.  It has a slight overlap over the screen, protecting it when the phone is placed screen down on a table or desk, and the case itself serves protects against drops and falls.

It gives easy access to all the iPhone 6's buttons and switches, with the exception of the audio port-- because of the length of the case, the provided adapter is necessary (I often use Bluetooth earphones, so the issue doesn't arise).

Unable to recommend, due to battery capacity.

[I received this product at minimal or no cost, for the purpose of evaluation and unbiased review. I accept no financial remuneration for reviewing products, nor do I resell anything I have reviewed.]
summary: Low-capacity battery keeps case from succeeding

I've been using wet application screen protectors for a couple years now. They are so much better than the dry application kind... when I first started using them, I was very careful about the liquid and dust/lint, etc... after having applied several sets of these to various phones and tablets over the years, I have become pretty cavalier about the application process.  I wash my hands with soap and water, do a few pumps of the liquid on my fingers that Skinomi includes, then a couple pumps on the phone and a couple more on the protector.  Then I peel off the protector from it's backing, slap it on the phone and align it just right.  Bring the the squeegee and squeegee off the excess water, trying to mostly avoid the holes (earpiece, etc...) in the phone and then dry it off with a cloth.

I then let the phone sit over night still turned off and it's ready to go in the morning.  The screen looks pretty bad for the first 24 - 48 hours, but once all the liquid evaporates through the protector materiel, it is usually clear as glass and I've not yet had any real problem with dust.  If I had a complaint about wet application protectors is that they don't feel nearly as nice as glass and some dry application protectors.  This is really a minor quibble, but the rubbery material that these Skinomi protectors are made of kind of drags on the finger when you are sliding around the screen.  It's not bad, but not nearly as kinesthetically pleasing as sliding around the glass.  As I said, it's a minor quibble on an otherwise excellent product.  The fit on the Nexus 5 is spot on - I was a little concerned that it did not have cutouts for the light sensor and mass sensors (but it does for the speaker), but it doesn't seem to affect the performance of either sensor, so I guess they aren't necessary.

Overall, an excellent product and I heartily recommend these to anyone looking for a screen protector.  Don't let the wet application scare you away, it's not really that hard and the fit and finish of the final product once installed is vastly superior to any dry application screen protector I have ever used (and I've used plenty!).

To me it holds on to fingerprints easily, not too different from the actual screen itself, no distortion nor does it affect the display at all, and it is extremely smooth when sliding your finger around.

[I]**ZeroLemon contacted me about a week ago asking if I would like to receive a free review unit of the Nexus 6 Slim Power case, and I accepted. This is a non-bias review on the case. I received it 9/16/2015 and promptly installed it. This review will be updated for 7 days.**[/I]

I have previously used ZeroLemon products for my Galaxy Nexus, Galaxy S4, and my girlfriends Nexus 5. I have found that the internal replacement batteries are much better than the externals, but the external ones come with cases that may actually give your phone a chance to live during a drop. I have so far enjoyed all of my ZeroLemon products.

[B]9/16: [/B]Received ZeroLemon slim power case in the mail and installed it immediately, replacing my SUPCASE Unicorn Beetle Pro.

The first thing I notice was that this case literally doubles the thickness of the phone. Not only that, but it adds nearly half an inch to the bottom of the phone below the speaker. The battery included in the package fits very will in the case, but I'm still a bit shocked that ZeroLemon thought 3500mAh was enough.

The case comes with a Z-shaped connector to keep the phone and the battery connected, and allows pass-through charging via a micro-USB port on the left side of the phone. There is also a decent sized cutout on top for the 3.5mm jack, though they decided to include a 3" 3.5mm extension with the case.

To turn the battery on, you hold the power button on the back for a few seconds and you will have confirmation by your phone beginning to charge, as well as 4 blue LED lights on the back of the case. This works exactly the same as all of their other cases for phones with non-user-replaceable batteries.

[B]First impressions: [/B]

-This thing is big. It's got a nice weight to it and makes it feel solid. Fits well in my hand (I have fairly large hands for a 25 year old male).
-The power and volume buttons are EXTREMELY SENSITIVE. I can't tell you how many times I have accidentally pressed something when just picking the phone up.
- No Qi-charging. Unfortunately, ZeroLemon does not give us a Qi capable battery, and the case is so thick that even a 3-coil charger will not penetrate it. (Now I have 2 nice Qi chargers that I can't use)
-No Quick Charge 2.0. This (as well as not having Qi) was a real bummer. ZeroLemon had previously sent me one of their Quick Charge 2.0 chargers, but it seems that it is now useless as you are actually charging the external battery, which in turn charges the phone.
-Single piece construction. The case itself feels solid, but I was hoping that it would be more like the one for the Nexus 5 that was 2-piece and had a plastic screen protector.

They really needed to include a belt clip with this case. It's that big. Because of the size and the buttons being so sensitive, I can't really carry the phone in my pants pocket. When I put it in the breast pocket of my shirt, half of the phone sticks out, and the thickness almost prevents it from sliding in at all. Not including some sort of belt clip was a very poor idea.

[B]9/22:[/B]

So I've been using my ZeroLemon SlimPower case for about a week now.

More things of note:
-NFC does not function with this case on
-Full charge of the battery in the case gave me about 40% charge (went from 30% to 71%)
-Buttons are WAY too sensitive. Just from being in my pocket and walking around, My battery life has been terrible (screen keeps turning on and off)
-The case does not do a very good job of protecting the phone. The two times that my phone fell (once from the arm of the couch, the other from the coffee table), the case literally just popped right off. A case this large really needs to be 2-stage or have some way to hold the phone in better.
-My cullular signal also seems to be hindered with this case installed. Where I would normally have a little bit of service at my office, I have no connection with this case on. Immediately when the case comes off, I have service again.
-Have had the phone randomly restart on me 3 times since having this installed. Never had an issue with this before.

All of my initial impressions stayed with me the entire time using this case.

I can see times where having the extra battery could be useful, but honestly, you are better off getting an External battery for the same price as this case or likely even less. Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this case.
summary: Does not live up to the reputation of its maker.

reviewText: I have never bothered to write a review on Amazon before, but this experience was so frustrating I had to stop others from wasting their time and money. The problem is that these films are impossible to apply without getting some dust and bubbles. I have gotten about 60% of the screen bubble/dust free but the rest is impossible. Because you peel away the film on the underside as you lay it down, the films create a static that draws dust as you get past about halfway. The instructions to clean the screen in a "dust free environment" is laughable. Do they think everyone has access to the clean rooms used in semiconductor fabs or operating rooms? The "soft card" intended to scrape away bubbles is also useless, better to just use a credit card with a longer and more usable edge. Perhaps it is worse here in dry Colorado where humidity is low? Another gripe, albeit minor, is that it is difficult to align the film straight over such a large surface. They should really make the front facing camera hole a little larger to avoid alignment issues. Maybe Apple should just start offering matte glass straight from the factory, because this is a waste of time. Politics is less frustrating that applying these films (and I've done it successfully on phones many times but the large surface area makes it impossible).

I have used quite a few smartphones in the last few years, (I probably go through like 5 a year just buying/selling on ebay). I remember when under 3 inches was still a decent size. I got an HTC diamond and it had a 2.8 inch screen and I loved it. The iphone had a upped screen when it came out to with a huge 3.5 inch. Now we have phones coming out classified as mini (Galaxy s III mini) with a 4 inch screen. The huge phone displays look great but are awkward to hold, and in the pocket. 4inch has probably been my favourite size so far, I was excited about the lg viper but the design and battery life were really bleh. I recently gave a try to the Galaxy Victory and it was fantastic but the battery life and the size of it were just to much, so i'm swapping for this.

I saw the galaxy victory and it seemed like the perfect fit. The phone is 4 inches, plenty of resolution for the size, plenty of ram, an S4 processor, decent design and decent sized battery (same one as the Galaxy S III)

So sorry for the ranting, here we go. I've put it through the tests over the day and I've had great results.

The screen looks great, It's LCD not an AMOLED but it gets the job done fine. I miss the contrast ratio when reading in the dark.

It performs really great, I put it through tests and games run great, running quadrant shows it really close to the htc one x. Really don't let the midrange category of this phone scare you off performance wise, the S4 is what is in some versions of the Galaxy S III and HTC One X, Its a S4 lite and lower clock but its not horribly far off.

Physical design while not the best, is not to bad either. The phone feels good in the had, it has a good texture and weight. I wish the power button was on the side but its not bad on the top. It has a camera button which I LOVE. Function buttons on the bottom are good though I wish there was a multitasking button (though you can just hold home to do it)

Samsung's customizations are surprisingly fairly useful, the launcher isn't to distracting, performs well and has some good shortcuts over stock. However one bad thing is that folders are a bit more difficult to make, but its like just one more step. It comes with some of Samsung's applications and enhancements which are mostly fine, I tried out the S Voice and it was pretty terrible.

battery life has been pretty awesome, it almost matches my Galaxy Nexus with extended battery (3850 mah). To give my battery use today, I was at work from like 7am - 5pm today, my service at work is terrible like 0-1 bars most of the day which wrecks batteries. I texted about 30-40 texts probably, did some ebaying, a bit of web surfing, I did like a 5 minute gps nav, played a game for like 10 minutes, checked weather a couple times. When I got home my battery said it was unplugged for 11 hours and I had 60 percent left, I used the program "easy battery saver" also, I'm not sure how much that affected the battery life though.

Camera seems to be fine, I'm not to concerned with quality on my cellphone, as long as it takes a picture and I can tell what it is, the camera button works great too.

Reasons I gave a 4: as mentioned above, some of the software (S voice) aren't to great but they aren't really needed either. The function buttons are fine but the home button for some reason has like a second delay before it does anything, which is slightly annoying. The phone has NO haptic feedback build into it, so if you need that it's a no go.

So really nothing to horrible unless you need haptic feedback, I highly recommend if you want a smaller phone on sprint.
comment if you have any questions, hope you enjoyed.

reviewText:
Ting's pricing is great, and the support is fantastic - you get a response from a real person right away, and they what they're talking about. Ting runs off the T-Mobile's network, which means it'll work with almost any unlocked phone.

Unlike other carriers, Ting charges you based on whatever level of usage you reach each month, so the more you use every month the more you pay. But usage is billed by level, so like a traditional plan, you could still end up paying for minutes or texts or data you never use. For instance, the "M" level for voice calls charges you $9 for any usage between 101 and 500 minutes.

Still, this "planless" model is a pretty good deal if keep an eye on your usage and don't go overboard.

Now you might be thinking "Gee, this sounds like it could also be a great way to save money for my whole family or my business!" Well if you are thinking that, not so fast! I tried this and it didn't work out well at all.

First, unless you don't mind paying a ton when everyone streams movies or talks all night, you'll have to prevent unlimited use. Ting lets you set up caps to cut off usage after a certain number of minutes, megabytes, or texts is reached, but it's not reliable - and they admit it! For instance I capped data at 475MB to avoid going into the next level that starts at 500MB, but usage still hit 509MB before being capped. I contacted support and they said they cant cut off in-progress calls or downloads (and realistically, that would be a bad idea), so they recommended setting the cap lower. But the lower you set a cap in a level, the more likely youll end up wasting minutes or data (and money) - and no matter where the cap is, you could still end up in a higher level since caps don't trigger until a call or a download is finished... which means a really long call or download could still blow through a whole level or even more (P. S. caps on texting supposedly do work reliably).

The other problem is that although you can always login to your account and see the usage on all lines, theres no way for individual users to see their own usage. The closest you can get is to set up alerts that are triggered at a specific amount of usage - but the alerts only say how much youve used, not how much is left.

Finally, adding/editing usage alerts and caps is a pain; you have to create separate caps and alerts for voice vs. text vs. data. So if you want to prevent all unlimited use, and you want to alert when getting close to your caps, youll have to create 3 caps and 3 alerts per line (it doesnt help that doing it on their site is tedious and slow).

Overall, my take on Ting is that it's great for individuals who clearly understand the pricing model, but its a poor choice for families/businesses. Instead you might want to look at a cheap carrier with more traditional plans, such as US Mobile. Theyre a really good deal if you don't use your phone that much, but their prices are not as great for higher levels of usage. And like Ting they also have excellent support and also run on T-Mobiles network.
summary: Good until you try to limit usage

First off, it is the best device I've ever owned and I'm never buying anything other than Xiaomi ever again as long as the quality stays this high.
  I bought this on a business trip to China, I knew about it and almost got it on eBay but it was a lot cheaper in the store, about $120.
  This phone is beautiful. Its fingerprint sensor somehow adds to the beauty. The curved edged and clear display along with the sandblasted exterior make for a gorgeous device.
  This phone is functional. It is fast, intuitive. I feel like the developers took everything you wished apple and Android iOS had, and they put it there. One instance, is on Apple devices you swipe up from the bottom of the screen to have a quick menu. You can turn off WiFi connection, get to the calculator, blah blah. I always wished with my iPhone 5s that if you held on the WiFi button it would take you into the settings for WiFi. Xiaomi does that! Holding on any toggle button will take you into the settings menu for that.
In addition, there is spotlight search just like Apple. If you swipe up from the bottom of the screen you get the same search options as you do on the iPhone. I have had 3 iPhones and 1 galaxy phone, and I miss NOTHING.
  The display is true to life colors. It has less glare but is still glossy and the best one in its flagship class.
  The only con is that it did not have Google play store on it. Check with this seller, they may have it on there. But when I bought it in the xiaomi store it only had the mi appstore on it, where I was able to download a few apps and follow along with a YouTube video to get Google play working great, and all the apps run as they should.
  The fingerprint is pretty great. Placed on the back of the phone, by the time you pull it out of your pocket, it's unlocked. I especially love it because with the iPhone you had to wake the screen and then place your finger on the home button at the bottom. So many times this would make me loose my grip since I'm only holding the bottom bit of the phone and then boom my $500 device gets dropped.... Again. With the redmi, simply placing your finger on the sensor wakes the screen and unlocks the phone, you don't even need to press a button. Now I'll be honest. It isn't 100%. I get my finger read about 90% of the time, but at this price point I couldn't care less.
  The phone has some really cool features. In the security app you can lock apps,  so if I wanted I could make snapchat require my fingerprint to open the app. There are hidden albums, and the folders hold unlimited apps.
  One of the best in my opinion-- it's basically a computer. I plugged a micro USB flash drive into my redmi and I was able to move files, work on a word document, make and delete folders. I have never even seen that on Apple.
  The battery life is to DIE for. 4,100 mAph has never run out on me even with a full day of use. I used to have to keep chargers everywhere for my galaxy and iPhones. One in the car, my bag, an extra battery, sevral around the house. Nope. I keep one charger in my bedroom and that is all I need.
  Any new phone takes some getting used to. I keep finding new things I love  all the time and I've had this since the launch in February 2016. Do yourself a favor, pop over to Ebay and buy 1-2 tempered glass screen covers and a nice case. The glass costs me 0.99 with free shipping and the cases are 0.99-$6. Buy them at the same time as the phone, if not before. They will save you. I drop this poor redmi all the time and 3 screen protectors have shattered, leaving the actual screen unharmed.
  I can't wait to see what xiaomi comes out with next, the next time I need a new phone it's going to be from them.

update: It is now February 2017 and I still love this phone, and continue to find reasons to. The Mi cloud is very helpful as well and that just about all I have to add. 10/10 amazing device.

First I'd like to preface this review by saying that I've used it since Sept 2015 and it has held up (including the wallet part) til now which is quite remarkable for how little I paid. A few flaws: the major one is that it did not protect my phone when it fell from my 2 year old's hand onto the bathroom tile floor. It landed on the edge and the screen cracked. Well I got my phone fixed and have since gotten a glass screen protector that curves and covers the entire edges so we'll see if that protects better. Second major issue - the flash on the camera is partially blocked my the opening in the back so my flash pictures all have a pink hue, which is ok if you love every flash picture you take to be pink-hued, but that is not my intention. Third, the wallet flap on the back has stretched out a bit so you have to be careful that things don't slip out. I did overstuff it and I have 3 cards in the top pocket and 2-3 in the lower pocket. Also the stand has loosened as well and slips down/opens all the way occasionally. A few other minor quips - there is no lip on the front so when you have your phone face down, the glass is touching the table surface. Also I wish the credit cards were not so obviously exposed - I don't want people to see my cards and information so easily. Until I can find a better phone cover/wallet replacement, I'll continue to use this for now.
summary: Okay phone case but 3 major issues

This is a very nice multi function USB cable. It converts USB 2.0 to either Micro USB or Type C.

USB type c is the latest type of usb connector and in my books is amazing. Type c connections do not need to be plugged into the device in a set way. You can insert this either side up.

Here is a quick chart for your reading pleasure. (Data pulled from CNET)
USB 1.1  Top Speed 12mb/s  Max Power 2.5v or 500mA
USB 2.0  Top Speed 480mb/s = Max Power 2.5v or 1.8A
USB 3.0  Top Speed 5gb/s = Max Power 5v or 1.8A
USB 3.1 (TYPE C) = Top Speed 10gb/s = Max Power 5v or 5A

The reason this is ideal over other type c cables you see is that is has the extra function of converting to micro usb as well! Almost all phones are now either micro usb or type c in terms of charging-data ports.

This cable will ensure you always have the right type of charging  data cable.

This cord is 3.3 long and is flat in design which is the best type for keeping it from tangling!
It feels solid and has a nice coating to it.

Follows TYPE C SPEC and will work with all your normal wall usb chargers and hubs. Tried with Sabrent, HP, Unitek and Samsung chargers with perfect results.

I would certainly recommend this to friends and family!

UPDATED 12/21/15: After just under 6 months of use my "good little speaker" has died. This speaker became a big part of my everyday. I do not have a Bluetooth capable sound system in my car and I would use this little speaker daily on my commute to and from work and on other errands. I also used it all over the house to make cleaning more bearable and when playing with my son in his room. I treated it well and though it is "water proof" I kept it far from water most times because I wanted to make sure it would last through the long haul. Even with treating it well a little over a week ago I turned it on in the car and it emitted an earsplitting screech that scared me and my son and then wouldn't work. I turned it off and didn't try it again that morning. That afternoon I tried it again and it worked but the sound was so quite I could not hear it, even though it's volume was at it's highest and my iPhone volume was turned up to the max as well. Since then it won't ever turn on and it gets very hot underneath the command buttons. I am very sad about this. I am hoping this is just a fluke incident and that more people won't have this problem. Since I don't know that it is though I have taken it from 4 stars to 2 stars.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: I really like this little speaker so far. It's a nice size. Small enough to take with you from room to room but big enough that you can easily find it if your one-year-old walks off with it. I also like that it is "rugged" because that same one-year-old does like to walk off with it but usually ends up dropping it after a few minutes when something else catches his attention. Being able to use it near my shower in the morning is a big plus. Because of the set up of my bathroom there are no electrical outlets near enough to my tub/shower for me to be able to use a normal radio. Since this is water resistant I can set it on the edge of the tub while I shower and leave my phone out of the way of the water and still be able to hear my audio book, a huge plus for me. The controls are easy to use and the battery life is pretty decent. I do wish the volume went just a few steps higher but I haven't had a problem with any sound distortion at the highest setting. The one real con I have is that the distance between my phone and this speaker has to be quite close or it loses connection or will do this weird skipping thing when my book/music plays. Most of the time this isn't an issue but when near the water I want my phone no where near it. Really, it's a great little speaker and I recommend it.
Worth the price
A great deal and it looks good.
Did not fit my phone

Sometimes it's hard to tell the difference between all the screen protector choices out there.  I was about to just buy the cheapest one, but saw that this one comes with a lifetime replacement warranty.  I have had difficulties in the past with screen protectors, and have screwed up my fair share, so a lifetime replacement definitely caught my attention.  Sure enough when I got these, I got lint on the first one I tried applying before I could properly adhere it.  When I tried to remove the lint I ended up dropping it on the ground!  The second one went on fine.  This only left me with one as a back up though.  Well just the other day, I found I scratched up the one on my phone somehow.  Having only one left I decided to contact Tech Armor to inquire about the lifetime replacement.  Sure enough, they let me know they would ship out a replacement as soon as I gave them my information.  No hassle, no haggle!  I would definitely recommend this screen protector to anybody looking for one.  Lifetime replacements!

**Update**

Well it was bound to happen sooner or later.  I dropped my phone, and of all places and ways to fall, it fell face first right onto gravel!  I picked it up half expecting the screen to be cracked, but it only had a few pits.  Or did it?  The Tech Armor took the full impact of the gravel.  It did get a few pits in it, but my screen was perfectly fine!  Tech Armor did it's job, and thankfully, because of their lifetime warranty I had extras to replace the damaged one.  Definitely still recommend using this screen protector.  Thanks Tech Armor!
summary: Great Product and Even Better Service!

The iSmooth screen protector turned out to be a good buy for me.  The package came with everything you needed for the install.  The kit came with 3 screen protectors, a large cleaning cloth, dust removal stickers, and installation instructions and other documentation.  I've purchased many screen protectors in the past and this is the first time I've received a decent sized cleaning cloth.  It may not be a big deal to others but this was a pleasant surprise for me.  The install instructions were very detailed and straight forward.  They even had a website you could visit to watch a video of the installation process for those that need visuals.  Although they didn't have an install video for the Note 3, they did have a video for the Note 2.  The video instructions sequence was the following: Turn off phone, wipe down screen with cleaning cloth, remove tab 1 and apply screen protector, identify dust bubbles (not air bubbles) and use dust removal stickers to remove the dust, finish applying screen protector pushing out all air bubbles, and remove tab 2.  I figured why should I apply the screen protector first to identify dust bubbles.  After cleaning the screen with the cleaning cloth, I used a dust removal sticker all throughout the screen before applying the screen protector.  After doing this, I did not see a single dust bubble.  Once I pushed out all the air bubbles, the screen appeared crystal clear.

Overall, this screen protector looks great.  I highly recommend this screen protector.  This product also has a lifetime warranty.
summary: Crystal clear screen protector for the Samsung Galaxy Note 3

reviewText: This is the second brand glass protector I've tried and I wish it would have been the first! I got it straight and even almost immediately and as soon as it touched the screen it pretty much did all the work for me, it spread over the screen with zero dust or bubbles and it fits absolutely perfect. It looks like the original glass of the phone and doesn't show smudges or finger prints. Every case I've put on my S5 has fit perfect around it and even as rough as I've been with it (shared pocket space with keys, change, etc...) there's still not a scratch on it. I've also dropped it face down twice on tiled floor and not a mark. This thing is going to last forever. I'd have to say this was even 1000 times easier to install than a typical plastic stick on protector. Long story made long......HIGHLY RECOMMEND IF YOU'RE GOING TO GET GLASS THIS IS THE ONE TO GET. I PROMISE! Oh....and I highly suggest glass for a screen protector. At least for a galaxy S5. It just makes the screen pop and the vibrant HD images look amazingly better through glass compared to stick ons(plastics....zagg....etc.)

It has a great grip that will not slip out of your hand. The stand is well constructed and not likely to break without effort and the clip is strong.

reviewText:
This holster is one of the best engineered accessories I have ever seen. I caught it on the car seat yesterday. Usually this case is tough enough to withstand that but I hit it very hard this time and it popped off. But instead of breaking as every other case I have ever used would, this one detached purposefully. I clipped the belt clip back onto the holster and back in business. Don't get me wrong, it is very sturdy and doesn't feel detachable at all. I was very surprised to see that it went right back together. But it didn't break.

My phone slides in and out very smoothly and easily. There is no clip on the top holding the phone in, which means that there are a few borderline situation when the phone will come out on it's own. Mostly when the holster is rotated to horizontal and you are jumping around; not a problem for me. And since the Nexus 4's shape is a mirror image both vertically and horizontally the phone can go into the holster facing up or down.

I love this case. I just ordered 2 more for the day I do figure out how to break this thing. When you consider that this holster only costs $6 it cannot be beat.
summary: Best engineered holster I have ever used

S5), and my gut kept telling me it was the magnet in the case.  I'd remove the phone and restart to get it working again, but upon reusing the case, it would work for a bit, then in a few days the same problem would occur.  I googled it and found a slew of complaints about both Samsung and Verizon knowing magnets can damage the phones, and some found the warning in the Samsung manual, but the chat sessions with them said "No problem, no damage to the phones with the magnetic cases."  Some decided to stay with them and see what happens and others strongly advise not to use any magnetic phone cases, pouches or holders at all.  I've decided to not use the case anymore and look for one like it without the magnetic feature, and I hate I have to do it cause I love the case features & convenience for shopping without a purse, especially.  I thought the magnet was a smart asset to secure the phone in the case, but not if it's slowly destroying it!

This Loca glue was very easy to apply. I saw different videos with different techniques on how to apply the glue.
These are my tips from my personal experience:
- Don't apply too much of the glue. It could block your microphone and flow over the sides of the phone.
- No need to create a shape during applying the glue according to some videos.
- Just apply the glue vertically in the middle of the LCD. A video on youtube shows dropping 3 big drops of glue, I applied 4 drops of glue in smaller amounts and it worked perfectly.
- Place the glass slowly, very sloooowww
- After the glass is in place, press the glass against the LCD to spread the Loca glue to cover up to all corners of the phone. Again, don't rush.
- It is sunny outside then you should be fine to let the glue dry. I used a UV light then 5-6 minutes were enough.
Good luck
summary: This is how I did it. I would buy it again

What a delightfully easy to apply product. The glass looks to be very durable. Its crystal clear and doesn't look or feel any different that a normal phone screen. Its slightly smaller than the regular glass, which doesn't bug me (leaves room on edges for a case to wrap around. Here's tips to use when applying this screen protector.
1. Turn shower on all the way hot and let steam build up for a minute or two
2. Clean Phone screen next to a window so you can see if any dust particles are on screen.
3. Walk to steamy bathroom and check screen for particles again
4. Peel 20% of the plastic off the protector and line up the hole at the top/ sides of glass
4. One lined up properly, begin to slowly peel plastic from under the the protector
5. While Slowly peeling plastic off, use the provided bubble card to apply pressure to the screen. This should ensure no bubbles from the get go.
6. After the plastics totally off, use the card to press screen down all over the screen (work bubbles to edge if necessary)

That's it! Looks great with no dust particles trapped underneath.

As a cell phone, I would not recommend this device as you are going to be locked to Verizon. (Currently cannot be unlocked, rooted, etc.)  Get the unlocked GSM version where you can shop around for carriers and flash custom ROMs.  Prepaid plans from AT&T, TruPhone, StraightTalk, etc. all beat the Verizon plans for the truly budget-minded consumer, especially when you consider the ability to swap SIMs with ease.

If you must have a Verizon phone because of coverage, then why bother with this budget device when you can just sign a contract for about the same amount per month and have a top of the line phone with LTE, for example?

However, if you just want something cheap to play with, then this is the ticket.  After hitting the auction sites for used phones that I could flash to Android 4.4, I decided this would be the better way to go for my projects.  This device is great for WiFi web cams, remote controls for copters, auto gauge clusters, etc.  The activation wizard is easy to bypass, just do a quick internet search.  Ships with 4.3, updates to 4.4 via a 247MB update.
summary: Great price, but not for a phone

Okay, it's a screen protector, and I'm pretty sure that the one I got actually is made of glass, rather than plastic.  It, indeed,  does not cover the whole screen, this one leaves about 1/8th inch bare around it.  Can't comment on durability, as I just installed it, but it was intact when it got here, at least.

It is very clear, and the touch screen function certainly doesn't seem bothered by its presence.  While it does seem to be better about prints than the stock screen, it still collects them, perhaps 35% of what the bare screen does.  That's not enough to bother me much, but I mention it for others who may see the matter differently.

My screen is pre-cracked (long story/I don't want to talk about it), so the "dry" installation method for this protector was much appreciated.  It went on a LOT more easily than I expected, I'd love to know something about the adhesive they use as it was pretty interesting to watch it take hold.  The protector seemed to somehow flow onto the screen without changing shape at all.  Very cool.

I'm going to hang onto it, at least for a while.  The case I use covers part of the screen edges anyway, so my bare screen exposure is closer to 1/16th inch, which I can live with for now.  If I decide that I like it, I'll consider upgrading to one that gives full coverage of the screen.  This one was cheap enough that I feel like it was a good gamble/research/learning experience for me (plus the entertainment value of the installation), but if you're not looking for that sort of experience, you may want to look elsewhere.

The screen protector is just as described.  You really have to follow the instructions down to the detail otherwise, you'll have a fly trap on your hands.  This thing has a smooth finish and it doesn't get in the way of swiping with my iPhone 5.  I suggest have a few paper towels or an Q-tip on hand to make sure you don't spill any on the earpiece of the phone.  It will drip a lot because it asks you to spray the solution on your hands and onto the front and back of the protector to prevent it from sticking to your fingers.  After about a few hours, you'll notice the imperfections start to go away and the remaining air bubbles just disappear after a full 12 hours. Plan on doing this overnight so that you'll have your phone back with you the next day.

The only bad thing about this product is that it only came with one measly protector.  Others come with at least two or three just in case you mess up the first one.  I would have given this a five star if it included a couple more screen protectors.  Overall, I do recommend this item but be patient with it to align it as best as you can.  I had to redo mine 2x to make it sit as evenly with the phone as possible.  You won't be disappointed once it's in place.  You'll even forget that it's there.

Update: 2/12/13

They have this program called Skinomi Awareness Program where you get an invitation and they send you a free screen protector for your gadget just for participating.  I changed the 4 stars that I originally gave them to 5 stars since my only complaint was the package only came with one protector.  Since they sent me an extra screen protector, I couldn't be any happier they did exactly what they said they would do.  I have recommended, I do, and I will recommend Skinomi TechSkin to everyone I know that's looking for a high quality screen protector for their smartphone, iPad and other tablets.  Not to mention joining the Skinomi Awareness Program to receive a free screen protector would be the icing on the cake.  Thank you Skinomi!

Update: 7/8/13

Now the 5 stars I gave this product is down to three.  It's only been eight months and it's already losing it's resistance to yellowing.  My phone is on average use and has never been exposed to sunlight or moisture which most plastics tend to suffer from if exposed to this type of environment.  It's changing to a yellowish color. This wasn't expected since Skinomi claims that their screen protector is resistant to yellowing and scratches (it says so on the packaging).  The scratches passed the test, but the yellowing, not so much.  I have the white iPhone 5 and it looks "dirty" on the white parts of the phone now compared to when I first installed the screen protector.  I can safely assume this is going to get worse so I have changed my stance about this product.  I will be removing this screen protector soon.

If you have the black iPhone 5 then this is not a problem, but if you have the white, then this will be a problem.  To some people this might not be a big deal, as long as it's protecting the screen, right?  I respect that about you but if you're like me and you have invested money on an awesome phone, don't you want it to be protected and look good at the same time?  Not looking cheap and slowly turning yellow instead of a bright white?  This is just my two cents worth to anyone willing to read this.

reviewText:
By now you've likely read dozens of in-depth reviews on this phone and maybe even watched video reviews, so I won't bore you with redundant repetition of the specs and so on.  I'll assume you know all of that stuff by now and want an actual opinion from an average Joe smartphone user who's neither a technophile spechound nor a "I don't know how to use thing thing" newbie, but comfortably just the other side of center.

The phone is thin but not 'geeze I'm going to snap it in half' thin, large enough to be 'big' yet not ridiculous phablet-big, not too big to hold with one adult hand.  Not too big to fit in your pants or coat/jacket pocket.

The M9 is lightweight, but not a 'cheap' lightweight, kind of a 'just right' lightweight.  It's metal, so it has a good weight for its size and feels good in your hand.  I came from an HTC Rezound with extended battery (and therefore larger thicker rear door) and this phone was strangely thin the first few days of use.  If you're coming from another thin-type phone this likely won't feel too different.  If you have large (or small) fumbly man hands, you may want a grippy case for this one.

The phone is fast.  I have flipped the screens as fast as I could trying to get it to lag, but I couldn't.  It comes with up to 6 home screens (previous HTC phones had 7).  It comes with standard HTC widgets you may be used to, such as Calculator, People, Calendar, Email, etc (although it appears the stock Weather widget is gone unless I am blind), except they've all received a facelift.  It also comes with a new one, called Blinkfeed.  Blinkfeed is always the first screen to the Left of Home (swipe to the right to bring the Left screen over).  Blinkfeed, which I consider simply an updated and way more user-friendly "Friendstream" from previous models,  places your social media program contents (Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, News) into tiled updates so you can scroll up & down and get it all on one widget, theoretically w/o having to go to your FB app or IG app, or CNN.  Old habits are hard to break, I still find myself preferring Instagram on Instagram and not on Blinkfeed, but I'm trying to give it a fair go.  I may just put a calculator there, who really knows....

Ringtones are all updated, as are text/email notifications.  They sound much nicer, crisper, modern.  The problem is, if you've been used to a certain tone- all your faves are GONE!  [tear].  Time to get used to new ringtones, especially if you had assigned tones and knew across the room who just texted you.

The notification bar at the top is updated with better results when you swipe it down.  It works faster, it contains more, is visually more crisp and tight, and swiping down with two fingers at once automatically opens the main settings screen such as WiFi, Airplane mode, Brightness, etc etc etc, with another gear symbol to open further settings.  It has a "Glove Mode" to make the screen extra sensitive for when you're wearing gloves.  Whatever you do, don't take off a glove!  :)

Apps in the "app drawer" or simply the 'app screen' as I call it, can be sorted into crowded mode (4 apps wide x 5 tall like they've always been), or 3x4 mode, which is far easier on the eye in my opinion.

The back button, home button, etc at the bottom of the screen are not hard buttons like on previous HTC phones, but are actually soft keys, or on-screen buttons at the bottom of the screen, giving the appearance of hard key buttons.  They can be customized too.  So if you want your back arrow button on the left, the right, the center- it's your call.  They've added a 'screen off' button to the mix too, which I added to the soft key row.  Now I can touch the tiny button to turn the screen off instead of having to use the physical power button on the side spine.  Love that.  Also there's an Open Apps button there too, with one-click cancel of all previous apps.  (This was done on older HTC phones by long-pressing the Home button and swiping each task off the screen one by one).

It has a zillion (approximately) other customizations, alerts, shortcuts, etc.  If you want to do a certain thing or make it look a certain way, chances are it will you just need to go into a setting somewhere.

Nice bright screen.  On full brightness I could easily view it bright sunshine, not sure if the 1080p resolution accounts for any of that, or if it's simply a brighter slew of LEDs, but it's decent on sunny days.  A tad better than other smartphones I've owned.  Slippery (in a good way) and tough Gorilla glass screen makes it easy to swipe on.  I seen a video where a guy was trying to scratch the front glass with keys and a knife and couldn't.  That's great.  (The rest of the phone however, including the camera lens, were far less resistant to scratches.)

The phone is very pretty, ughh, I mean attractive.  The silver on gold color looks classy and is a welcome change from the black I've had for years on other phones.  The aluminum body is brushed so it has a visual texture to it, adding to the classiness.  It has lots of  'leave out on the table for others to see' value to it.  Sexy, in other words.

The camera, even though 20MP, isn't terribly crisp, even in bright sunshine and on full resolution.  I don't understand this.  My HTC Rezound (from 2011/2012) takes stunning bright sunlight pictures and it's "only" 8MP (I understand MP has little to do with picture clarity, but one would assume improvements wouldn't lead to a drop in quality), and despite the negative reviews of the M9's low-light abilities, I thought bright light pics would be at least comparable to HTC's older phones (Incredible, Rezound) but it really isn't, which is strange.  This disappoints me a little but I don't lose sleep over it.  If you're the type that insists on the best of the best, the camera will likely disappoint you too.  But if you're a pro photographer, you won't be using your cell phone anyway.  Cell cameras are meant for taking pics at concerts, selfies, rollercoasters, your dinner at Applebee's, the big fish you just caught, and the shopping list you left on the counter being texted to you from your significant other.  Not the bridal party or Junior's 1 year pics.  it doe shave a slew of goodies in the camera bag.  Photobooth, Burst, "Bokeh" (pronounced bouquet, term for an in-focus subject w/ blurry background), 4K video (which ironically is a slower frame rate and therefore more choppy) and a host of on-board effects make it kind of fun to play with.  It snaps pictures fast, especially if you have the 'review' feature off. Snap snap snap, no lag at all.

The charge port is now on the bottom, just right of center.  Next to it, on the bottom now as well, is the headphone jack.  I don't prefer either of these changes but I won't lose sleep over it.  The charger plug still inserts with the prongs facing you, facing up, facing the screen of the phone...so be watchful of this when purchasing a dock.  I have read reviews on docks that people have bought saying the charger prong was backwards and wouldn't fit this phone.  Supposedly the soon to be released "M9+" comes with a reversible charger prong/port similar to Apple's iPhone chargers.  If that matters to you then there you go.

The volume buttons are still on the right spine. The Power button is now on the right spine as well, just under the volume buttons in the center.  I don't care that change either, but many people seem to prefer all of these button & port position changes.  I guess I don't know what everyone else knows or I'm not doing the same things others are doing and therefore don't appreciate these changes as much.

NO replaceable battery.  So, if you found yourself needing to replace your phone's battery every year or two....guess what....now you'll probably need to replace the phone.  I am NOT a fan of this change.  This is the biggest disappointment to me.  I assume this is in an effort to make you need to get a new phone, win win for HTC and your carrier both, whether you purchase your phone outright or extend your contract to get it for a discount.  Lose lose for Joe consumer who would just replace the battery when it began failing [me].

It does have an SD card slot, right spine near the top.  Since the back of the phone is not removable, the SIM (left spine, top) & SD cards need inserted externally.  The phone comes with a 'tool' to poke into the little hole to pop open these tiny trays to insert the cards into.  The SIM card comes pre-installed, at least mine did as a Verizon upgrade.

The sounds is great.  Music is loud.  Not knock your socks off loud but great for a phone.  BUT- and notice this- it's still a cell phone, so don't expect the world when playing music for the first time.  They are the best cell phone speakers I've ever heard, but they're still cell phone speakers.  The Theater mode makes it sound like a very nice spacious stereo, which is unique to cell phone speakers.  Your other sound option is Music mode.  Only these two options.  Music mode is *slightly* louder, but less stereo effect.  I really like the theater mode myself.

The battery is great, at least now while it's new.  I got 16 hrs of light use yesterday (pocket most of the day, occasional email checks periodically) and it still read 52% at midnight.  It's a 2840 mAh battery.  To put that into perspective (if that's Greek to you), my Rezound, which I bought an extended thick battery for, had a 2750 mAh extended battery.  This is better than that extended battery.  Very decent for a stock battery.  Sure, there'll be reviews where people complain they watched Netflix and played 1080p games on full brightness and the phone was dead by 1pm....boo hoo.  It's a phone, you have to be reasonable in your expectations, and this battery does great if you're rational in what you expect and use the phone for normal average things.

It gets warm when charging, and it gets warm when you're using it heavily.  And it gets warm when you're charging it AND using it heavily.  So get over it.  It's an electronic device with a battery, there's a lot of chemistry and physical science going on inside this metal body, you're going to feel heat from all of that.  It's not hot and it won't hurt you, it is what it is.

Surely I'm forgetting many things, but I tried to hit the basics in case you're familiar with HTC phones are considering this as an upgrade.
summary: A review from a realistic, average smartphone user- no super techy talk or redundant specs

reviewText:
For the price point this is a 5 star phone -- If I had the extra cash I think I would go for the new v10 or gs7 but i got this on sale for 513 and change after tax here on Amazon... compare that to the 800 something I would have paid for a gs7 and this phone was a great price.
A more expensive phone likely will perform better but I haven't had that many issues besides a random restart issue with certain applications... likely because of incompatibility with the software update (latest marshmallow i think it runs) -- small inconvenience b/c it restarts quick and remedies the conflict whatever it is. Was annoying once when I was at airport and had mobile boarding pass though... hah.

PROS:
-rear fingerprint scanner is awesome ~ and very responsive! I was impressed
-great size screen
-front-facing double speakers! (no rear speakers, which to me isn't a con b/c I hate how the sound muffles when phone is set down on a surface for rear speakers)
-camera seems pretty good
-interface is similar to galaxy s4 style which is nice
-charging is FAST w/ usb-c cable it comes with (havent tested any other cables yet - though i need to buy 1 or 2 more for car / charging on the go)

CONS:
- when I have certain apps installed, it restarts randomly i think b/c of incompatibility with the software update... kind of annoying
- volume is on the right side -- (wish it were on the left)
- power button is a bit touchy in my opinion
- no button on front or double tap to unlock -- I think there should be a button on the front b/c when it is laying on a surface you have to press the power button on right side to unlock which is awkward (an app may remedy the no double tap feature but probably requires rooting)
summary: 5 star phone for the price point! minor hiccups and only a couple major cons when compared to higher price point phones

I was surprised when I received this item:  it actually exceeded what I expected from it.  The three-way switch allows a variety of lighting levels, from "very low and soft" to "nearly blinding" (but good for subjects further away).  The color given off by the two distinctly different LEDs is warm and pleasing.  The flash can be set to be on continuously (which I find is a better mode in low light situations) or fire only when your camera takes a photo (I could not get this mode to work on my G4).  It also appears to have more LEDs and a wider color gamut than those circular iPhone-type lights, which would make scenes brighter and more evenly lit.  The always-on feature allows fill-in lighting from a different direction, making it quite flexible for a such a cheap little gadget.  The utility I found with this product is rarely seen for the price, but it manages to pull it off.
summary: It might be a cheap little gadget, but it manages to be a useful one, too

reviewText: The Poweradd 25W 5V/5A 5 Port USB Wall Charger is an awesome product. I like having the choice of being able to have 5 USB ports to charge different devices from. There are two ports for charging iPads, one port for charging my iPhone, one port for charging and Android phone and one port for charging a Samsung Tablet. Each port has a different amount of Amps that charges the device, but your ports and Amps are listed on the backside of the HUB. On the front side of the hub, it specifically shows which USB port is for what device. I use this device as my central charging bay for all my devices. The only complaint that I have, is when you try to plug a USB cable in to the device at first, it feels like the USB connector does not want to go in the USB port. That might be due to the design of the case, or the ports being new. But it seems to have no issues after connecting the cable several times. Overall, this is a great product for charging multiple devices.
summary: One Device to Power all your Devices!!

reviewText: This is a great screen; It has rounded edges and has good touch sensitivity but what I found remarkable and what set this screen apart from others was the installation process....There are instructions; they are listed inside of the case the screen comes in. At first I just ignored the instructions and started cleaning the screen with my own microfiber cloth and optical lens cleaner, as I have installed these type of screens before...but then I got curious as to what the little red tabs were about and also the blue plastic sheet....after reading the instructions I decided to use both the red tabs and the blue plastic sheet....the installation process went smooth as glass....the Blue sheet takes out dust on a clean screen and also eliminates static so dust does not re-attach itself immediately to the surface of the phone...the red tabs helped me place the screen in the exact position I wanted it to be before application...Once the screen was lined up and I placed it on the phone..it just melted onto the phone...I did not have to take any bubbles out or do anything...I did rub it with the provided micro cloth to clean to a crystal clear finish...never have I had a better install nor has it ever been easier..but you do have to clean the screen of your phone extremely well first before appling the blue screen...do not be afraid of applying the blue screen more than once....I repositioned it three times so that the whole screen every edge had been covered. I received this item at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

I haven't had a chance to use it much, it just arrived today, but I wanted to post my initial positive response to the item.
I bought this for my wife who, despite the news stories to the contrary, is not a narcissist.  The problem with photography is there is too much in the way of the photographer getting in the shot.  Yes, it's OK for the photographer to be in a picture.  It's O.K.
Doing the arm-length selfie results in a lousy picture for a lot of reasons, too close, not enough background if you're somewhere interesting, front-facing camera usually lower resolution, and arm.
Selfie stick solves all of those problems.
Get it set with the view you want then turn your phone around for HD camera.
The BT shutter control was a breeze to connect, cam-lock telescoping sections are quick to extend and are keyed so they will not twist, grip is adequate, 1/4"-20 on BOTH ends, and there is a little convex chromed insert below the camera mount that gives you an idea of what the camera is seeing if you cannot see the screen.
I'm uncomfortable yanking open the jaws far enough to accept an iPhone 6+ but with the 1/4"-20 adapter I can come up with whatever I want and change cameras without much hassle.
If you have NO interest in using the BT remote for other applications it might benefit you wrap a rubber band or nylon tie around the handle to make sure it doesn't pop out and get lost in the trunk or back seat.  I'd like to glue it in but the battery will need to be replaced at some point.
For maximum stability and perhaps longer product life: when extending the sections leave an inch or two unextended on each section.  This takes the load off the plastic end and adds stability.  Lots of friction on the cam-locks, may hit them with a drop of light oil on the hinge pin and the point of contact.  Will update if that causes it to self-destruct.
A saying in the US is "That's why we can't have nice things.", in this case it would refer to all the lunk-heads who've given the selfie stick a bad name. If you can find a place where these are allowed the Fugetek seems very nice out of the box.  Will update if that changes.

(edit)
Alright, just noticed that it's a rechargeable remote so I may glue it in after all.
Strapped a spare Otterbox holster to the Fugetek clamp with a couple of nylon ties.  Note how bottom of holster rests behind lip of the included clamp.  This adds much stability to the installation.
It'll be easy to forget to turn off the remote, there's always the built-in timers on most phones and cameras.

(another edit)
If you plug in and run your headphones with integrated microphone down from your phone close to the grip, or even hold them in your hand, the microphone input will switch to the mic built into the little part on the earbuds that changes the volume.  By getting the microphone closer to you your voice will be louder and will offset the proximity effect of having your mic way out on a stick.  You can also get dedicated microphones that you can use, but this is cheap and effective.
summary: Nice accessory, OK for non-narcissists to use.

I'll admit it - I have a lot of different battery packs, from el-cheapos that use AA batteries, up to this one (the most expensive of the lot.) Wow, am I impressed.  What exactly does 100 bucks buy you?

First, it's got a ton of power - 6000 mah Lithium Ion, so no memory set or max power loss over time. Next, it has all the adapters BUILT-IN! This is great - It's a pain to carry around a pouch with all the adapters and chords.  The myCharge Peak 6000 includes a built-in cable for the iPod/Pad/Phone series of devices (Apple Dock Connector), a micro-USB cable that will charge most smart phones (including Droids), and a standard USB port. You can plug in your other USB devices here.  For example, if your GoPro is shooting a really long time-lapse, connect it to this battery back and you can run for days.

Charging - you have two options. Slow charge over USB or quick charge with a built-in wall charger! Just hinge out the prongs and plug 'er in!

Other features: Bank of LED's to indicate charge status, plus a verbal status. Yep - press the button and a voice tells you the battery status. "Battery is near full" and so on. That's different, and a little over the top. You'll also receive spoken status updates when you attach decides, powering off, etc. The language can be change by pressing a small button.

Specs:
6000mAh Lithium Polymer battery
Apple connector: 5VDC, 2.1A
Micro USB: 5VDC, 1.0A
USA: 5VDC, 1.0A
Wall charger: 100-240VAC

It's large - 5 1/4x3x1 - but packs a plethora of features and power in this space. It's now my preferred travel battery!
