One of the most well executed products I've ever bought.  Had it over a year now and it's still solid.  It doesn't place phone far away from you like others, but right in the CD slot.  Very adjustable.  I can use my big phablet phone on it.  It's just great to see one of these things finally designed perfectly.

I love the look of the phone. Everyone who sees it says, "Ooooh, what is that?" Looks aren't everything though. This is a first generation product and there are some things that need work. Specifically, the camera app. OMG, I feel like I'm in a time machine back to my first smartphone, where every small needed the manual. And come on, no panorama mode? I'm hoping this will be fixed in an update. I'm taking off a star for that. The other thing I'm not enamoured with is the finish. It looked awesome for about 15 seconds, until I touched it. It's one of those finishes that absorbs oil from your hands and looks like crap immediately. I'm also not a fan of the current trend of not putting an sd card slot in Android phones anymore. That was one of my biggest gripes with Apple and now Android is starting to go the same way. Yay, cloud and all, but sometimes there's no internet, and sometimes you don't want to put all your stuff in someone else's pocket. A pocket which might go away at any time.  I knew it didn't have an SD card slot when I got it but I didn't expect it to annoy me as much as it has.
summary: Not quite ready for prime time.

I wanted the cheapest possible smartphone plan for occasional use, and found Tracfone to be the way to go. I started with the 1200 minutes/texts/mb plan with a year of service so it won't expire too soon, and that was a good choice for me since I don't make calls often, and only use data for quick checks when I'm not on wifi.

The phone is awful though. Google Maps crashes all the time and I can't use it. Browsing the web reminds me of the days of dialup, and it's purely because this phone can't handle it since I have very fast wifi at home. It works okay for calls, though when I switched, many people told me my call quality had dropped and they had a harder time hearing me. Both the cell signal and wifi signal are significantly reduced compared to other phones being used in the same place. I restart the phone before expecting to surf the web to at least start out fresh, but that just brings it from 'barely usable' to 'mediocre'.

The camera is a piece of junk. Image quality is awful compared to any other phone I've used. The tint is always off, the images are grainy, and they never seem to focus well. Forget being able to snap a pic of something up close to research later, as any picture closer than 5ft has never came out in focus. This may be acceptable for instagram, but for anything else it's way sub-par.

The only good thing about the phone is battery life. I mostly left it alone and once got 6 days on standby before it got to 10% battery. With my typical use, I get about 2 days. You really only get about 3 hours of heavy use, so if you are playing a game, surfing the web, responding to emails, etc. it will die pretty quickly, and this mostly seems to be due to having the screen on. I bought a spare battery for a few bucks which works great too, as a backup for traveling away from outlets.

The trick I've found to making the most of Tracfone is to route your number through Google Voice. Since I take most of my calls at home by a computer anyway, I can just answer the calls on Google and not use any minutes. Texts sent via Google Voice are free also, but you pay for the ones received. Wifi is the key to limiting data use too, and I leave data off unless I am actively using it. This has meant that I can get by on about 2000 minutes per year which means I pay at most $200/yr for service.
summary: It was the best Tracfone at the time, that isn't saying much

I just got this Otterbox for my Iphone 4s (Sprint).  It is what you have seen...a very well made product.  Otterbox makes high quality stuff.  And yes, i did get the updated design with the big camera cutout. Everyone can tell you the goods about the Otterbox.  I am not here to repeat those things.  I am here to tell you about ONE MAJOR FLAW:

The problem is that when you put your iphone into the holster, you better be sure that NOTHING is caught in it.  In other words, if your shirt tail is in between the holster and the Iphone, then the iphone is NOT clipped in!!  It may feel like it is clipped in, but as soon as you turn and your shirt pulls out (of the holster), your Iphone goes flying out!  This happened while i was walking and i heard my iphone dropped to the ground.  The case itself protected my Iphone well.  I was lucky...not because the case protected my Iphone, BUT because i heard it fall!  If i was in a busy building, then i would have lost my Iphone because i would not be able to hear my iphone dropping to the ground.

The only way around this is to conciously use one hand to lift your shirt up and use the other hand to clip the Iphone into the holster.  Two hand method.  Forget rapid holstering of your Iphone with this Otterbox!!  Now, if you tuck your shirt in, then this may not be a problem.  However, you better be sure that the tucked shirt is nicely tucked in or else part of the shirt can be caught in between the holster and the case...and you have the flying Iphone syndrome all over again!

Other minor negatives:
- The screen protector does dull the beautiful retina screen a bit, but functionality remains excellent.  This was expected and i did not mind at all.

- Bulky...when i sit in my car and strap my seatbelt in, i can feel the holster/case pressing against my side hip bone...maybe a comfort issue on long drives.

- It is kinda hard to clip the case onto the holster, unless you slide it in perfect.  Just a little to the left or right and you will not be able to clip it in.

So, i think that the product is very well made.  The new rubber surround is very high quality.  But, the flying Iphone issue has made me look for other alternatives.  This is sad for me because i have high respect for Otterbox...i bought cases from them for my Ipod Touch 3rd and 4th gens.

reviewText: Great product

Honestly I cant say how this rates against the iPhone 6+.  That said, this is the current phone that is not only an excellent phone (no call drops period) that is also the highest fidelity personal music server too if you use quality phones in a wired configuration.

I have an Xperia Z3 and I love it.  The 3Z+ raises the bar just a little bit which for some will be quite meaningful and for others (those who own the 3Z presently) will likely not be earth-shattering as a reason to upgrade.

You probably already know the latest version of the Xperia is virtually the same phone called the 4Z in the world outside of North America.  Sony wisely chose the Z3+ name for a phone that is amazingly just the same phone as the recent Z3 only tweaked.  Its  got a faster (processor is currently one of the state-of-the art mobile processors), a very very slightly tweaked screen (res is still full HD w/ color and glass improvements), and the phone gets a bit marginally thinner (battery does shrink, but only slightly).  The camera is still excellent except in the lowest lighting and there I cannot say it is changed either plus or minus).  My forward camera does actually seem to be noticeably better even if it shouldnt on paper.  As for the battery life even with a slightly smaller battery this Sony Xperia 3Z+ is so very close to the original 3Z Im inclined to call it the absolute best lasting high-powered smart phone extant.  Without any ridiculous web usage you can still stretch it to two days with one day often still having approximately 40% batter when I plug in.

What really separates the 3Z+ is the emphasis Sony has put on audio quality for anyone who is into high-resolution audio files.  Ive yet to download any format of HD-Audio files that cant be decoded.  Also, the fidelity is off the chart when used with any high-quality wired cans.  Also, I have 2 highly-rated Sony Bluetooth cans and they both sound impeccable over Bluetooth at up to 40-ft. in my home.  Excellent!  Sony also includes a pretty impressive engine that UPS the lower resolution MP3 files to where I, personally, believe they sound better than Ive ever heard them when using wired cans.  Hey, this is a fantastic phone (remember the first function) that is almost like getting the Sony +1000 Walkman included at no charge.

Sony has really hit a sweetspot in the screen.  This is the best full HD screen Ive ever seen.  It will rival QHD screens in overall appearance and it doesnt take that killer hit in battery life the other QHD screens seem to just annihilate.

So, if your an Android lover and a music lover who isn't hellbent on getting the screens approaching 6 there is absolutely no reason to not pull the plug.  The Sony Xperia 3Z+ is currently one of the most water repellent phones on the market too.  It will like drop into up to about 4 feet in water for between 30-45 minutes without any problems according to most accounts and Ive washed mine without powering down so I have no reason to doubt it really has extra water resistant qualities (no Im not submerging it in a pool just for testing).  As for cosmetics this one ups the 3Z slightly too.  It has the same glass back which does attract fingerprints (not a big deal), but with better impact screen resistance (this is only good because Ive dropped my 3Z repeatedly without harm).  I do like the increased memory of this phone versus my 16GB 3Z, but with the memory card option on both this only a small, but meaningful improvement.  All in all, this a beautifully constructed phone with a metal surround chassis covered with exceptionally strong glass front and back and integral 4-corner bumpers.  Its a phone designed with top quality industrial appearance and real-world toughness.

If you sense I love the 3Z+, I certainly do!  I have had absolutely no problem with the noted heating problem.  The hottest my original 3Z ever got was when updating the Android OS and since this one shipped with the latest Android OS Ive experienced no overheating in my typical usage at all.  Im not saying this isn't something a gamer or someone recording 4K videos won't experience as I have not tested either.  Im only saying for more folks than not the overheating will likely never be something youll experience.  I really think for someone like me who loves music this is the top phone currently available that is also a fantastic actual phone.  I use mine with Cricket Wireless and Ive got excellent coverage and have never dropped one call.  So, if you're at all similarly minded I suggest you seek out this excellent phone!  BTW, in full disclosure I got this 3Z+ at no upfront cost to test and I purchased my previous 3Z slightly used at almost $500.  The 3Z+ isn't easy to find except at Amazon (not always available here either), but I'd have to say this is one phone worth the cost if you want a robust phone that is an exceptional music server too.  It's absolutely beautiful.
summary: Perhaps The Best Android Phone As Of Late 2015

I ordered these because of the One review.  The sheet is fairly easy to install probably not any different than other screen protectors.

That being said.  These were marketed originally for Asian market.  All the printing on the packages are in either Japanese or Chinese.  When I applied the protector and as I said it was fairly easy.  But the top tab used to keep from leaving finger prints to the sticky side did not come off cleanly.  It left some paper and lots of sticky.  I did finally get it off by scraping it with my thumb nail for several days.

Finally Shipping:  The seller sent the envelope via USPS mail.  The label says First Class.  However the envelope is the size that the post office calls parcel post.  The seller made the label USPS Delivery Confirmation.  Because the USPS does not include Delivery Confirmation with First Class mail with out additional fees I was charged additional postage. The Cost of Priority Mail plus Confirmation Delivery.  Instead of the regular handling fee the seller charged with the additional postage I wound up paying over $6.00 for shipping and handling.

I had asked for Standard Delivery.  Which is what they did... but they added services that made the delivery more expensive than I agreed to pay.  But Had to pay to get the package.

I wrote SF Planet as soon as I picked up my package and received no response.

I am therefore giving them a 2 star for lack of communication.  And for not shipping correctly for the amount of money I paid for shipping and handling.

Most people think of screen protection for a mobile phone as a glass or plastic cover that prevents the actual screen from shattering. Thats true, this is the most important aspect of screen protection. But, what about protecting the data displayed on the screen? I have seen privacy screens for laptop screens, but this is the first I have used with a mobile phone and it works exactly like the laptop screen protectors.

Similar to a regular screen protector, this is a thin sheet of glass that applies very smoothly and easily with no bubbles. It has fine screen coverage to the edge of the phone - this has been an issue on some other screen protectors I have used but not this one.

With this screen protector in place, the screen is definitely darker than usual and it might be helpful to adjust the screen brightness. It is a lot like looking at your screen through a pair of sunglasses. Turning the phone at a 45-degree angle makes the screen appear completely black as if the screen has been turned off - no light can be seen at all.

Before I put this protector on the phone I held it up to a light source and saw a repeating pattern of the light source itself, almost like I had held up a mirror to a mirror to get a replicated image. I think this protector works via polarized light and the repeating image is an effect of that - I have seen similar phenomena when wearing polarizing sunglasses.

If protecting the data on your phone screen is as important to you as protecting the screen itself, this is the screen protector you need. It works great, is easy to apply and is sufficient protection for you phones screen to prevent physical damage. Just make sure you have the right one for your model of phone.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.
summary: Tempered Glass Privacy Screen - Works Great

reviewText:
I bought two (2) of these for my kids' new smartphones (Galaxy Grand Primes) and one of them broke the kick stand right off, the other claimed to have "figured it out."  The trick, at least while it's new, is to treat it like a bag of chips (crisps)... apply JUST ENOUGH force (slightly less than needed to break your finger nail - it's all fingernail to grab it), then let off immediately once it pops out; otherwise, you might pop it off and break it completely. This likely will change over time and use.  I am not a fan of kickstands on phone covers, but it is well-integrated for the price-point.  It would be a 5-star case if the plastic was a bit "grippier" - that is, it's somewhat slippery (maybe because it's new?) for having all those square knobs on it.  However, I do like the ridges on the side a lot!

The charger port could be a hair taller to accommodate the cheaper, thicker chargers; though, it handles Samsung's default charger wonderfully.  The black portion also comes off, should you want "less case" or whatever.  I like it, it's attractive.

My kids have not dropped their phones, so I cannot speak to the most important aspect of having a case for a phone, but for an inexpensive case, it fits well and looks good.  Feels nice in the hand (though a tad smooth with the plastic, the side ridges make up for it), the buttons are aligned well, but are plastic and not recessed at all (for people who look for that - or avoid it).

Overall, we are thus far satisfied with the cases.  Be careful with the kickstand
summary: Not a bad choice for the price!

Pros:

Adjusts to fit a very wide range of phones. It _might_ even handle a Galaxy Note phone in a Defender case - I didn't have one to test that, though. It does grab my Defender-ed SGS4 with ease, though.

Cons:
Not quite as slick as a custom-fit dock, not that you'll find such a thing with Qi coils.
Qi output limited to about 1A.

Overall, this cradle is so good, I'm tempted to grab another for use as a home charger and a third for a bike mount. Yes, it's that good.

I was very excited for this, I've been having trouble charging my phone with standard cables and this seemed like the perfect solution.

The case is white, which is not in it's favor, but I can deal with it. It didn't fit well, one of the sides wouldn't stick down no matter how hard I pushed and when I did it get down all the way, it would pop right back up. My standard case has no problems clicking into place and staying on. I'm not sure if the new case is bent, doesn't fit right in general, or if the bulging from the extra equipment inside causes it to not fit correctly. It looks like it should fit and that there are no cosmetic defects to prevent it from fitting.

The touchstone, cable and power adapter all fit together and plugged in. There are no lights, vibrations or other notifications to let you know if it's working.

I connected the back to the phone (As best I could) and it fit well onto the touchstone. There are magnets in the back plate that kind of force it into the correct position on the touchstone. But, when I connected the two, it constantly connects and disconnects the charger. No amount of moving it around the touchstone allows it to connect more than a millisecond and then it flutters back and forth between connection and not connecting.

I could not get it to work, I've been messing with it for a week. I've read online that any of the 4 pieces (touchstone, cable, outlet connector, or back plate) could be causing it to not work correctly. I can either return the whole thing or start buying new pieces and see if I can figure out which one is messed up. I probably should have just paid the $8 for a better cable and saved the money trying to wirelessly charge it.

I haven't tried to return it because I foolishly ripped open all the packaging when I got it. One of these days I'll learn.

I have the AT&T Gnote(the i717) & I bought this version because, A) I didn't like the battery cover design for the i717 version, and B) I wanted to use it with the corresponding TPU case that is also available from this seller- Hyperion Samsung Galaxy Note Extended Battery HoneyComb TPU Case Black (Not Compatible with AT&T Galaxy Note. Compatible ONLY with International Galaxy Note 5000mAh Extended Battery Models (N7000 and GT-i9220)). It'll fit, you just have to take a razor blade and cut off the tabs on the inside of the battery cover that don't line up with the slots on the back of your phone. The first cover I received was cracked due to careless mail carriers, so I felt safe experimenting on it since it was damaged anyway and I found that if you cut off a few specific tabs along the sides, it'll go right on. You do have to use the case with it after cutting the tabs off though because it won't stay on very well afterward. If you want this battery & don't want to use a case or do any cutting, I suggest just getting the i717 version. Either way, I'm quite happy with my purchase, I love my big fat purple brick phone & I can't wait to see how well the battery does after a few drain/charge cycles :)
summary: This WILL work for the AT&T model with a bit of modification!

reviewText:
I had an otterbox years ago, but didn't get one for this phone because I didn't want the bulk.  I broke my phone.  I had another phone case that was just as bulky as the otterbox defender, but cheaper, and it was fine.  But... what a brick to carry around. I had the opportunity try this case, and I thought -- what the heck, its an otterbox, and my screen is already cracked...
First, it looks good, and it feels good.  The leather is nice.  I like it...so much better than plastic or rubber.
But then yesterday I dropped my phone.  I left my phone on top of paper on top of a stool, and it flew off -- sailed through the air and "splat," landing not on the corner, but perfectly flat -- the worst way to drop a phone from a height.  I fully expected a shattered phone -- the phone was already cracked.  But OMG, nope.  Nothing.  Perfect.  Wow.
So....when I upgrade my phone, I'll get this same style.  Love it.
summary: Looks great, but PROTECTS well too

This Ranboo Men's Leather Wallet is super nice. I honestly will be using this as it's a perfect size for me and larger than what my husband likes to carry. It definitely one that could be unisex. Size is approx 8 1/2" x 4 1/3". Comes with a stylus which is great for using with the screens on your smart phone.

The wallet is black and the snapping flap on the front is a deep navy blue (at least that's how it looks to me). There are 2 snaps to close the front flap and there is a large pocket with credit card holders in that area. The piece will also slide out if you for some reason didn't want to carry it or wanted to use the wallet without it.

 Inside is tan (as well as the closure small strap). Small strap closure easily snaps and has 2 different snaps to choose to close it. There are pocket holders for another 10 cards inside. Also there are 2 large pockets for your paper money and can use the other for receipts or important papers. If you have a thinner phone, you can also keep your phone in one of the pockets too.

Finally, it comes with a small carry wristlet strap you can attach or leave off if you prefer. Attaches and detaches easily. Perfect for a man to keep in his briefcase or woman for her purse. Definitely love this and absolutely would recommend it. Nice quality and made very well.
**I received this product with a promotional discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. No compensation for a positive review was provided. All of my reviews are based 100% off of my experience with the product and I never guarantee a positive review.

However, if you're on a train in Europe, or are studying and have your stuff in a Starbucks, yeah it's probably worth turning those alarms on.  But for day to day use, you'll be disappointed and probably come here an post a bad review, lol.  In general, these fobs do what they are designed to do, let you know if your keys are within a certain proximity and, if needed, you can also make the key fob sound an alert so you can locate it. So I broke my screen on my iPhone 6 two weeks ago. It was either pay $200 for a new screen at the store or a new phone which would cost 3 times as much. I figured I'd give this a try. So this is the first time I broke the screen and first time replacing it myself. I was very nervous but I'm glad there's a link for the video provided. I did step by step as I was watching the video. I replayed at some part of the video. I took about 1 hour and 30 minutes. For a first timer, this kit is great. Video was very useful. My only complaint, really, was the screw drivers (all of them actually). They could use magnetic tips because these are some of the smallest screws I've seen. It was not easy to remove and install them without magnetic tip screw drivers. But they're free and provided so. I did not need to use all of the tools in the pouch. I do have a white screen so it's a step or two less than the black screen. There were 2 or 3 screws that didn't want to come off using the phillips screw driver provided so I had to use one of my screw driver at home with a large tip to remove them. Last but not least, the tamper glass screen protector arrived broke in the package so it's useless. I had to install my own screen protector. In the end, once everything was putted back together, I was really afraid that it won't turn on but after 4-5 seconds it did. Speaking of which, the first time turning the phone back on, the color was a bit off from the original screen but after an hour or so, it went back to normal. Strange. All of all, I spent approx. $60 and it took me about 1 hour 30 minutes. I'm happy.

Pros: Snug fit, doesn't add any extra bulk, felt material feels good and gives phone good grip, has all the cut outs, looks nice.

Cons: Hard to get off, doesn't have raised lip to protect screen, hard to use power/volume buttons ( see Picture of how close the buttons are to the top of the case), only offers minimal protection for phone.

Over all for the price this is a nice case, but if you want better protection, or plan to take the case off a lot, I would not recommend this particular case.  However if you are looking for one that is made of the felt like material, and fits really snug, this is the only case that I know of that is like that. A wonderful, affordable, and multi-use item. I ordered this as an alternative mount for my GoPro Hero2. Anyone who owns a GoPro knows that once it is in its waterproof case, the audio becomes muffled and weak. Using a skeleton case is an alternative but takes time to change out all the pieces. I took a chance and ordered this, waiting to see how well it works. I am happy to say that it holds the GoPro nicely with gentle rubber clamps with just the right amount of tension. Not too hard, not too soft; just right.
Of course I don't plan on using this in rough conditions, but as a casual, stand-alone mount (with a mini-tripod, not included) to capture things like party activities while sitting on a table. Much less intimidating method than sticking a camera in someone's face.

I am very happy with this purchase, and I can use it with my smartphone, too.

Update, August 7, 2014:
As other reviewers have noted, the plastic fittings are the weak point of this product. First, the threaded base separated from the mounting column (the upright portion, the parts are separate), then recently one of the hinges broke; the plastic portion that connects to the metal pin. I repaired both with superglue, but I wanted a good replacement so I ordered another one. After all, the price is low enough.

Like others have also said, I wish just the stress points were either made from metal or at least a stronger material. I use this every day as a smartphone mount (it keeps the phone screen near vertical and helps the battery to stay cooler). I retain my 5 star rating since this is probably not meant for everyday or rough use. Still worth the cost since it did last from November last year to August this year (about 9 months).
summary: Adaptability, usable with GoPro Hero2 camera.

Personally, I don't like it. Let me explain why.

- It's too thick.  The 9H hardness is welcomed, but the screen protector itself is just too thick. There is definitely a noticeable added layer to your phone, and it interferes with responsiveness.

- It doesn't work well with most cases. I do not like big bulky cases. I like tight, slim fitting cases. Since the screen protector goes closer to the edges than others, a lot of the slim fitting cases for the iPhone 6 won't work.

- It's not really curved. It just extends a little further than other screen protectors.

- If you don't put this on absolutely perfect, and when I say perfect, I really mean PERFECT you will notice it. The "screen" portion of this, is an exact measurement if the iPhone screen.  So a smidget off when applying this and you'll notice it. It probably should've been clear.

Overall, I would not recommend this nor would I buy it again.  It didn't satisfy me.  I guess the iPhone 6 just isn't designed for tempered glass screen protectors.

I purchased this for my Galaxy Note 2 since most other chargers don't have enough power.  Before I got this charger, I could not use my phone for navigation or music while charging.  My battery would deplete a little faster than other chargers charge.  This one is great!  It charges my large battery quickly even when being used.  I took away the 1 star because, like a lot of other reviewers stated, the cord is very short.  In my work car I keep my phone in the center console next to the outlet so it's not a big problem.  But I had to replace my phone holder from the inside windshield to the front of the dashboard in my Suburban in order to use this plug and navigation at the same time.  Overall, if you have a big phone like the Note (2, 3 or 4), this will charge it nice and quick.  Just don't use it too far from the power source.

**Update: I purchased this August 2014 and it is now March 2015.  This charger no longer puts out the 2.1 amps.  It is only putting out 460 mA. My note 2 now takes 5-6 hours to charge.  I tested my other chargers to make sure it wasn't my phone and they all still work at their max (1800 mA).
summary: Updated review: was good while it lasted....

reviewText:
This is a very good case, but it's specifically for a type of customer; not for everyone.

PROS:
I have a water proof case for my Flip video camera and love it. I love taking it to the coast or to swimming pools. It is natural that I'll love it on my iPhone 5 as well. But here's the thing: my iPhone 5 is $650 to replace and my Flip is $150. The fix? Lifeproof guarantees it will be waterproof. I found that it was for those shallow dips under water for videos and pics of the kids jumping in or trying to swim. I did not (and don't recommend) the 6 foot deep limits I've read you could do.

This is a very thin case for a fully wrapped case. Unlike Otterbox, this one adds very little thickness. It still feels like a smaller phone.

I found the screen to be responsive and the buttons are all in the right place. It did not affect my use of the phone.

CONS:
As for protection this isn't the best case. If you want shock and drop protection I'd recommend an Otterbox or even an Incipio.

I've seen one of these get dropped a couple times and the clips not hold it together well. (I wonder if the warranty on the waterproof would still work if the case was slightly damaged. I think not.) It doesn't hold up as well and it won't protect your phone as well.

There is no warranty for if your device breaks from a drop or fall. This is normal, but it isn't really "life proof" is it?

Overall a nice waterproof case that isn't as strong or safe as some others like the Otterbox. It is thinner though and much better than snap on cases. I like it, but don't love it.

Perfect for the long days on the boat the kids love to fish but after a while they want to go sit and play games with these boosters I never have to worry about dead batteries they will last a long time and work with all of our devices.  Great buy and super-fast shipping. I received this product for free or at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review. All the information is based on my own opinions and personal experience with the product. I rely on genuine and honest reviews when shopping for products so I hope you found this information to be helpful in making your purchase decision. If there are any issues with the product after my initial review, I will provide an update as needed.

reviewText: real nice

The battery itself is well made and durable, but the product as a whole just isn't the best design.  Let me explain.  There is a tiny little piece that connects to the USB end of the charging cord and that tiny little piece goes in the USB end and has a micro USB on the other end.  There is no holder or place to put the little removable chip/piece when it's not in use and if you use it then the battery is pretty much useless.  The battery itself does NOT have an USB inlet/outlet.  It ONLY has a micro USB hole for both outgoing power and for charging.  In addition, the battery and cord are two separate entities so you have to keep track of both to use the charger.  I have another external battery, similar to this one, but that one has the charging cord attached to the battery and so once it's charge you can just grab it and go - no need to carry a cord around with you, the cord just tucks in the side and untucks for easy charging of devices.  So it is well made - made of quality materials, but the design just isn't the best nor is it convenient to use.  If I loose that tiny little chip then I can't use this charger unless I find a cord that is just a micro USB to a lightning on either end.

reviewText:
Thought I would contribute a review since I get so much from them.  I share the other reviewer's praises.  Nokia's Asha 311 is very well designed and the in-phone and online software is beautiful.  Everything is well thought out and relies on simplicity rather than complexity but has plenty of firepower (my past Pantech and HTC phones prove just the opposite).  Read the online manual to see what I mean.  If you want a phone that has most capabilities but don't want to pay the extra mandatory $40/mo or so for smartphone internet access, this is it.  The touch screen is a new experience for me--very sensitive, yet not prone to errors.  I bought it for use abroad, but can use it with my AT&T sim card in the US.  (To be picky, the phone is perhaps a tab small--would like it very slightly larger!)

I've been disgusted with the "locked" phones AT&T offers in their stores, and now its down to just a handful of non-smart phones.  With an unlocked phone you can purchase an independent sim card for about $50/mo. which gives you lots of talk and internet time--much better than the major carrrier's contract rates. (Some sims actually use the same network as AT&T, so you get the same quality.  Note that Verizon's network is incompatible with most unlocked phones).  So no more 2 year contracts--take THAT AT&T!  Check out [...].  "Locked" phones are a US phone carrier scam that does just what they say--locks you into high monthly fees.  Europeans have been enjoying the benefits of unlocked phones for years and now we can too.  Hope this helps.

Further comment:  Took off one star because internet access won't work using AT&T network in the states--you must use WiFi.  Also their downloaded maps are not the greatest.  Talk and sms are good, as is Nokia support.

Update, April 8, 2013.  Many hours later, I finally DID get internet access.  With Nokia's help, found an AT&T forum that gives the internet (web) and MMS (multimedia) settings you need to plug into your phone so it will work properly (presumably they only work if you're with AT&T). So I'll restore the star I took off before.  Here's the link for the magic info (some terms were slightly different on my Asha.  note that this is for a Nokia C3 phone, but it still works):

[...]

On my Asha 311, I went to "Tools, configuration, personal settings".  Create and set up the "AT&T MMS" settings, and then the "Media Net" (web) settings.  Call Nokia if you have trouble.
Hope this helps others avoid the multiple hours of set-up.

I'm trying hard not to let my perfectionist tendencies influence this review.  I was able to get the glass on the phone and it looks like it'll do a good job protecting most of the screen.  However, in the process, I left a portion of my fingerprint on the adhesive, as well as a few dust specks.  It's good enough now and unless I look for these issues, they shouldn't bother me in my day to day usage.  But it is frustrating given the amount of time and care I put into placing this screen protector on my phone.  If this were solely my fault, I would give this 4 or 5 stars for the protection that it is providing.

But there were two issues that TechArmor could have resolved: first, the screen protector doesn't cover the entire screen.  Now I've seen the reviews that say it wouldn't, but I assumed that it meant the display part of the screen would be covered, but that the bezel would not be.  That's not the case - there's a minuscule gap in coverage on the left and right sides when the display is centered.  Please see photos.  It's not very large but it's there and while I can learn to live with it, that was not my expectation so when I initially lined up the screen protector for placement, I only checked that it was lined up over the speaker grill per the instructions.  Once placed, I realized that the coverage on the sides was uneven and it was very apparent just by glancing at it.  I fixed it but that's when my fingerprint ended up on the adhesive side.

Which leads me to my second gripe - the speaker grill is ever so slightly off center.  To make sure there was an equal amount of coverage on the left and right sides, the speaker grill cutout was slightly off center.  Because the instructions noted that the speaker grill should be used for centering, this contributed to my initial placement issue.

I don't know if other screen protectors have this issue, and I'm fine with it if this is the best that can be done unless you purchase the E2E protector.  But it would be helpful to show in the instructions what the final product looks like so you can see that the alignment on the sides won't be perfect.  That way, we'll know to align by the speaker grill and the sides of the glass.  This would've prevented the misalignment and the subsequent correction that left a fingerprint and speck of dust on the underside of the glass.  That is the major issue here.

There is one more minor issue that comes with the screen protector not fully covering the display portion of the front of the iPhone - the refraction on the edges of the screen can be annoying.  When seen at an angle, you see a sliver of the screen that is uncovered, the refraction from the curved edge of the screen protector, and then the covered part of the screen protector.  It's not a big deal, but it's there nonetheless.
summary: Decent screen protector but alignment issues are annoying

reviewText:
I purchased the rose gold Henoda band for my wife's Gear S2 and the red band for my S2.  At first, these bands were great.  They fit well, are easily adjustable, and I like how the end of the band tucks under.  However, within about a week or two, a problem became evident; the rose gold coloration on the edges of her band started to wear and show the white plastic (silicone?) beneath it.

My red band does not have this problem, and I suspect that the red is colored material throughout, while the rose gold is merely coated.  We're going to seek a replacement from Amazon for the rose gold band and switch to a different color for my wife.

As for the fit and function of the band, we give it 5 stars all the way.

reviewText:

I received this as a replacement for a clear Zagg screen protector that was defective. Today was installation day and I am happy to report that it all went splendidly. If you are going to do the installation yourself, it is imperative that you follow the instructions to the letter to guarantee success. Find a clean and dust free work area. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Clean the screen with the microfiber cloth that is included until it is dust and particle free. The kit includes a spray tube of solution. Saturate your fingertips with this stuff.....all ten digits. Remove the backing paper and liberally spray both sides until they are wet. Position and align the protector against the screen cutouts. Using the enclosed squeegee, affix and work outward to the edges get rid of any air bubbles. Theoretically, you should be ready to use the phone immediately. However, I gave it a couple of hours to dry and cure. I now have a bubble and dirt free shield.
Some people don't like the matte finish. I like it because it cuts down on screen glare without interfering with the image. My husband has the smudge proof shield on his iPhone4. I have it on my iPhone4s. In both cases, this screen fits perfectly. The composition of the shield isn't the same as the clear shield. It seems more stable and easier to work with. I have a similar screen on the new iPad4 and have had the same great results with it.
If applied as instructed, you should be happy with this product. It does a great job protecting the screen.

I am getting this Arkon car seat rail mount for my 6.1 inch Huawei Ascend Mate 2 smartphone. Due to the big 6.1 inch screen size, I am having hard-time in finding smartphone holders that can accommodate the 3.5 inch wide phone body. Most of in-car smartphone holders can open up-to 3.4 inch wide only.

If the vehicle to be installed is a mini-van, van, SUV or pickup, then the 22 inch size is better. For sedan, the 18 inch option is sufficient. I installed the seat rail mount to my 2014 Odyssey mini-Van. The installation work is not hard, but need some palm-size handy tools around as the working space is tight inside the car. The metal goose-neck neck of this rail mount is pretty stiff but bendable. That's good as it keeps the shape once I bend it into final position.

The 360 degree swivel of the phone mount is very flexible, as my phone can pivots to any direction. During driving, the goose-neck does shake but not too much.

Overall, this is a solid phone holder that can sustain quite some abuse. I would recommend this Arkon car Seat rail mount over other smart phone holders that relying on sticking to the dash-board, or ventilation outlets.

This is a very well-made and sturdy bumper-type case for the iPhone 5 / 5s. The material used is grippy in the hand, yet slick enough not to catch on materials such as pockets and not pick up lint and hold on to it like silicone bumpers can do. Putting on the case is like putting on a bumper case...just pop the phone in, backside first and pop the cases corners over the phones corners. The back is fully covered except for the area near the camera & flash which is to be expected. The fit is nice and snug without being overly tight. There are some additional grip ridges near the bottom sides which help quite a bit when holding the phone...a nice touch.

The case is very slim in spite of the protection it adds to the device. The corners are thicker than the rest of the edges which puts more shock-absorbing martial where its needed...on the corners where the device will likely hit upon impact. No drop tests were done, however, I can see the phone surviving pretty well with no damage if dropped to the floor from a normal arms-length distance. Note that the screen itself is not protected nor covered by the case, except for the raised edges and corners which should protect it somewhat if dropped onto the screen itself and it lands in a somewhat flat manner.

All of the phones buttons work well through the case and the cutouts for the microphone and speaker are very precise. The lightning connector opening should work fine and accommodate any Apple or MFi (Made for iPhone/iPad/iPod) certified cable. The headphone jack opening works fine with the standard Apple headphones/earPods but I have no other brand of headphones to test this functionality any further.

Cosmetically, the case is very glossy due to the material used so of you don't like this type of flash or prefer a flat, non-glossy look, look elsewhere. I personally did not care for the etched internal line pattern on the case. It distracts from the clean look that having a minimalistic-type case would bring to the device. The NewTrent logo is fine however. Again, this is pretty much personal preference and doesnt deter that much nor affect the cases functionality.

All in all, a great minimalistic bumper-type case from New Trent!

Disclaimer: I am a New Trent Pilot User so the item reviewed was provided to me for only a minimal charge. My views and review of the item are not influenced by this in any way.
summary: This is a very well-made and sturdy bumper-type case for the iPhone 5 / 5s

Having used the LG G2 as my primary phone for the last 2 months and a half I think it is enough time to write a fairly competent review of my experience. My experience with the device has been very pleasant. I love the phone, but as with any other electronic device it has its pros and its cons. I will explain with more detail each of the above pros and cons below.

Pros (continuation)

1. Probably the single most important thing a smart phone needs to have is good performance. In this aspect this phone certainly delivers. It is fast, very fast. It will handle pretty much anything that you can throw at it. I currently have 1 live wallpaper running behind three home screens that have a total of 4 widgets. It still runs flawlessly. The transitions and animations are smooth and lag free. My previous phone was a Galaxy S3 and even though that phone was no slouch you can definitely tell the difference between the S3 and G2. I have seen the biggest improvement in the browser. The G2 is noticeably faster opening tabs and loading pages. It is also smoother when zooming in and out of web pages. As far as games are concerned I have not run many graphic intensive games. I do play a lot of Temple Run (my favorite game) and it runs with no problems.

2. Battery life is often times the biggest weakness that a smart phone can have. That is not the case with the G2. Battery life is simply outstanding. I find it almost impossible to drain the battery with normal use in one day. For example, having use the phone for 14 hours today listening to podcasts and music, talking for about an hour, sending over 50 text messages and watching Netflix the battery is still at 60% before going to sleep. By the way, the screen brightness was at 75%. I absolutely hated having to always have to dim the screen in the S3 to have the battery last me a whole day. The only thing that takes a considerably amount of battery is the GPS. An hour using the GPS with full brightness will use about 25% of the battery. Not a big deal if you have a car charger though. Speaking of charging, this phone charges from 0-100% in two hours. Not bad at all for such a big battery.

3. One of the most advertised aspects of this phone is its big beautiful display. There is no denying it is gorgeous. Absolutely great if you want to watch videos and pictures. Reading on the phone is comfortable. Colors are considerably toned down from the AMOLED displays on Samsung phones. The pixel count in the display is through the roof making texts incredibly sharp. I have not had any problems with burn in or flickering on the screen. Nothing more to say here, the screen is awesome.

4. The camera of the phone is excellent by cell phone standards. There is no way it is going to replace a DSLR camera but it can replace a regular point and shoot. I have not used my regular point and shoot camera in the last two years. The LG G2 takes excellent pictures during the day and decent pictures at night. The pictures come out looking much better at night if you use the night mode on the camera app. But that can be a hassle when you are trying to take a picture quickly. LG has marketed OIS capabilities of the camera. Honestly, I see this having the biggest difference when I am taking videos. The videos definitely look less shaky than the ones in my S3. When it comes to taking pictures however I don't think it really does much though. If I am not careful I still get the occasional blurry picture.

5. The phone comes with 32 GB of memory. You can only use about 24 GB out of the box. After installing all my apps, music, taking a ton of picture and videos I still have 12 GB left. The storage is not a problem in my opinion. It is a good thing the base configuration of the phone comes with 32 GB and not 16 GB.

6. I got used to the buttons being on the back of the phone after a few hours. It just becomes second nature after that. I actually find the position really comfortable now. I laugh whenever somebody tries to turn on my phone and they spend half a minute trying to figure out how to turn it on. If you are hesitating on this phone because of the back buttons DON'T. They are really no big deal. You might actually like it after a while. Even if you still don't like the buttons on the back you can always use the knock knock feature. That way you don't even have to use them if you don't want to.

Cons (continuation)

1. The bad thing that comes with having such a big phone is that it makes it pretty difficult to use with one hand. It can get annoying when you are driving and trying to change a song quickly on the phone. I have small hands for a guy but they are not exactly tiny either. The phone itself is pretty thin and it definitely packs the biggest screen possible with the space it has. The borders are very small. Just keep in mind it is still a huge phone, not much smaller than the Samsung Galaxy Note 2. That is great for watching movies but a real pain in the behind if you like using the phone with one hand.

2. Having use the G2 the last few months you can definitely tell that the LG software team is not up to par with its hardware. I have experienced a few bugs while using the phone. None of them a huge deal but annoying nonetheless. For example, the knock knock feature should be more like knock knock knock knock. You definitely have to tap more than once to get it to work at times. Also when the knock knock feature is On and I am going to put the phone in my pocket or lay it on a table the phone turns On for no apparent reason. The problem goes away if I turn the knock feature off. But by far the most annoying bug I have had has been with the messenger application. I have had to completely turn the notifications for text messages off. The phone will not turn off the screen if I have the notifications On. It happens with every single text message application on the market which makes me think it is a bug in the operating system itself and how it is handling these notifications.

3. This phone has no removable battery or micro SD slot. Not that big of a deal for me but I know many people care about it. It might be a problem in a couple of years if the battery starts giving me any problems and I need to replace it. By that time I figure I have gotten a new phone though.

4. I have tried the quick remote feature a few times now. It works with all my TVs and DVDs on my house. The set up was simple enough. The problem is that it just doesnt have nearly enough range and you have to point exactly straight at the device you are trying to operate. Often times it doesnt receive the command and you have to press it again, again, and again. Very irritating. It is definitely a feature I see using in case of emergency only if I ever lose or break the other remote controls. It is a real shame though because I can see how useful it is to have all your remotes in one.

5. When you first get the phone it comes with the LG stock launcher. It is not bad but it is not nearly as good as some other launchers you see on the Play Store. The Nova Prime launcher has less clutter while having more features and customizations. There are no swipe shortcuts in the LG launcher, which is one of the reasons I like Nova Prime so much. The LG launcher is very similar to the Samsung Touchwiz in a lot of ways. When you swipe down the notification panel it has toggles for rotation, wifi, data, Bluetooth, GPS, airplane mode, quick remote, NFC and more. It also has volume and a brightness slide bar so you can adjust them. All of these features in the notification area are very useful but it would be very nice if you could have the option to take them away. You cant take them away which makes the notification feel cramped and cluttered.

6. The final problem with the phone is that just like with a lot of phones a protective case is a must. The phone is fragile and it will definitely break if you drop it. Not only that, it is also fingerprint magnet. I had my phone two days before deciding it was a mistake to have it without a cover. The phone looks disgusting without a case. You can see the fingerprints from a mile away. The phone feels slippery without a case too. I ended up purchasing the Incipio Dual Pro case. It gives the phone a much better grip and minimizes fingerprints. It also offers very good protection while keeping the phone pretty slim. I highly recommend it.

In conclusion, do I recommend this phone? I sure do. Overall, the phone is a fantastic devise. It is fast, has a nice screen and it takes good pictures and videos. The battery lasts all day which is a big plus in my opinion. Unfortunately I cannot it give 5 out of 5 because of all the cons I mentioned above. The biggest problem being the software bugs it has. To be fair though I don't think there is a single phone in the market that is worth 5 out of 5 stars. There just isnt. There is a lot of pretty impressive competition but you will always find fault with a product if you really want to look at it with an objective view. I really hope this review helped you decide whether this phone is right for you. If you are in the market for a new phone keep an open mind and go to the store to try different phones. There are other options besides Apple and Samsung phones and the LG G2 is certainly worthy competition.
summary: Great phone with a few flaws

reviewText:
I have been eyeing this phone for months watching for a price break, which finally happened last week. On top of that great deal, I am going to send my phone to Nokia Trade Up For Cash program, which means overall I have spent $200 on this really cool phone.

I had Nokias my whole cell phone history and last year got a Motorola. I really did like my Z9 but it was almost obsolete from day 1 (but I really don't have anything bad to say about it, it was a good phone.) I missed Nokia with their simple menus and excellent quality.

To be honest, the menus are no longer simple and sometimes seem counterintuitive LOL. And the touchscreen is a bit hard to use with the fingers like touching an iPhone (I have an iPod Touch so I was waffling between this phone and the iPhone). The touchscreen works very well with the included styli though. And my learning curve is getting better with touch, so I don't see it being a problem after a while. I think the accelerometer is faster than my Touch, almost too quick sometimes. The Music Player is the bomb! Way louder than my Touch and perfect clarity. It sounds amazing. I don't even need an additional speaker like I need for my Touch.

The screen is gorgeous and so far setting up everything has gone well. I have my music transferred, my contacts transferred and am very happy. I like the compact size and heft of the phone. I don't like lightweight feeling phones. The camera seems fine to me. The battery life does seem to be on the shorter side but make sure you close web applications after use. The phone does so much that you can dejuice it quickly. My Touch does the same thing.

Nokia definitely needs to step up with apps and also get the Music Store available for the US! Also if you message the downloads to yourself it is a pain, so it is better to download on the phone direct from the store. The App selection bites though, but that's what my ipod is for. The thrill of app-ness dies down anyway, so it's not really a big deal, but not having music store access is just silly.

Otherwise this phone is very competitive to iPhone. Being upgradeable with its memory is a definite plus and you can even have many memory cards since it's hot swappeable, technically that is unlimited memory. I love my Touch of course but I got an 8g and I'm maxed out with music and apps and now I can't do anything to it unless I get rid of stuff. That kinda bites. So the 5800 has a true edge there.

I already had AT&T and it was no problem to pop my SIM card in the phone and move right along. I had everything except the TV out cord and the stand which it appears on the website that they do not sell that in the package anymore so that is more Amazon's fault for not upgrading the info, but I don't really need the stand or cord. The USB cord is entirely too short. The headset comes in 2 pieces with a piece that can control the music and phone, which is very nice. Of course the charger is included and is acceptable. It easily connected with my internet, easily paired with my bluetooth, and once I finally figured out how to transfer music from my ipod to it, there were no problems there.

I am very pleased with this phone and would recommend it for people who want a quality touchscreen phone and not necessarily an iPhone.

PS I LOL at 8g holding 6000 songs. Maybe 6000 ringtone sound bytes. 8g will net you between 600-800 average songs....
summary: happy to be back with Nokia

reviewText:
This is my third buy of this product with three compaimes. I was hoping for different results but they're all the same. The biggest con is the case affects picture taking and the pics are blurry. I don't know if it's from the water itself or the heat or condensation, but the main reason I take my phone with Me to the lake is for the ability to take pics while in the water. I was too afraid to try it under water as the last one of a different brand failed to even work at all under water. The biggests things u need to remember is 1: perform a water test first by placing some toilet paper inside - closing it up and putting it in water. #2 close it tight! It seems closed but unless u put pressure on every seem, side and corner until u hear it click-- it is NOT closed! #3 make sure your volume is on and once the case is on you can go into your settings and accessibility and then turn on the assistive touch, this way you can turn your volume from on to mute easily. Cause without that feature you will NOT be able to turn volume from on to off with this case on.
Pro: it works for when u may get splashed or by a shower or tub.. Water resistance is more what I would use it for, when u don't plan to get it wet where the camera eye is.  For picture ability.
Pro: the strap
Pro: the kick stand - although it's almost truly impossible to get it to open, I mean we had to use the included tool, it is really a good feature for doing timer group photos!
overall I don't hate it and wouldn't be opposed to buying it again, it just wasn't exactly great for what I wanted.
Phone was not sealed and did not look authentic. Returned.

In my review I started with the assumption that anyone considering this case is specifically looking for a folio case and has accepted some of the drawbacks of this case format. As a result, I did not adjust the overall rating either up or down for the features or drawbacks that are unique to this case format. Here is a summary of some of the pros and cons of the case to consider.

PROS
=====================================
+ Very little bulk is added to the phone by the case.
+ The slot inside the flap can fit a few credit cards, ID and paper money.
+ The magnet on the flap allows the case to remain closed and the magnet also holds the flap in place if you fold the flap behind the phone.
+ After answering or placing a call the flap can be closed to continue the conversation. A small slit on the flap allows the sound of the receiver to come through.
+ The phone easily slides into the case.

CONS
=====================================
- Taking a picture with the rear-facing camera means leaving the front flap open. If there was a slit on the front flap to expose the rear facing camera then flipping the flap around the back of the phone would work very well.
- The power and volume buttons are awkward to reach while in the case.
- The phone is well protected when the folio is closed, but the phone is exposed if the folio is opened, which could lead to damage to the phone if it were dropped.
- Ideally the flap on the folio would hold the phone in a horizontal upright position. Considering the larger format of the iPhone 6 it makes it an ideal option to consume multimedia, so it would be nice to have the folio case be able to support the phone in this position.

Overall this is a great folio case with some drawbacks that depending on preference could place the star rating anywhere between a 3 to 4.
summary: Solid Folio Case w/ Some Drawbacks

reviewText: Perfect.  Great product.
Wonderful

It a nice phone.  You all know the specs.  It does come with a lot of loaded apps that take up plenty space.  I must say, you probably should find a case for it.  It seems a bit harder to handle than any other phone I've had, so I fumble with it a lot.  I think it's a fairly fragile phone.  It probably won't handle many small drops.  Also, I always seem to turn it on when simply grabbing it or pulling out of my pockets.  The buttons, on the side, are very sensitive.  It seems like a very capable phone, but I struggle with the arrangement of the power and volume buttons on the side.  Battery seems to need recharging 5-7 hours into the day with very little use. And, did I say, it has a lot of bloatware?  I am constantly killing apps in order to preserve battery life.  So much junk running in the background.

I've been a Samsung fan for a long time. It all started with the Galaxy Player 5.  That was a great device during that period just before the true smartphone boom.  We have 3 Samsung LED TVs, two Galaxy 7inch tablets, a nearly 3.5 year old Galaxy Note 10.1 inch Tablet, a 10 in Galaxy Tab, and 9.7 inch Tab S2.  This however is the first of the Galaxy line of phones I've purchased.  While I like the look of the phone and the style, I'm not overall impressed with this device.  Samsung loaded this with plenty of bloatware and AT&T also loaded it with a ton of crap.

This is a late review of course.  I just purchased this phone just prior to Christmas (2015), yet this phone has been out for probably 3 years.  I liked the hardware specs and it finally fail into price range (approx $200) that I was willing to spend on a phone.  I refuse to spend $600+ on a phone because it boast capabilities that I would never use.
summary: Nice Hardware, but I'm not crazy impressed by experience.

This Lens kit turns your iPhone 6 into a real camera, maybe even a better camera than my Nikon point and shoot.  I love my little Nikon, but sometimes I don't have it charged or with me when I need it.  I always have my iPhone with me and take a lot of photos and video.  This lens kit with two lens is easy to carry and slips on and off in seconds. The system is really quite ingenious.  The metal casing slips on your phone and snuggly holds the lens in place over the iPhone lens.  I tried to upload before and after pics of my dog but had problems with that - I will try again since there is really a huge difference in detail.  I can now use the wide angle lens to capture more of a landscape and the 3x lens picks up more detail than I could even imagine possible.  I am enthralled with the 3x lens since it lets me take pictures that even my Nikon couldn't because it doesn't have this type of magnification.  The only downside to this system is that it won't slip over a case but I use an easy-to-remove one when I know I want to use the lens.

reviewText:
20151101-I'll preface this by stating that the case is still very new to me, and it is the first rugged case I've put on this phone.  So I'll be back to update my impressions of this case in a few months.

Generally, I'd wait and put some miles on it before I reviewed it, but right out of the box I got a very strong impression of this case.  I've used rugged cases on every smartphone I've had; except my first, the HTC Merge, which was not a very aftermarket friendly phone.  Since I buy my phones outright, I'm well aware of their value and spend accordingly on their cases.  It's pretty much a compulsion with me; to keep trying till I find "the one".  So I've tried everything from a cheap, off-the-shelf Pelican to a hideously expensive Seidio Obex that I bought on Amazon.

Simply taking it out of the packaging, it felt sturdier than anything I've had on any of my phones, except the Obex of course.  Indeed, the only case I've used that was more difficult to open up and get the phone into WAS the Obex.  But that's not necessarily a bad thing.  It seems like the harder they are to get open, the less they rely on the structure of your phone to maintain their shape in an impact, which translates to the case taking more punishment than the phone.  Just watch the installation video they have on YouTube, bring your patience, and you'll get through it.

Integrated screen protector-Was extremely well attached.  If any part of your purchasing decision involves that, I can definitely attest to how well it's fused to the case.  With designs that aren't "water proof" I typically provide a tempered glass screen protector and throw away any integrated ones; this is the first case I've done that to where I actually had to start a corner with a knife and slit the first inch along the edge before I could get a good enough hold to pull it out.  Its fused to the case like the one in the waterproof Obex.  Unfortunately, I can't speak to its quality beyond that, since the first thing I did was remove it.

Beveling around the screen- Hands down my biggest pet peeve where rugged cases are concerned.  YES, I do appreciate that when the phone is lying face down, the glass is a good 1/8" from the surface I've rested it on.  NO, I do not appreciate non-beveled edges that require two handed use, or a double-jointed thumb to drag an icon from one screen to the next.  The Obex and Otterbox Defenders were the worst, Obex had no beveling at all, 90 degrees to the glass; the Defender's bevels were so steep they could barely be considered an improvement.  This case is the only rugged case I've ever used where the edges are beveled so neatly that I can slide my thumb right up to the edge of the touch screen.

Easily my favorite feature-big props to the engineering team that realized that not all thumbs are tiny and/or double-jointed!

Materials- Thick, very sturdy, very tight.  Feels more like an Obex than a Defender; although some genius put 6 little rubbery accents on the back that look cosmetic, but are very well placed for keeping the otherwise hard and not-tacky back of the case from sliding around on what you put it on.  I'm hoping that "feels more like an Obex" remains true over the long term, as the root of my dislike for the Defender lies in the silicon outer skin's tendency to get baggy and sloppy over time.  Given the way this case goes together, if it gets sloppy like the Otterbox, it'll become unusable.  Though...  considering how much less it costs than the Defender, I think I could live with replacing it if it lasts more than 6mo.

Belt clip/holster- Definitely more Obex/Defender quality than Pelican; but time will tell.  It feels solid, the case engages the holster in a very solid and reassuring way, although unlike the Obex it doesn't have a positive lock that actually reaches over the phone and grabs the back.  It's more like the Defender, where the clip rests in a dimple.  This design is close to the Obex in that it doesn't use a dimple, but I'd definitely like to see more clip reach around the back of the case, even if it did require more force to get the phone out of the holster.

Summary:  It's priced like a Pelican, but without the disappointment.  In my opinion it's competitive with Seidio's Obex and Otterbox's Defender, with tradeoffs.  It actually feels less like I've compromised for ruggedness than it does with either of those brands.  Of course, it's not waterproof like the Obex, but it doesn't mess with the sound or features of the phone either...  The only thing I feel you'd lose in going with this over Otterbox's Defender is the branding.
summary: Very polished design-Punches above its weight from a price perspective.

reviewText:
I bought this to replace my Cricket branded Moto G.  I had considered getting the Alcatel Onetouch Idol 3 like my wife did, but in the end I decided on the Asus Zenfone 2 Laser

I was a little uneasy about getting this particular phone in the beginning. Many of the reviews were mixed and I was not sure that it would be worth the money I was going to spend on it (I can only afford budget phones). However when Amazon lowered the price by $30 which put it at $199, I pulled the trigger and hoped for the best. The 32 gig of storage and 3 gig of memory works very well for this phone. It is fast and it has not lagged yet even with 10 or more apps open at the same time. Battery life seems to be comparable to other phones and if I am not playing games on it, I can get all day out of it without a problem on one charge. It is a little bigger than I am used to but oddly enough it seems to work for me. While larger than my Moto G, it is much better performing in almost every aspect.

The notification light is not overly bright, unlike my Moto G which seem to be far too intense at night. The Zenfone allows you to turn it off if you would like but I leave it on for emails, texts and voicemails.  I could not turn it off completely on my Moto G.

My complaints are mostly minor.  The display is very weak in bright sunlight. The overall volume seems a little lower then my Moto G but it is still loud enough to hear even when it's in my pocket. The Zen UI is a little confusing at first. It is an acquired taste but once you get used to it it is not bad. Also the back, home, and recently used apps buttons at the bottom of the phone do not light up which is kind of a pain when you use your phone in the dark. To me this is a big design flaw. Of course most Android users know where the buttons are, but it would be nice to have them light up just a little bit.

My biggest complaint would have to be the amount bloatware installed that cannot be removed. I think I was able to remove 3 apps total. you can uninstall the updates and disable them but I am hesitant to do so because I do not know what effect they will have on the operation of the phone.

Even with the large amount of bloatware installed, this phone does not lag at all. It has some great tweaking apps that allow you to clear the memory quickly which helps out if you have lots of apps open. Sound quality is on par with other phones I have used and the photo quality is very good.

Many people complain about the power button on the top of the phone, but this works out very well for me because it makes it easier to find in the dark. Also the volume buttons on the back of the phone, while a bit odd, also work because with the MoKo hybrid  case I am using, it means the volume buttons never accidentally get bumped while it's in my pocket.

Solid phone, well priced, good value.
summary: I had considered getting the Alcatel Onetouch Idol 3 like my wife did

reviewText:
I have now used this in two different cars, and it is perfect - you can have the USB ports (and 12V ports, if needed) where you need them. The USB ports are also high-power enough to charge not just the usual GPS and Smartphone, but even my iPad, which needs 2A to charge.
The unit comes with a long cord, and additional hardware to allow various ways to connect it to the car, all of which looks sturdy and functional, tough I ended up not using them - the unit fits perfectly in the space between the front Passenger seat and the center console (on two cars now - a Subaru Wagon and a Toyota Camry).

This so convenient that I recommend this to anyone, even if your car does have 12V sockets in the central console. it has 2 of everything, for the couple who has multiple power-hungry devices (you know who you are ...)

In addition, after I bought the item I received a gracious email from Mr. Dodge, a Customer Service Manager of Gizmoco, the vendor,  writing to make sure I was happy with the product and the transaction.
As you can tell, I am. If you are in the market for additional car charging ports - I highly recommend this.
summary: Perfect product, and good Customer service - Highly recommend

reviewText:
This is such a cute case and comes with a stylus too. When I got it the price was $8.99 and currently it's listed at $5.97. For the price this is a super cute little wallet style case. The Tree and Leaf Pattern is so cute. The inside of the case also has the design on one side and it is pink on the other side.

The case that holds the iPhone 6 is pink and soft pliable plastic that makes it easy to get your phone in and out of the case. All the buttons on your phone have an opening and there is an opening on the back for your camera.

It is easy to fold the case back to talk on the phone. I love that it has little slots for a credit card or some money. You can not put anything too bulky in there but its fine for a business card, credit card or a small amount of money.

Honestly for the price you just can not beat it for this case. It has a magnetic strap that keeps the case closed. Also there is a small grommet if you want to attach a strap or lanyard to the case. I have seen cases like this for double or more.

Thanks for reading my review

Becky Brooks

*I was selected to receive this phone case for free, for testing and review purposes.

This is the first gamepad that I've ever purchased.  And after about 3 weeks of use, love it.  It has totally changed my gaming habit on my galaxy s7.

Pros:
I love that the controls are on both sides of the phone.  Makes the phone/controls very balanced.
Width of the Gamepad easily adjusts, and locks in place.  It's also spring loaded, so you can load and unload your phone/pad easily.  Because it's spring loaded, it securely holds it in place.
Controls are very comfortable in the hand.  Buttons, except in the case below, work well, and are conveniently placed.
Auto shut off of the pad.  I think around 5 minutes of non use.  Might be a bit shorter.
LED light indicates when it is on.
Second LED light flashes when battery is low.
Battery lasts a while.  I usually charge it once a week.  And usually use it at least an hour or two a day, if not more.
Easily paired with my Galaxy S7.
Very lightweight.  I don't get tired at all when playing games using it.

Cons
Some squeeking in the left joystick
Left button sometimes sticks.  You need to completely depress and press again.

reviewText:
This battery charger has sleek design and it is very light. Although it is not very thin. Two different Amp output options are simply marvelous." Hit two birds with one stone! "
I have charged multiple electronics and the NT70T maintains 60-70% of its battery life which is great and exceed my expectation. This battery can charge most Apple products which is great.

Pros:
-Sleek design and light weight. Robust construction with a nice looking glossy front.
-Two USB ports for charging (1A/2A) and a third 1A mini-USB. This means up to three charges at once.
-The built in charging cord is a big plus.
-It's a bit bigger than my iPhone. But smaller and lighter is always better.

Suggestions/ Improvements:
-I wish this included a bundle of short little charging cables for various devices so there is no need to lug around long charging cables.
-I would prefer a more precise battery level indicator. Digital indicator could be even better, instead of the four LEDs on the unit or something that shows a percentage
 instead of just a simple colored blue light without meaning.
-It would also be nice if a carrying case would be come with the unit.
-It seems to get dirty very easily on its shiny gloss black finish. I would've preferred matte plastic.
-Light indicators turn off while charging the devices and it is a little bit confusing it could be blinking in every few seconds instated of shutting off.

All in all, I love this product. On a scale of 1-5, I rate this product a four (4).
There are definitely some ways to improve this product; however this is the best one in the market for now.
I would recommend this device for anyone on the go, especially for a person with a smartphone.
summary: Great Battery Charger in The Market

reviewText:
This is the second replacement for this Screen Protector (amFilm), the first one had a square mark on the sticky side of the protector that was visible once it laid down on the screen,  I returned it to Amazon who promptly sent me a replacement.
This one (Replacement) went down on the screen with out so much as a bubble,  "But"  for some reason I have the same problem as others have reported about the bottom Left & Right corners,  for some reason they will not lay flat to meet the screen,
I tried everything including using two small plastic clamps which I attached to both corners and left them on over night,  but as soon as I removed them the corners immediately pop rite back up.
I would also like to add that I have two LG G4 phones, the one I purchased in 2015 has the TECH ARMOR Premium Ballistic Glass screen protector on it that I ordered here on Amazon when I ordered the phone on here,  and even though there were a few tiny bubble that eventually went away, the protector laid down and completely covered the LG screen with no lift what so ever.
So here is what I'm going to do,  I'm going to order another TECH ARMOR for this new LG and remove the amFilm,  I will then install the TECH ARMOR to see if the problem is the LG G4 Screen itself,  or if the problem is the amFilm. I will then report back here in a week or so to report the results,  and if the problem is the LG screen itself I will eat the cost of the second amFilm replacement.
(Update 02/02/17)
Well as I promised and after Two (2) Failed attempts at trying to get a flawless install of the amFilm Tempered Glass Screen Protector installed on my LG G4 I went ahead and ordered another brand from another Manufacturer,
I was planning on getting another TECH ARMOR which I have installed on another LG G4 but because of the TINY bubbles I got when I installed it the last time I decided to do some research,
So here on Amazon I typed in "Glass Screen Protectors For The LG G4" and about 6+ pages of different Manufactures loaded on my screen, the choices I had were over whelming to say the least, So I decide to pick one based on the numbers that were sold here on Amazon, One of the highest was the "YOOTECH Glass-Protector Premium Tempered Glass (YT-001-US-LG-G4) which is marked YOOTECH AMAZON on the box, which I assumes that this product is made to Amazons Spec's.
I'm happy to report that after removing the "DEFECTIVE amFilm"  which didn't fit my LG G4 at all, I did another complete cleaning of the screen and installed the YOOTECH and it went down "FLAWLESSLY" without any bubble and no lifting on the corners at all, in fact I';m so pleased with this screen protector I'm going to order another one for the LG that has the Tech Armor on it.
I'm giving the YOOTECH 5 Stars because it fits the Curved Screen of the LG G4 like a Glove + NO Bubbles at all.
By the way I did check out the 1 / 2/ and 3 Star reviews of the YOOTECH and most of the negative reviews were baseless, because the people were unsatisfied because the YOOTECH screen Protector ether shattered or chipped on the edges when they dropped it, "EXCUSE ME"  but isn't that the purpose of installing Screen Protector, So they Crack/ Shatter and Chip instead of the Expensive screen.
summary: UP IN THE AIR I'm Trying Another Brand

reviewText: Great portable charger for the price.  Needed a portable charger that could charge my Note 3 several times before I had to charge it back up.  This works perfect for my needs.
