reviewText: Needed to repair phone and it works.

Aukey Dual Port USB Car Charger Adapter (4.2Amps/20W) Designed for Apple and Android Devices: This device was sold through Amzdeal Direct (fulfilled by Amazon.com) and retailed for $7.99 at the time of writing this review.

Please Note: I was provided with a free device for the purpose of writing an honest review.

The technical
Weight: 1.07 oz (30.4 gm) I actually weight this unit.
Output: 20W 4.2A output on each port.
  port 1 is for Apple products
  port 2 is for other devices.

Some thoughts on "Aukey Dual Port Car Charger"...

1.) a small device that has a solid, well made feel to it.

2.) I have an dual port Amp meter so I was able to charge both my IPhone and my IPad at the same time from port 1. The combined total output I got from both devices was 2.89 amps. I could also do the same thing with port 2 but the charging rate was a little slower.

3.) has a small red LED light comes on when a connection is made between the car socket and the Dual Port charger.

Impressions:
I've only had this a short time but it works as advertised. And at $7.99 it's very reasonably priced.

As it is... 5 Stars.

Ray Nicholson
raynicholsonsreviews@hotmail.com
@ralannicholson
summary: The Aukey Dual Car Charger... excellent preformance at a reasonable price.

reviewText: GREAT

OK, seeing as there are so many good reviews I don't know if I received knock-offs or what.  There were no instructions in the package that I received but I've applied these before so I thought no-big deal.  I have applied 4 similar tempered glass protectors on S4s and every one went down without any problems at all.  Both of the protectors in the package wouldn't stick down completely around the speaker area.  The previous protectors I applied laid down completely without any effort on my part, I just dropped them into place.  After lifting the protectors up I noticed that the laminate material on the edge wasn't fully adhering to the glass portion and that's why it wouldn't fully lie down. In case you're wondering, yes, I rid remove the protective plastic from the adhesive side.  These are going back.

I really like the cover.  It feels good in my hand and does not add a lot to the device.  I have had it about 6 weeks and had concern about the flimsy way the face cover was attached to the back.  I thought it might tear.  No tear there but today, I found a crack at the top edge above the volume controls.  This may be from removing the phone when I charge it because it becomes quite hot while charging or playing games.  I'll probably crazy glue it together on the outside and continue to use it.  I hate that this happened because of the price.  It really is a nice, cover though.

HANDS DOWN BEST PHONE CASE IVE EVER BOUGHT! I am super picky and used to change my cases monthly with every other phone i've had until I got the iPhone 6 and bought this case. It is slim fitting but yet very protective, I drop my phone a lot. Perfect fit and the cut out around camera is good also, as it does not cause a glare on pictures when you use flash. I noticed some other people wrote the colored bottom piece may slip off, just make sure that when you put it on it "clicks" in, if its on properly it is actually hard to take off. Case covers buttons on sides of phone nicely, doesn't cause sticky keys. Edge of case is slightly higher than the screen so you can lay the phone face down and not worry about your screen touching. iPhone headphones and charger fit in the phone perfectly through case. The liney grip part above the colored piece is a great touch, I like the grip. I have been using this phone case for 8 months! The only reason I would replace it is because it is clear and turns brownish over time, I will definitely buy this TOTU DESIGN case again.
summary: BEST PHONE CASE IVE EVER BOUGHT

First of all, I will start by saying that I am very happy with how quickly I received the iPhone 6s Case,FEIKESI [Safe Slide] Stylish Color [Scratch-Resistant] Unique Emboss Matte Hard Back Snap on Protective Case Cover for Apple iPhone 6S (2015) & iPhone 6 (2014)(Mint Stripe)only 2 days from the time I ordered, it was at my doorstep! This really is a hip and beautiful case. The black and white stripes with the mint really stands out and looks clean. The feel of the case is smooth and matted, which I love. The bumpers are elevated enough so that the screen will not get scratched if you placed it screen-down. When I made the decision to spend $1593.75 (including shipping) on Glass II Explorer last November, I had expectations for what I could use it for. Here is a report on what those were, what other uses I discovered, and how Glass fared in regard to each use.

A better action video camera?
I had high hopes for Google Glass to be a replacement for my $50 bullet camera with better battery life, better image quality (because of the wide-angle lense) and better operability (because I see what it records and can pause it etc).
The verdict: Glass fails in this category. The battery life is even shorter (30 minutes tops with a full battery right off the charger). I can wear it under my aero-helmet, but not without feeling pressure. This is a no-go on even the shortest bike rides or runs. The low-light capability is not great, either, and on my night runs with a head light there is not much to see on the resulting video.
It does not fit under or over ski goggles, and the clear or active shades do not replace goggles (too small and too much draft that will tear up eyes at higher speeds).

An in-vehicle or dashboard camera?
A camera that reliably and continuously records what happens around me when I drive would be great. Glass is promising, because it captures my field of view, including the rear view mirror, but it is not reliable and cannot record continuously. When plugged in, the battery life would be no issue, but there is currently no app that records continuously (and overwrites earlier clips when memory runs out). Also, the display is always on when it records video, which is bothersome at night.
With a little bit of practice it is possible to wake up Glass and get into video recording mode in a matter of a few seconds, but that is not fast enough in unexpected situations.
My verdict: I think that the device has potential in this category with the right software. Currently it is limited.

A better run/ride tracker?
I saw that Strava has Glass apps even before I placed my Glass order, and I uploaded my entire workout history from Garmin to Strava in anticipation of using their apps with Glass.
The verdict: Glass fails in this category, but my reasoning requires explanation, because admittedly this is the fault of my Nexus 5 and not so much the fault of Glass. Glass relies on the GPS sensor of the phone, and the Strava app only works when the phone is paired. Unfortunately my Nexus 5s GPS sensor data appears to be very inaccurate.  When I started a "Run" on Strava while walking the dog, it placed me some 50 yards away from the road that I was on. I will continue to depend on the good old Garmin 305 in the coming years.
In addition to issue with GPS accuracy, I don't take Glass on runs because I sweat a lot from the head and both the power button and the bone-conduction speaker would be exposed and allow sweat (or rain water!) to enter the device.

A better headset?
A resounding no here. The bone conduction speaker vibrates and tickles behind my ear. Having longer conversations on Glass is uncomfortable. The sound quality is moderate at best, and many times there is some kind of mechanical obstruction that causes strong distortions, to a point where I cannot understand the other party. I keep my Glass clean and protected, so I am not sure what causes the distortion. Maybe a tiny dust particle is all it takes.
The ear bud speaker that is now included with Glass is too cumbersome to deal with for me. Glass is already bulky and in the way when you take if off because you can't simply fold it and put it in your shirt pocket. Now having something dangling on a USB cord attached to Glass is a non-starter. I have not even taken the ear bud out of the box yet.

A hands-free smart phone controller?
Being able to control important features of your phone without actually having to look at it or even hold in your hand is a compelling feature. If you use Gmail and Hangouts exclusively, you are being well-served by Glass. You will be alerted by and can read instant messages. and respond to and write instant messages and emails by using the voice recognition that works pretty reliably for me.
I don't seem to be able to create emails from scratch, only instant messages to one of up to 10 contacts. I do see emails in my Gmail inbox, though. They appear as a new slide in the timeline and I can respond to them without ever touching Glass. This is pretty cool.
The verdict: Unfortunately, I use neither Gmail nor Hangouts, and I frankly don't get Hangouts. I cannot access emails on my company's Exchange server or my personal IMAP service from Glass, and while I have over 1,000 contacts on my phone, I only see 14 contacts on Glass. This pretty much renders Glass useless as a communication device.

A better navigation device?
I really like the way navigation works. I have one car with a built-in navigation system and will not use Glass there - it certainly does not compete with the Mercedes Comand System. In my other car I do not have a navigation system at all, and previously I had to meddle with the phone when I needed directions. This works so much better on Glass.
My verdict: Navigation is definitely a compelling use of the product, in the car as well as on the bike or on foot (even though Google Maps lacks trail data). Based on some recent incidents that made national headlines, it appears that there is currently doubt among law enforcement officers whether using Glass while driving is legal and safe. I can attest that it can be surprising and distracting when Glass comes to live in full brightness during a night drive to alert you of an upcoming turn, but I don't find it all that different from having a GPS device in the car that is on all the time.

A better music streaming device?
With access to Google Music and completely hands-free operation through voice-activated searches, Glass offers yet another compelling use.
My verdict: Exciting possibilities, but currently we have to compromise on either poor audio quality or complicated handling/wiring of ear buds. The mono ear bud that comes with Glass is, well, mono only; stereo ear buds are available for an extra $85, and my ears aren't made for ear bud-type headphones anyway. They tend to hurt and fall out, and the same is true for the ear bud that came with Glass. Voice search appears to be mostly broken. I have close to 20,000 songs on Google Music and searches only randomly find stuff. Is it possible that the songs have to reside in the phone's cache for this to work? Overall, I am somewhat indifferent about Glass' current usefulness as a music streaming device.

Other uses?
Glassware can be installed from the phone or the computer. The current selection of applications that work with Glass is limited (I just counted 35), which I find surprising, given how long Glass has been available to the development community already.
My verdict: The speed of adoption among application developers seems to be slow and the number of available applications is small. I am confident that this will change. Still, no more than a null-vote on other uses at this time.

A mature and well-tested device?
I run into odd and unexpected situations with Glass almost daily that require some tinkering to figure out. Examples?
*The on-head detection is flakey and sometimes shuts off Glass unexpectedly. I figured this out myself and the chatter on the Explorer forums confirmed my diagnosis. I just disabled this feature entirely.
*The "Ok Glass" command stopped working on the 3rd day. I had to do a factory reset to get it back.
*When I did a factory reset, it took several attempts and an uninstall of the MyGlass app on the Nexus 5 before I was able to pair them again. Glass would just not get into pairing mode.
*Currently, phone calls or navigation don't work while on a Wifi connection, even though I am paired and connected with the Nexus 5. There is no way to "disable" the wireless connection temporarily. You have to make Glass "Forget" the connection to make a call and then recreate it. The phone reports the Bluetooth profile "Phone Audio", not "Headset" as one would expect.
*I am perpetually confused by what contacts I get to see on Glass. I understand that I can add up to 10 contacts from my phone that will show up on Glass as separate slides. So far I added 5 contacts. When I want to make a phone call, I am presented with 14 contact choices, though, the same people that appear in my Hangouts on Google. With half of them I have had no contact in years and I don't have the slightest idea how they ended up there.

My overall verdict:
The head-mounted display and its possibilities are exciting and an indication that this technology will become pervasive in the very near future. But Glass appears to still be an experimental device that does not excel in any particular discipline, comes with a high price tag, and that non-techie consumers will struggle with. The short battery life severely limits its practical use and spoils the fun.
I no longer keep my Glass charged and use it maybe once a month. It still works as a conversation-starter and that's pretty much the only thing I use it for.

I purchased this based on the recommendation of a friend. The case is a precise fit in all aspects. It's so precise that I had to remove the front screen protector because the Zagg Invisible Shield Glass Screen Protector that I also had installed would not allow the case to assemble until I did. The Zagg is super thin, so it shows just how close the tolerances are! All of the cutouts are also precise. The case does not hamper access to my S-Pen, and the charging and 3.5mm audio ports have tabs that seal them against water and dust. Frankly I do not need that level or protection, but if you work in harsh environments those are nice features. Installation is straightforward and easy. I had mine completely installed in about five minutes despite a little initial confusion from the storyboard part of the instructions. There are two steps in the procedure that do require attention: aligning the covers for the volume and power buttons. Those took mere seconds, but on the first attempt I did not have them properly seated. The way the rim around the screen is beveled and how it recesses the screen is a nice level of protection. I am guessing that the included screen protector is effective, but since I removed that so accommodate my Zagg glass protector I cannot say one way or the other. Bottom line: this is a little on the bulky side, but is possibly the best protection there is. I've wrecked phones in the past by accidentally dropping them, and do not expect the same fate for my Note 4 with this case installed.

I'm not sure you can ever have too many battery packs for your mobile devices, so I was more than happy to test out the LifeCHARGE JUMBO 22400mAh dual USB external charger. Now that I'm using an iPhone 6 Plus, I'm happy to have anything over a 10000 mAh charger so as to make sure I can get through a heavy use day. This LifeCHARGE has that and more...

In terms of size, it's 6.5" long and slightly over 3" wide (with just under an inch in depth). It's got some heft to it at one pound, but I'm used to that when you start getting into the 20000mAh size and beyond.

The white case gives it a very clean look that doesn't pick up any fingerprints or smudges. The on/off button sits on the side right next to the two USB ports. On the top edge you have the micro-USB slot for charging, as well as a small LED bulb that you can turn on with the on/off button. The front of the unit has four blue LED lamps that serve as the power remaining indicator.

I used this over a four day period to top off my charge on the iPhone 6 Plus. In just under 500 minutes of usage, I was able to get 225% of charge, *and* I still have two LED lights showing on the power meter. On my iPhone 5s, I was used to getting about 1% charge per minute of use, but the iPhone 6 Plus battery is a lot bigger. I'm happy with the two minutes per 1% recharge rate, and I'm *very* happy to know that I could get at least three full recharges on this battery before I'd have to plug it back in. Couple that with the fact that I can share the charger with another device (with the dual USB slots), and this becomes a must-pack charger for my trips.

I have a week-long conference coming up in May where I'll be using my iPhone and iPad a lot during the day. Having this charger makes me feel much more comfortable with my ability to go hard all day.

I had an Incipio DualPro on my last phone, and was pleased enough with it to use one on my upgraded Galaxy S7.

Pros
+ Nice texture
+ Price
+ Fitment
+ Protection
+ Doesn't add much bulk

For the benefits of this case it is cheaper than the other offerings, and for that I cannot complain. Installing the case on your phone is easy and the fitment is perfect with all ports and buttons aligned exactly where they should be. If this case holds up against drops as well as my previous Incipio had, then it will have served its purpose. The inner cushion shell has an added stiffness to it compared to my older model for my Droid Maxx, which is a definite plus. Any case will increase the dimensions of your phone, but for me personally it doesn't add that much extra and the benefit of having a case is plentiful.

Cons
- None as of yet

Conclusion
In my experience a case like this is all you need to protect your phone. The gorilla glass which seems standard on phones now days does well against impacts and scratches, except for corner glass impacts which is really where you experience damage. The raised lip of the case eliminates corner and full face impacts, and because of that there is no need for a screen protector, this of course has been my experience and opinion.

These are the only protected 18650 cells that fit all of my flashlights without issue.  I've recently been upgrading to higher mAh capacity protected 18650 batteries in order to extend runtimes on my flashlights.  Unfortunately with the higher mAh comes at a cost of larger cells that have prevented them from fitting in most of my 18650 flashlights.  My usual quality brands were becoming too wide at these higher capacities to fit my flashlights, from single cell to others with battery carriers.  I have some ThruNite flashlights, but never purchased their cells previously as my goto 18650 brand had served me well until width issues surfaced.  So I took the plunge after being frustrated with other top 18650 brands that no longer fit my flashlights and my search is over.  These protected 18650 cells fit ALL of my flashlights whether it's single cell, multi cell or battery carrier.  The reason seems to be that the PCB is a top mounted only version and not a top and bottom with a strip down the side.  This top mounted PCB variety seems to keep the width a little slimmer than the usual top, bottom and strip PCB's.  I'm not sure on the pro's and con's of this particular setup, but I can say that they fit all my lights and seems to provide the added runtimes that I was looking for in higher mAh cells.  Time will tell how these hold up and perform, but for now I am happy to find a 3400mAh cell that fits and seems to be of high quality (they are wrapped nicely)....
summary: Finally one that fits all my 18650 flashlights

reviewText:
This Qi wireless charger is the easiest way to charge.

I do not know about you, but I hate searching for a cord to charge my phone. Having this wireless charger, makes charging much easier. This charging method will take a little more time than a standard wall charger. Most people charge their phones at night time, so this is not a deal breaker.

First, you have to make sure your phone is Qi-Compliant (wireless charging capable). There are there options to choose from: your phone comes with wireless installed; you change your back cover to a wireless cover; or get a wireless receiver (patch) that goes between the back cover and battery. Once you have chosen you wireless charging method, plug up the wireless charger and let the magic happen.

Once you phone is placed on the charging pad, try to keep it centered with the white ring to ensure the best charge. There is a status LED that will show the charge state, green for standby and a turns blue for charging. The best part is there is an audible sound when the phone is charging.

If you are tired of plugging up you phone, with this charger that will be a thing of the past.

CONTENTS:
PowerBot Qi Enabled Wireless Charging Pad
Micro USB Cord
User Guide

FEATURES:
Input: 5V/1.5A
Transmission Distance: 0.15-0.39in (4-10mm)
Size: 3.2 x 5.9 x 0.39in (81 x 150 x 9mm)
Weight: 4.16oz (118g)
Charging Efficiency: > 72%
summary: Easiest Way To Charge Your Phone

It has good, heavy clear and black plastic material with  a chamber along the long sides and bottom that serves as floatation and a cushion as well. All of my pressurized diving gear, from camera lenses to camera bodies, flashlights and decompression meters, has some form of o-ring seal that gets tighter when pressure increases. reviewText: Excellent

This thing is a beast. This a travelers best friend. I travel often for both work and pleasure and this thing has been a godsend. Ridiculously fast charging of my Galaxy S8+ and my Galaxy Tab S2 and it kept my phone and tablet charged for nearly whole week without the need to plug in to an outlet... and I'm on my phone A LOT!!!!

As soon as I purchased an iPhone, I knew I had to get something to protect it from my clumsiness, and after looking around at a friends Defender (and realizing how BIG of a case it was) I wanted something smaller, but still able to handle punishment.  So far, the Commuter has fit the bill.

The Commuter consists of 3 parts, a screen protector (applied with an applicator to 'try' to smooth out the bubbles), a silicon sleeve to protect the sides and back from drops and impacts, and frame / metal wrap to keep the silicon sleeve in place.

Overall, the pieces and parts work well to protect the phone from scratches, dings, and most importantly (for me) drops.  I've dropped the phone several times now on hardwood floors (just my lack of coordination) pulling it out of my pocket (3ft) and have seen no signs of damage to the phone.  The screen protector is doing its job, and doesn't seem to easily scratch (the phone sometimes rides around in my pocket with keys, and still looks perfect).  Additionally, since most of the ports are well protected, small splashes haven't seemed to hurt it at all, even though it doesn't claim waterproof abilities.

Another nice thing about this case is that it adds very little in the way of size.  The iPhone is a fairly good sized phone to begin with, but this case is a very small addition and the protection is well worth it.  The buttons are all easy to press with the case on, and the speakers still provide close to the same sound (from what I can tell).

The only reason I've given this a 4 instead of a 5 is because sometimes the case tries to slip from the edges occasionally, and the covers for the ports can sometimes be a pain to get back into place.  Overall though, I can't complain and have been very happy with its level of protection and small size.

reviewText: This is a great case.

I purchased and installed this for my Motorola X Pure.
Initial thoughts:
-Well packed. Triple packed in fact.
-Comes with all necessary cleaning pads and instructions
-Screen protector is thin

Pre- Installation:
-Wiped phone down with my personal electronic wipes.
-I wiped phone down again
-I used air can to blow out any loose dust particles.
-I then 'test fitted' the Pleson screen protector

Actual Installation:
-Wash your hands! ;)
-I wiped both sides of the screen protector off slowly. Rubbing too hard creates static.
-I then wiped the phone down with the provided wet wipe.
-After the wet wipe, you can use the dry wipe but FYI. This caused extra static for me due to the winter months and dry air. I chose to re-wipe the screen with the wet wipe and allow to air dry briefly before applying the protector.
-Removing the plastic shield from the protector should be done SLOWLY, so you don't create static. Be sure to not squeeze too hard on the sides or your fingerprints will show.
-I grabbed the sides of the top and the bottom. I started with the bottom. It is much easier to align the lower part up and then guide the top.
-Once the bottom is squared around the speaker, guide the top using the sides to keep it straight and gently set the top down on the phone.
-The screen protector should automatically start to settle and you will see it do it's magic.

Disadvantages:
The top could cover a little bit more. The top left on this phone doesn't cover as high as I'd like.
The screen protector is much thinner than what I removed. Maybe it will protect as well, I am not sure.

Problems encountered:
Dry environment in winter time caused a lot of static and I had to remove the protector twice. The maximum Pleson recommends before adhesion loss around edges occur. The problem I had is that there was so much dust, the sticker they provide wasn't cutting it, so I ran the scren protector under warm water for a few seconds and shook it off while it was facing down as best as possible. I then re-installed after cleaning phone yet again... The plus side of wetting it allowed me to slide it around to get it perfect. The downside to this was many many fingernail strokes to remove all water and air. The pics were taken immediately after and really need a day to fully dry underneath because of my problems. BUT I was able to salvage a high quality screen protector!

Final thoughts:
-It is very form fitting. By this I mean slim and shrunken to fit the FLAT part of the screen. The Moto X Pure has very rounded/curved edges and any protector that tries to fit the screen entirely will have lifted edges where dust gets in and it doesn't look pretty. I've tried 3 other brand screen protectors and this one fits the best.
-I really like that the bottom enclosed the speaker. All others I have tried have an open bottom and I do not like that.

Recommendations:
I recommend this product for the Moto X Pure due to the curved screen and not many have fit well.
Take your time. You use your phone daily and will likely have this protector for a year or more. Take the extra 10min and slow down during installation.
My last recommendation is to keep an up to date and current secondary camera in the house. I am so used to my 21MP camera on my phone, I didn't realize how terrible my 12mp Olympus camera is. I apologize for the bad pics. :(

I hope this was helpful. I took the extra time trying to provide as much detail as possible since i recieved this for Free to provide an unbiased review for the community. I wouldn't want to steer anyone in the wrong direction because lets face it, our phones are as important to us as our cars. maybe even more.
summary: Best fitting Protector for Moto X Pure

reviewText:
Bastex Heavy Duty Slim Fit Hybrid Armor Premium Dual Shock Rubber Silicone Cover with Hard Protective Case for Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge (Black) arrived quickly and is a simple plastic bag. The case is well made and easily installed. We wiped down the phone and inserted the bottom edge into the case and then gave a slight twist to the case so the volume buttons edge slipped in. After that we simply applied a slight pressure to slip the top right corn in to the case an presto the S7 edge is now well protected. The case is a soft flexible rubber material and the outer back is textured dotted pattern that is a separate hard shell that goes over the soft rubber case. The texture adds a nice grip area so it is no where near as slippery as the original phone back. This case does add a little thickness to the phone but it is well received by everyone who holds the phone. We have come across a few who did not like the soft rubber top and bottom but most approved of this case. Great looking case with a lot of functionality which make this a nice looking case to complement your S7 edge. We found no issues with using the edge feature as the sides are recessed so they do not interfere with the screen edge. We are able to leave the case on while it is on our wireless charger which is a really big plus. Honestly this is a nice case for the price. The S7 edge is well protected in this case thanks to the soft rubber inside shell. I did feel the inner soft rubber portion of the case was a little too soft so I deducted 1 star.

Yes - I would recommend this product to anyone who needs a new or replacement case for the new Samsung S7 Edge.

Note: I received this product at a discount for an honest and unbiased review. (I will never compromise my honest opinion for a discount).

reviewText:
5 Stars Reason:
+ Invisible: Clean and clear cover without compromising any screen sensitivity or feedback.
+ Bumper Case Compatible: Covers just the flat surface of the screen and not the boarders. Ideal use with bumper cases.
+ Great Low Price: I nab this while it was on sale at a really low price. Extremely satisfied about every penny spent.
+ 3 + 1: Mine included 3 sheets of screen protector and 1 sheet extra as a promotional bonus.
+ Super Easy Installation Process: Although I did had to toss away the first one because a small piece of lint made its way to the sticky side and I couldn't get it off without leaving partial fingerprint.
+ Included Tools: Micro-fiber cloth, sticky tape for lint removal, scraper to push our air bubble.

Installation Tips:
1. Without removing any protective firm, place screen cover on phone and align to desire position matching the home button, receiver, and screen edge vertically.
2. Once aligned, pay close attention to the small gap between receiver and screen cover. REMEMBER the length of this gap.
3. Now. peel off PARTIALLY the protective firm on the sticky side (#1) starting from the receiver side (top), place it on the phone with the same gap length you remembered.
4. Using one hand, place the underside of pinky to hold screen cover in place (like trying to cover your phone to not let people see), using same hand, brush out any air bubble with the thumb. With the second hand, slowly peel downward removing the rest of the protective film. Continue pushing bubble out with thumb.
Note: If bubble cannot be removed, lift screen cover and reapply.

Overall, fantastic product. I ended applying 3 sheets over two iPhone 6, keeping one extra for replacement or if any of my friend needs it.
summary: Great Deal with Amazing Protection (Easy Application)

I have been using the iTorch as my sole means of charging a few separate devices since I received it. Namely, an iPod touch 5th Gen, a Verizon MiFi Jetpack, my Blackberry Curve, and an older iPod Touch (2nd Gen). The iTorch has delivered exactly what I was looking for in terms of allowing me to not have to find an outlet to recharge any of my devices. The capacity of the iTorch completely recharged my iPod 5th Gen twice, as well as recharging the older iPod Touch completely, and the iTorch still had some power remaining. This is more than adequete to get me through the day.

In terms of design and functionality, I find the physical dimensions and design to be very pleasant. It slips VERY easily into any pocket, and is less bulky than some of the other battery chargers I have.

The single-button implementation of enabling the various functions (battery on, laser pointer on, flashlight on), while efficient, takes a bit of getting used to. I'm the type of person who simply assumes that I can figure out how most things work without needing to read the manuals, and most of the time that's true. I had to check the manual in order to figure out how to turn the flashlight on, but that's not really a big deal, as once I learned how to do it, I haven't had to look at the manual again. Ultimately, though, the primary function of this device is to serve as a backup battery, and getting it to work in that regard is a no-brainer, and it works flawlessly for that.

Overall, I think the iTorch has a great physical design, more than adequate capacity for a single-user to get through the day, and the performance meets my expectations. The added bonus features of the flashlight and laser pointer may come in handy.
summary: Great charging companion with bonus features

reviewText:
GPEL's Battery Case for iPhone 6/6s is Apple Certified and is a wireless charging solution that uses Qi technology. If you are anything like me, halfway through your day, your phone is dying and you don't have your charger with you. I received the gold case, but ordinarily I would have gotten the silver one.  No matter though, the gold one is pretty sharp looking too. Using this MFi certified case with my iPhone 6/6s and then placing it on the Qi wireless charger (reviewed separately), you can wirelessly charge your phone quickly and easily.

This battery case is super thin and has an internal 590mAh Lithium-Polymer battery capacity providing additional talk time as well as surf, download and streaming time. The material around the edges has a high-quality feel and provides rubberized grip while also being lightweight and sturdy. The description also notes that the product is tear-resistant although I hope not to have to ever verify this. The case itself provides reliable protection from getting scratched up.

The company is pretty awesome too - I mean they give such a warranty you can't go wrong. They say if anyone has issues with any GPEL products, they will make it right.  All in all, this is a great battery case with an extra feature of wireless charging with the other product (reviewed separately). I give it a 4 star rating instead of 5, because I do not care for products that have the company logo plastered on them.

If you found my review helpful itd be great if you please click yes below. I am happy to leave reviews to help others make decisions prior to purchase and I enjoy reading your reviews to help me with mine. I have received this product without cost in exchange for my honest review. Thanks for reading.
summary: If you are anything like me, halfway through your day your battery is dead!

reviewText:
This product has been with me nearly every day since I received it.  I use it for my Samsung Galaxy S5, in a Tech Armor SlimProtect Case, and it fits just fine.  The clasp on the top doesn't close as easily due to the addition of the case.  However, due to the secure fit of the phone, that's not a concern for me.  It's great to have the slots in the back for my Driver's License and another card or small amount of cash.  I generally slide a debit card and $5-10 in there if I'm right around the local area.  If I'm going off away from home, I don't put much of anything in there due to the possibility of it being lost.  The slots are tight, making the chances of that very slim.  A slim chance is a chance, though, and I'd rather not risk it.

My only *almost* complaint with this is that the longer strap might have been 3-5 inches longer.  That would have made it easier to use as a cross-body bag.  I consider, though, that this is likely a product that was designed for younger persons (children and adolescents), and my older, larger frame isn't what it was designed for.  Therefore, I've made the best use of what's available to me.  I clip both straps together when I need the freedom a cross body bag offers, creating the perfect length.  Otherwise, there are zero complaints about this.  It's beautiful, the color is perfect, the size is just what it needs to be, and the straps are appropriate in proportion to the bag itself.

reviewText:
This thing is awesome.  Believe the reviews.  Unlike others who seem to have been given this product for an "unbiased" review,  bought it.  And I love it.  Charges my Note 5 really quickly.  It works through a Caseology bumper case without issues.  The lights are ambient, so they dim or go out if the lighting in the room goes down or out, and they are bright in well lit rooms.  I bought (and returned) another wireless charger and it made a whining noise.  This one is whisper quiet.  No noise.  It also seems to handle a full charge well.  Some wifi chargers either stop charging after the device reaches 100% causing you to get your device in the morning with 85% or so because they don't start again.  Others keep charging, even at 100% getting the device super hot and doing who knows what kind of damage.  This one gets mildly hot, but seems to stop charging at 100% and then, when the battery drains a little, it starts charging again.  Exactly like you'd want.

Build-wise, this is weighted, so it doesn't move around on it's own.  It has rubber pads for the same reason.  It looks nice and works perfectly.

My expectations were low for this device, even with the great reviews.  I was very pleasantly surprised.  If you're looking for a wireless fast charger, get this one.  It's cheap in price, but really well made an does what you'd expect.
summary: Great product! Better than I hoped for and super cheap.

I honestly get tired of all the ugly chargers and wires all over the house, and this charger even looks a bit artistic. These are much better than the ugly flat ones! reviewText:
There are, literally, hundreds of companies offering low-cost headsets ... both wired and Bluetooth. Most of them that I have tried have been adequate for casual listening to background music while exercising or doing other tasks. Only a few have been good enough (especially those of the Bluetooth type) to provide satisfying sound when I am just sitting around listening to music. I find myself both surprised and pleased to discover that this Magnetic Bluetooth set from Vic Tsing delivers sound that is, at least, on a par with wired sets costing 3-5 times as much. They are great.

The added feature of the magnetic ends which can be used both to hold the set securely around your neck when not in use or to control transitions from music listening to phone operations.

Designed to be compliant (and downwardly compatible) with Bluetooth's latest incarnation (4.1), the technology is high-end while the price is not.
Together with about 7 hours of listening time on a single (about 2 hour) charge, this set leaves little not to like. I did find the ear pieces a bit awkward as the design is uncommon in my experience, but after fooling around with them for a few minutes (and noticing that the R and L pieces are labeled) there was neither problem nor issue.

I am delighted to be able to offer this Bluetooth set a 5-Star recommendation. They are simply surprisingly outstanding!

After using for two weeks, it's still pretty stiff (although with time I'm sure it'll loosen up).

Didn't have a picture window like my last case but I love the design.
it took two full days to charge; and overheats with only a few minutes of phone use.

Solidly put together and seems very sturdy, especially if you use the holder that locks down with a screw clamp (included).  The bluetooth paired easily with my Galaxy S5 and if you want to use zoom, change the volume button control to "zoom."  Sections lock into place with a flip clamp and they operate easily.  This DOES include the GoPro mount.  If you remove the phone holder/GoPro clamp from it, it is a standard 1/4-20 mount that you could put most any standard camera on.  Holding a DSLR at length might be a bit heavy but using it as a monopod would work great.  There is also a 1/4-20 mount hole on the handle so you could mount this to a small tripod.  Overall, I'd say if you're looking for a selfie stick, this one will do the job very nicely.

So here is what you need to do if you buy this product for a Rezound:

1. If you look carefully you will see the the phone plug is not correct. However, it will still plug into your phone - just be careful.

2. The power plug for the MHL adaptor is an HTC Incredible compatible plug. Will NOT work with you Rezound power plug. Just go to walmart and buy the cord for the Incredible, about $10. The 110 volt wall plugs are all the same.

3. Plug in power and HDMI cable (15' one is $4.03 on Amazon, free shipping)

4. Change TV to HDMI input, soft reset your phone. Picture and sound should now be on your TV, "HDMI" should show up in upper left corner of phone screen.

If there is still either no picture or no sound on your TV, reboot your TV by turning it off (with phone on and everything connected) and back on. I had to do that to get sound.

Had my first experience of the Diztronic Flexible TPU Case when I bought one for my LG G2, and loved it so much, that I had to go back to one for the new iPhone 6+. It is extremely form fitting, yet provides a good amount of protection for your phone. Watched several videos online about drop tests before going with this case and was impressed with what the videos showed.

It is ironic that in today's world, smartphone manufacturers go to extreme lengths to make a phone slimmer, thinner and lighter, all to be undone by wrapping them in some bulky, ugly and oversized cases. My requirement for a good case was that it needed to be slim and light to complement the device it protects, while still offering it some protection and better grip should it accidentally slip out of my hand. The Diztronic Flexible TPU case does just that and does it well. While I wouldn't consider myself clumsy to where I drop phones on a regular basis, my previous phones have occasionally slipped out of my hand and dropped to the ground and this case did a remarkable job of protecting not only the phone, but the case itself showed little to no sign of any damage. I do have a ballistic glass screen protector on my iPhone 6+ and this case works well with it, leveraging the phone up just higher than the screen protector when laying it face down. Minimalistic, simple and effective. I would highly recommend it to anyone that is looking for a simple case without frills. If you're the person that constantly dunks your phone in the toilet or underwater, this may not be the case for you, but it will definitely protect it should it slip out of your hand onto the ground - even on solid concrete.
summary: Minimalistic, simple and effective! 2 Thumbs way up!!

I haven't used a phone case in years because I don't want my phone to be any larger than it already is, but this case is very slim and adds just a fraction of an inch to the phone's dimensions, so it still fits easily in my pants pocket.  I feel the phone is well protected from drops with the 2 layers of protection -- a soft rubber case that fits tightly on the phone and a hard plastic case outer case which snaps over the rubber case .  The Z2 Force already has a shatterproof screen, so the screen mainly just needs scratch protection and this is provided by the included screen protector. reviewText: Works fine, as expected. Could have a beep when you plug and unplug it.

[2015-01-03 - Update]
The two small circles originally noted (3/16 rings) as manufacturing defects have faded to no longer being very visible (have to strain just to see them).  I am assuming these marks were in the seal layer applied to the glass as when installed they were easily visible the first day, but after that they started fading and by the end of 2nd day were no longer visible.  Lesson learned:  if there is a blemish that is NOT dust, give it a day or two to see if will fade.

Additionally, iCarez csupport checked in to see how the product was working for me and when I discussed the issues I was having, they quickly started working with me a fast resolution.  Kuddos to iCarez.

Since installation I have noticed the protector lifts from the screen slightly when the power button or volume is pressed due to the case, but immediately reseals within seconds.  This is not an issue for me, but reminds me to be very careful when centering the protector.  There is such little room for error for the protector to be off-center with a case and if the protector is not perfectly aligned, the case could put some pressure on the side, as is my case.  Mine is only off by a fraction (1/32 at best), but enough.

[Original Post]
The protector is nice, but installation, dust control, and some spots on protector is of concern to be careful of.

In the past I have used screen protectors (film), but went without a screen protector on my S3 for several years without issue, even with phone in pockets.  With the 6P I thought I would try the glass protectors to see.  So far I am liking the glass MUCH better than film protectors.

So positive, I can barely tell protector is there (except for the raised edge cutouts around speakers).  Only a few blemishes and dust spots give it away.  It is also very smooth to the touch.

The bad...while the protector is very nice, with smooth clean edges, and near screen feel, the issue I have comes to dust on panel before I removed protected film off and several spots with the material and edges.  The dust itself was only a few spots, but very noticeable. Before installation I washed my hands twice, used a terry cloth to blot dry them, and ensured area was completely clean.  After cleaning the screen I started to take the film off on side that goes against the screen, only to notice before I got very far that there was some dust on the protector.  Quickly attempting to clean it I found the dust was between the film and the protector, meaning it was in place when manufacturing.  Removing the film I found several of the dust to be on the outside of protector (so no concern) and only one inside.  Sadly, after I got protector in place I found that 2 others I thought were not on protector WERE.  Once in place I could not lift side to get to dust and even with screen on, they were noticeable.

**no longer issue...see update above**  This brings me to the 2nd manufacturing issue:  there are 2 small spots/circles about 3/16 inch in diameter next to one another that are a flaw in the glass itself.  Maybe where machine/manufacturing was in play?  Again, with screen on, these were still visible.

Lastly, on bottom on both left and right corners (more on left) is almost a fingerprint looking impression.  This impression is not fingerprints, but a manufacturing texture.  It is in the area off screen, so doesn't affect that at least, but very visible against the black face of the phone.

Overall, I still like the protector, even with the several issues I noticed.

[Final thoughts...]
So would I buy the protector again?  Yes.  In today's high durable screens, a screen protector is becoming less needed, but for a new device that sometimes finds it's way into pockets with keys and my prior phone falling into dirt few months ago while working in yard (accidents DO happen...luckily no issue/scrach/dent happened), having extra protection just as a "just in case" isn't a bad idea.  If choice is for film protection, I would rather go without.  But with this glass protector, my view is changing back to liking a protector.

If someone was shopping would I recommend?  Yes, but with strong recommendation to check with manufacturer if you see any issues in screen or dust on screen prior to installation, but wait a few days first to see if it disappears.

reviewText:
I own four of these magnetic air vent phone mounts all from different brands. This one is one of the better ones of the bunch. THESE MAGNETIC AIR VENT MOUNTS ARE NOT ALL CREATED EQUAL! One of the other ones I have has much weaker magnets so when I go over a bump my phone (Moto X 2013) will either fall off or slowly slide off the mount. I haven't had any such problems with this particular mount. I wouldn't hesitate to pick up another one of these from Okra.

Pro tip: The prongs on the back of the mount have two different spacings to account for different air vent sizes so if you receive this mount and find that the mount just comes off the vent with your phone then rotate the mount and use the smaller prongs to grasp the vent.

reviewText: I LOVE THIS!!!

Caseology comes through again! I have never been disappointed by a Caseology case, and I've had several of them now (for different phones). I was concerned when I received this one for my Samsung s7 Edge because it looked like it left the curved edge glass  totally exposed, and it does to pointed objects. However, most phone injuries come from dropping them onto a flat surface. Concerned, though, that it wouldn't protect the phone from a fall on its side, I set the phone face down on a flat surface and shone a flashlight behind the phone onto the surface. The entire surface beneath the phone lit up, convincing me that if the phone face plants on a flat surface, the glass is not going to be hit. (I keep emphasizing on a flat surface as no phone case but one with a protective front shield, which loses the clarity of the wonderful HD screen and becomes cloudy and gets scratched very soon, not to mention how inconvenient it is to work around it.) The sides and back of the Caseology case are of a texture that the phone no longer feels like a bar of soap, eager to slip out of my hands and become damaged.

My only regret (a very small one) is that all of their cases for the Edge have gold trim while my phone is all silver (one of the three styles available from Verizon Wireless). I wish they had a case that had silver or other non-gold trim to perhaps look a little "chic"-er with my all silver phone.

(I'll update my review later if I experience anything to the contrary of its being a protective case.)
summary: Caseology does it again - great case for a good price!

The clip of this mount holds my Moto G2 very solidly.  Unlike some others I didn't have a problem with this mount falling off the windshield.  In fact it stuck very well.

Unfortunately, I found the arm to be too long and too wobbly.  I have a midsize sedan.  I positioned the phone in the lower middle of the windshield and then in the lower left corner.  I used phone GPS for testing.  In both cases the phone was too close to me.  So close that by focusing on the screen, I was completely losing sight of the road.  Not safe.  Additionally the long arm is wobbly, since roads in LA are far from perfect, the phone is constantly shaking making it even harder to concentrate on the screen.

I think that due to such long arm, the mount is more suitable for SUVs where windshields are farther from the driver.  Potentially, wobbliness can be mitigated by supporting the phone on the dash, but that may result in noises in the cockpit.  This mount is not for me.

Anker has several different cables:

Powerline Economy Cable, charges well, low price, rubber coated cable, cheap connectors.
Powerline II Entry-Level Cable, charges well, low price, rubber coated cable, upgraded connectors.
Powerline+ Mid-level Cable, charges well, average price, more durable cable with nylon over the rubber coat, more durable connectors.
Powerline+ II High-End Cable, charges fast, high price, Extremely Durable, Best Connectors at both ends of the cables.

I only use Anker Cables.  The Powerline cables I have all over my house, the cheaper cables are great for areas you'll just put your device down and let it charge.  I use the Powerline+ in areas where we actually like to play on the phone while it charges.  The neck on the powerline+ is more durable so if you're moving the phone a lot it should handle a lot of bending at the neck of the cable (I have had some of these cable fray at the neck so they are not impervious to bend/break like Apple cables)  Finally the powerline+ II  I only have a couple of the cables, I use them with my powerbanks beccause not only do they seem to charge faster, but they are more durable and when I'm charging with my powerbank I'm constantly moving, bending, pulling on the cable, have not had a problem with the Powerline+ II, just can't afford to upgrade all the cables in my house with this expensive line.

Love Anker Products. Anker stands by their products and replaces anything for free as long as it's under warranty (usualy 12-18 months depending on the product).  There is 1 thing I hate about Anker customer support, they are completely impersonal.  You'll read this grievance in my most of my recent reviews, I'll explain and let you decide for yourself if Anker Support could have, should have, treated me better.  Just bought multiple items as Christmas gifts for 16 family members (16 power banks, 16 lightning cables, 8 micro USB cables, 8 Wall Chargers, 5 Car Chargers)  Not only did I spend a lot of money but I gave Anker 16 new customers that are already purchasing more Anker products.  So when my personal 6ft Powerline+ lightning cable broke after a few months of minimal use (exposing the wire) I sent in my request for a new cable.  I explained how much I love Anker, how I just got my entire family Anker products and got Anker a bunch of new customers and I was surprised the cable broke so easily.  I asked if they could replace my cable with the 6ft Powerline+ II, figuring it may be more durable.  Their reply was surprising, they wanted to refund me for my cable so I could purchased the newer cable.  They did not offer a discount for the new cable, so essential they were not willing to give me the newer cable for free, it would have cost me a few more dollars and honestly I can't imagine it really costing Anker more than a few cents for the upgraded cable.  This is such a huge turn off, I'm the customer you want, not just a guy who buys a cable, but someone who buys many, many products from you, gives your products to all of my family members, and promotes your products to everyone... So many of my friends have also gotten Anker cables based on my recommendation. Highly disappointed in your customer service skills Anker, still love your products but I don't plan on promoting your products until you learn how to treat your GREAT CUSTOMERS BETTER.
summary: Great Product, Great Warranty, Horrible Customer Service

reviewText:
In the past I'd never think to review a charger dock.  It seems so simple, what is there to really say?
Well, my previous phone is an HTC Aria, and the dock I bought for it was awful.  I was shocked to learn about all the ways a product could be made badly.

That is why I am happy and specifically saying, this dock is great.  The fit I give a 9/10 - well above average, not perfect but in no way bad.  There's a slight discernible play sliding the device in which isn't problematic but sometimes noticeable.  This 9/10 may be a 10/10 for some people, because perhaps that millimeter of play gives you room for a case (don't hold your breath though).  I'm gonna get a slim case and update my review shortly.

Also sliding it into the dock and onto the micro USB is smooth and easy.  Bundled also are two cables thoughtfully labelled power and data - presumably because power cables are made with fewer wire connections (saves a penny I guess).  I could whine that it may not be two data cables, but instead I will praise them for delivering as advertised and going the extra mile and labeling the cables.  Well done.  Additionally a power transformer is bundled, looking very similar to the OEM one which ships with the Galaxy S II.

The rear battery slot is a bit of a snug fit, I'd like it a little looser so I could more easily drop the battery in there, but it's not a problem.  The rear LED changes color once the battery is dropped in and charging.

The overall finish of the part closely resembles the gloss black finish of your Galaxy S II (mine is an AT&T model, FYI).  I like it a lot.  I find the front red EVO logo to be out of proportion with everything else.  It is simultaneously subtle yet distracting.  Clearly not a deal breaker.

Lastly, the device doesn't interfere with data sync at all, unlike some other docking bays.  Sync occurs as naturally as it does with a direct USB connection.

This is the 4th battery case I've tested for my iPhone 6 and it is, bluntly, the best of the lot, easily. Trianium Atomic, ZVOLTZ, Unu and the Anker Slim are the others.

All of them extend battery life by 75-100%. All of them weigh about 3 ounces, except the ZVOLTZ (over 3.5 oz), all of them are well finished with all cutouts and ports fully aligned and easily accessible. All of them ship with mini-USB charging cables and headphone extension jacks. The Unu and ZVOLTZ cases have the same blue charge lights as the Ankers, so you'll know when the case is fully charged.

Where the Ankers differ is in how the case delivers juice to the phone. Most battery cases deliver a more or less constant charge to your phone. With the Anker design, when you press a button on the back of the case, you can see how much power remains in the case, and you also begin to charge the phone. As I wrote in my review of the Anker Slim battery case, Anker lets you be the boss of your phone.

While I liked all the cases, the Anker Slim was my favorite, so far. So with that background, you need to know that this new Extended Battery case is a little wider (1-2mm) and a little heavier (3.5 oz. vs the Slim's 2.9 oz.) than the Slim. However, it is only .2 oz heavier than the Unu and weighs about the same as the ZVoltz. The finish on the Extended case is a bit different, too. I previously described the Anker Slim as sueded, but now, comparing them side by side, would amend that to "matte", calling this Extended case "Sueded". It's even less shiny than the Slim, with zero sheen. The Slim has a slight sheen. Staying with the tactile, the sides on this Extended case feel a little less rounded than the sides on the slim. The transition from the back to the sides is definitely squared off, making room for the extra battery. It makes a subtle difference in the grip that i like. Both are comfortable hold, it's just personal preference.

Packaging on this case was typical Anker quality, we'll-constructed cardboard box with good directions for use and minimal waste. I won't go on about that, other than to write that I appreciate that Anker prints the instructions on the paper that wraps the box, saving a bit of paper. I like that.

Let's get to the nitty-gritty. I charged the case and my phone to 100%. 48 hours later my phone was at 19% power so I pushed the button on my Anker Extended case and gave it a jolt. It was soon back up to 100%. 48 hours later, my phone was back down to about 20% power. this is when all of the other cases, would no longer be much use to me. But with this Extended case, I was still showing quite a bit of charge on my case, so gave my phone another boost. It charged up to 87% power this time. This charge only gave me an extra 18 hours before my phone was in the red zone again, but I was using a lot of Safari when we were out to lunch. And then there's Bejeweled, too, one of my favorite time and power sucks, which saw heavy use yesterday. So while most of the other battery cases I've tried doubled my phone's power life, this Extended case increased it by about 130%. If my use had been fairly constant, I'd guess it would be closer to 170%.

As you see, I'm a light/casual user. During my test run, I always had open the following: Kindle, UnBlock Me, Paprika and Sudoku. Frequently open were Messages, Phone, My Fitness Pal, Fitbit and Weather. None of these are particularly battery intensive. Other apps that I close as soon as I'm done with them include Bejeweled, Safari, Maps and Passbook.

Bottom line, this is the perfect case for anyone, even power users, planning a weekend getaway. Imagine being 100% cordless while on a trip. With much more than double the life, this Anker Extended case makes that possible. And you still get to be the boss of your phone.

I got this case for a friend and wasn't sure what to expect. It was cheap, and I know sometimes you get what you pay for. I gave it to her and she loved it. The fit was perfect and surprisingly it does not feel cheap AT ALL!  It is very solid and durable. Color is purple but almost had a slight metallic hint to it on the phone. I highly recommend this case! Very happy with this purchase. :)

The Bad:

reviewText:
First off, I'm a lifelong Apple fan as far as computers go, but I'm certainly a convert from iPhone-- used the iPhone 4, 5, and the iPad Mini and replaced my iPhone with this when Sprint wanted to charge me $500 to buy a new iPhone 5S. As far as this product versus other Q10's, perhaps you're wondering about buying this versus the much more expensive black Q10 without the Arabic keyboard. They're identical-- except that this also comes with European/African power plugs, plus a flimsy but functional North American one (plus, who doesn't have a few extras lying around-- I sure do). So, that's convenient, and hopefully you won't be fazed by the documentation in UK English and Arabic ("learn about how to set up your favourite smartphone"). Next up, maybe you're wondering about buying this versus the BlackBerry Classic-- they're also basically the same phone. Same amount of RAM, same processor speed, same internal memory. The BlackBerry Classic has the old school buttons, which is fine, but not worth the extra $300 for me.

It's important to note that when you buy the Q10, you're not buying an iPhone 6-- you're buying a BlackBerry. All of the badmouthing of the BlackBerry brand ignores the fact that this is not a device that is designed for watching Netflix or playing glorious games (although . Most people I know who own iPhones don't watch Netflix on their iPhones, and most of them write e-mails on their laptops. Case in point.

Pros:

-Most apps work great, whether Kindle/Android or native BB. I've downloaded Groupon, Instagram, various photo apps, AirBnb, a banking app, Shazam, NY Times, Wikipedia, Amazon store, a couple of Twitter clients, and it comes with Evernote and a decent note-taking app that can do voice memos as well. I'm having some frustrations with Facebook (native), but it works ok.
-Size is convenient to hold in your hand, and the classic BB keyboard is great.
-Ability to take notes during calls, for when a customer service representative gives you that super important phone number.
-Durable. Feels more durable than any iPhone I've owned and comes with a free rubber+hardshell case.
-Great battery life. My iPhone will often die before 11am, and this powers through the day even with heavy use. Charging doesn't go so fast, but I guess you can't win 'em all.
-Call clarity is amazing and the speakerphone is super loud.
-Swipe-up equivalent of the home button becomes extremely comfortable fairly quickly. I was skeptical at first, having gotten used to the old school BlackBerry buttonry and even the iPhone home button, but it works great and hasn't failed me yet.
-Fast and not fazed by a multitude of apps and data.
-Expandable, cheap memory. Comes with 16GB built in and you can get 32GB on top of that for $15 on Amazon.
-Easy to customize notification settings and it's set up intuitively.
-Screen is great.
-When you close out of an app, you automatically see all of the open apps and therefore don't tie up valuable RAM running stuff you're not using (this was a peril on the iPhone).
-The Hub works alright. I was prepared to hate it, but it's pretty convenient, and it's easy to navigate around to adjust settings, add new accounts, delete accounts, etc. It's sort of like a glorified home screen.
-Transferring contacts was a breeze, and the OS actually automatically added a TON of stuff that I was glad I had-- notified me, for example, of a meeting I had coming up before I had even transferred anything over (I guess from an e-mail account).
-NFC stuff is easy to use.
-The Facebook app is imperfect but lets you conveniently use FB messenger inside the application instead of having to use a different application.
-Included HDMI port.

Cons:

-Special multi-touch gestures aren't quite as advanced as the iPhone, which I find myself lamenting probably a few times a week on random stuff.
-Included earbuds in headset are absoutely horrendous.
-Haven't figured out how to set up a good Podcast app.
-I haven't been able to get absolutely every app to work on this phone, but there are only two that I am going to have to "sideload," those being Uber and Yelp ("sideload" = meandering in command prompt slash developer nonsense slash upload download file conversion nonsense).  I think that's a product of BlackBerry having relied on the Amazon Kindle/Fire appstore instead of Google Play. As the fates would have it, the Google Play website doesn't really work very well on the phone's browser, so you're sort of sunk until you figure out how to sideload Android apps-- which isn't quite a piece of cake but also isn't the worst. It's much easier to download apps on the BlackBerry than it was on my old iPhone because I don't have to type in my password every time I download something, so it's easy to try out new apps-- and there are plenty. But really, how many calendar apps do you need?
-Notification LED, while fully customizable, is pretty weak and only illuminates on the front side as opposed to the linear LED on the Tour/Curve, which sort of sliced through the top of the device so you could see it in a holster or when it was lying flat. I really liked the Tour's function of the lock button an the mute button at the top-- they were hard plastic and easy to access. This has no such thing, just a lock button at the top. Which is fine, because you can easily swipe up to unlock and customize your lock settings (not to mention add hotkeys, which the iPhone lacks in any comparable way).
-Special function button is inconveniently placed between the volume rocker buttons, making it clumsy and easy to press accidentally or hard to press intentionally. On my Tour it was on the opposite side of the phone, making it great for pushing with your thumb while your index and middle fingers could access the volume buttons.
-Voice control kind of stinks, but then again, Siri ain't perfect neither. I find that it works okay for voice dictation, but it's very hard to ask your device, for example, where you can get a good meal in Grand Rapids. It's technically good, but not very smart.

Overall, I'm pretty satisfied. Not entirely perfect as far as the not-mainstream app situation is concerned, but that'll get better, and it's great to have a community of die-hard BB fans who are always willing to help on forums like CrackBerry.
summary: Affordable and fully-loaded alternative to the expensive flagship phones-- and every bit a BlackBerry

reviewText: This is my second Kenu Airframe. I bought one at Brookstone and I'm glad I found it on Amazon for a lower price and prime delivery. This little device works perfectly with the Galaxy S6 and the iPhone 6. I really enjoy how small and practical this is compared to the stands you put in the glass. It is less obvious and looks better in the car. I've used in a car with horizontal vents and in one with vertical. It fits well in both but I feel its better on the horizontal. In any case my phone is secure and ready to use. If you don't know, the difference between this one and the plus (+)  is the size. An iPhone 6 plus won't fit on this.

This just might be the best smartphone for $99 (subsidized) and if that's your budget read no further- go and buy it. However, if you're looking to switch from a high-end Android-powered phone or the iPhone, keep reading.

Summary-
Despite all its surface eye candy (Live tiles, etc), after playing with Lumia 900 for a couple of days I found WP7 to be underwhelming in the usability and customization department. Microsoft's own Skype can NOT run in the background (rendering it useless as an always-on Skype phone). Lack of multiple "home screens" make app navigation cumbersome, especially if you have a large number of apps. Small amount of storage (16GB) and lack of memory card slot. Not the best ergonomics and touch interface.

The review is divided into the following sections-

Hardware and Ergonomics
OS and Metro GUI
Music Streaming
Apps and Marketplace
Backgrounding and Multitasking
Ecosystem

HARDWARE and ERGONOMICS

Pros-
* FM Radio
* Dedicated "Back", Search and Camera buttons
* Standard Micro-USB port
* 4G LTE Support

Cons-
* Doesn't have a good grip (slippery)
* Display- very shiny/glossy, a fingerprint magnet
* Might be too large for one-handed operation (for those with smaller sized hands)
* Touch interface a tad sluggish/un-responsive
* Dedicated "hard" buttons aren't customizable
* Dedicated Search button isn't application- or context-sensitive (only Bing)
* The phone cannot be unlocked (as of the time of writing)
* Micro-USB port placement on top (not the best for car dashboard use)
* Only 16Gb or memory and no memory expansion slots
* Cannot be un-locked at present (even by ATT)

BOTTOM LINE- if you have large hands, you might like its ergonomics, given you get a nice rubberized case for it. For people with small hands it may not be as convenient. And if you're looking for a lot of storage this isn't the phone to get with only 16GB.

OS and METRO GUI

Pros-
* Live Tiles
* Windowing system with unified sliding bottom bar and common functions (Add, Remove, Select, etc) and horizontally "swipe-able" pages/screens across OS and apps
* Customizable (pin/unpin and re-arrange) Home Screen

Cons-
* Limited 2-screen interface (i.e. Home Screen and App list)
* Only one Home Screen (vs. multiple on Android or iOS)
* App list can get very long and difficult to navigate. Only navigation option is using alphabetical search by app name (implying you have to remember all your app names).
* Tiles on the App Screen are small and not very distinct/recognizable.
* No ability to logically group apps/tiles (not without third-party tools anyway)
* Only 11 accent colors and 2 backgrounds to chose from out of the box
* Only 3 brightness levels (low, medium, high)+ Auto
* Limited OS settings and info (for example- lack of WiFi network type/speed)
* Lack of advanced settings for OS and apps (for example- only five configurable settings for Internet Explorer, no privacy settings besides cookies on/off, etc)
* Toggles for WiFi, Bluetooth, etc are buried pretty deep. (fortunately there're third-party apps such as Toggle that bring them all to the Home Screen for ease of access.

BOTTOM LINE- if you're using more than a handful of apps, navigation on this phone becomes cumbersome. Very limited customization and configuration settings. This is not a phone for app "geeks" and certainly not for those who like to customize their phones.

Side note- it can be jailbroken, but since the Chevron project has been suspended, the only way is by having a developer-unlocked phone (AFAIK). So it really can't be easily jailbroken at present...

MUSIC STREAMING

Pros-
* Bluetooth A2DP for streaming
* Built-in FM radio (uses headphones as antenna)

Cons-
* No Airplay support
* Lack of native Pandora client

BOTTOM LINE- Bluetooth is the only wireless streaming option.

APPS AND MARKETPLACE

Pros-
* Unified expanding bottom bar with application-specific settings and the "swipe-able" horizontal tabs/screens
* Ability to "try" apps on the Marketplace before actually buying them

Cons-
* To "sideload" any other apps outside of MS Marketplace, the phone has to be jailbroken and as the Chevron project has been suspended, seems that the only way is by having a developer-unlocked phone.
* Some big omissions in the Marketplace (for example- Pandora, Google Voice, Talkatone, Citibank). There're some third-party equivalents though. Check first if your important apps are available for WP7.
* Microsoft's own Skype version for WP7 is very basic and way inferior to its iPhone counterpart (for example- the lack of "Online Contacts" list, only "All Contacts" and "Recent Contacts").
* Skype CANNOT run in the background (known issue). This means no incoming calls if Skype isn't in the foreground.

BOTTOM LINE- while app selection isn't all that extensive, you can try them before buying. Missing Pandora client and half-baked implementation of Skype are inexcusable.

BACKGROUNDING and MULTITASKING

Pros-
* Easy switching between backgrounded apps (by briefly holding Back button)

Cons-
* No ability to add/remove apps to be "backgrounded"
* Lack of configuration settings to change background task behavior.
* Some apps don't show up in Background Tasks list (e.g. TuneIn)
* Lack of indication (e.g. a badge) on the app's Live Tile that it's running in the background in the App List or the Home Screen
* Skype does not run in the background

BOTTOM LINE- Backgrounding on WP7 is very limited and not customizable with some glaring omissions, such as Skype.

ECOSYSTEM

I don't believe there's much ecosystem that evolved yet around this phone and WP7. There're only a handful of docks, speakers, and accessories made for this phone besides your general BT accessories.

BOTTOM LINE- if you're invested in an iPhone ecosystem, don't expect anything close to it with Lumia 900/WP7.

THE BOTTOM BOTTOM LINE- If you're in the market for a phone with good connectivity options (4G LTE) and a pretty GUI that is not iOS or Android, this is it. And with its $99 subsidized price it's probably the best smartphone ever ! However, if you're an app person/tinkerer/power user/jailbreaker- stay away from this phone.

I have to say that Belkin have really outdone themselves with this package, icorporating the best materiails and procedures I have seen, and with packaging you generally do not see on screen protectors (this looks more like an apple product). The proterctor is clear, strong and sensitive and adhesive good.  My one and only complaint (and where it lost a star) is in the  fit.  The prorttector is sqare while the watch has rounded corners.
