This is a high-quality cell phone cover that makes a sophisticated statement about its user. The black textured grid design with silver accents makes your cell phone look sharp and classy.

This hard case fits my iPhone 6S perfectly. It is easy to snap on and remove, but it holds tight. I like that it is felt-lined, so it won't scratch the finish on my phone.

The case comes in a good, solid box that protects the product in-transit. Whether handled by the US Postal Service, UPS or FedEx, it is going to arrive undamaged at your home. It comes with a 1-year warranty, and there is contact information (800 number and email) for customer support, should you need it.

My only complaints are that the case is not rubberized at all, so it is hard to grip (especially for smaller hands), and it is easy to drop your phone. I also don't like that the sides are not raised much past the face of the phone. This means there is a greater potential of your screen getting scratched when laid face-down on a hard surface than with other cases I have tried. Other than that, I think this case would make your cell phone reasonably safe and attractive.
summary: Classy-looking cover with nice features, but a bit hard to hang onto

reviewText:
Update on 5/8/2010:
-------------------
It's been a couple of months since I bought this phone. Finally, I've updated the firmware and some software, so I'd like to give a quick update / review on the new changes, because some of the things I mentioned before are no longer accurate.

- Firmware v40.2.005 is great. It's just a slight improvement but good nonetheless. One can update the firmware either through over-the-air (ie. 3G / WIFI) or from a PC. I'd prefer to use Nokia Ovi Suite on a PC to update the firmware because you can backup all your settings / contacts / data. Although updating the firmware is relatively safe, you'd want to do a backup just to be sure.

- Ovi Maps v3.03 is a nice improvement. The interface is about the same. The biggest change is you can download voice guidance that speak street names during navigation. With this update, it really depends on one's usage to think if this phone can replace a dedicated GPS unit. It's getting harder to say now.

- Nokia Email Messaging is Nokia's way of doing Push email. It works pretty well with GMail / Hotmail / Yahoo and I'd assume it works with other email service providers too. It basically syncs all the contents in each email accounts (up to 10). The updated client displays HTML contents which is a significant improvement.

Many new phones (especially Android phones) have come out in the last couple of months. I still think this phone still proposes excellent values with its price and features. Most of all, it's unlocked, and it can be used anywhere in the world, even without a SIM card.

The phone's user interface remains its Achilles' heel, however. As long as the user finds the phone hard to use, it really doesn't matter if the phone has the best price / features / performance in the market. Most users are using this phone to be more than just a phone. It's a smartphone because the phone is smart, not because it expects a smart user to use the phone.

Original Review:
----------------
I'll try to keep it short. I'll give the phone 5 stars without hesitiation. Others have provided very good (or bad reviews) of this phone, and mostly they are right-on. The key about this phone is you need to know why you want this phone, and how this phone suit your needs. Do not have an unreasonable expectation. The strength of this phone is its cost vs. feature proposition. In my opinion, there's simply not a phone out there that provides such a rich feature set while costs < $250.

If you want to buy an iphone (and pay ~$1000 total - $200 for the phone + $720 for 2-year data plan @ $30/month), don't buy this phone. Buy the iphone instead. This phone is not an iphone, not an iphone killer, and not an iphone replacement.

If you want to buy a Garmin GPS, don't buy this phone. Buy a Garmin GPS instead. This is not a GPS replacement.

If you want to buy a good quality digital camera, don't buy this phone. Buy a Canon or Nikon. This is not a digital camera replacement.

If you want to buy a FM radio, don't buy this phone. But who needs a FM radio anyways.

If you want to buy a music player, actually this phone's music feature is really nice.

With the above being said, buy this phone if you want an excellent phone AND want to do all of the above without carry all of the above gadgets at the same time. In particular you want:

- a phone that is unlocked, quad-band (international use), no contract, no $30 data-plan, no $10 GPS navigation plan and costs ~$250

- a phone that has strong signal, excellent call quality, and long battery life

- a phone that can play music/video/games, browse the internet, check email, take pictures/videos, provide GPS turn-by-turn drive and walk navigation (North America only) and maps service (global map is free download), provide VOIP video calls (using the 2nd camera in the front) over WIFI (fring and nimbuzz apps are free download) EVEN WITHOUT a sim card (excellent for travel)

Some tips while using this phone:

- the touch screen is a resisitive touch screen (unlike iphone's capacitive touch screen). Do not use your "finger tip" to control the touch screen. Use your "finger nail" or the included stylus instead. Personally I like "finger nail" much better. Once you get used to this, everything is a breeze. If your "finger nail" is as sharp (or unsharp) as the included stylus, it will not scratch the screen.

- the user interface takes a while to get used to. The iphone user inteface is more superb (and it's not even close, so I'll give credit where credit is due.) However, the Nokia 5800 features are excellent and there are plenty of supported (and unofficially supported) apps to download. No need to download itunes. No need to wait for Apple certified apps. Basically, you can download whatever you want and do whatever you want with this phone (e.g. use it as a USB storage device), and that's why it's not an iphone.

- speaking of iphone interface - there's a PAID (for money) app out there that you can buy and install iphone-like user interface onto your Nokia 5800. Get that app if you really need the iphone user interface. Just google "Nokia 5800 myphone app" and you will find the link and reviews.

- use the GPS without data plan (and do not get charged for data usage) by going to

settings -> phone -> app. settings -> positioning -> positioning methods and check only "Internal GPS".

The GPS without data plan may take up 5 mins (or more) to acquire a lock. The GPS signal is weaker than a dedicated GPS unit, and the voice navigation does not speak street names. That's why it's not a GPS replacement, but a GPS capable phone that you can use while a dedicated GPS unit is not available.

- browse the internet and check email using WIFI. Make sure you don't get charged for extra data usage by going to

settings -> connectivity -> destinations -> Internet (or MMS or WAP) -> "Your service provider" and make sure "use access point" is set to "after confirmation".

It's annoying that you will keep getting asked if you allow internet connection, but you'll get the peace of mind that you'll never accidentally connect to the cellular data network.

- visit Chinese (Traditional or Simplified) / Japanese / Korean websites by downloading "Opera Mobile with Asian Language Support" (not the regular Opera Mobile, not Opera Mini). Just google it and you will find the link.

- take pictures / videos while outdoor and with good lighting. Poor picture / videos quality is expected for any camera phone when taking them indoor with poor lighting. The phone flash does not help. That's why it's not a digital camera replacement, but a phone with camera that can use during social outings (e.g. Facebook Mobile upload).

Some nice to have (but not required) for this phone:

- get a data-plan if your service provider has a cheap alternative compared to the standard $30 smartphone data-plan. Being able to browse the internet and check email anywhere without WIFI is very convenient. Plus, the GPS / maps include additional features like traffic, weather, additional point-of-interests update that require a data-plan. More plus, with data-plan, you can turn on A-GPS (assisted GPS), which allows the GPS to acquire a lock in less than 30 seconds and to maintain a much stronger GPS signal throughout.

And most of all enjoy your phone while you are sitting somewhere nice, like a coffee shop. People, do everyone a favor - DO NOT USE YOUR PHONE (TALK OR TEXT) while driving.

Hope my review helps.
summary: Understand what you're buying with Nokia 5800

When it works, it's great! I live in a basement and have virtually no service. I rely on wi-fi calling, but with Time Warner, wi-fi is not very reliable and often drops calls when there is a blip in the signal. I needed to improve service so I gave this a shot (I bought it used so I didn't get directions). I tried placing the window unit at several different windows and the smaller unit in several different spots. The best I could get is a 7-8 signal, which is good. The problem is my phone doesn't always get the boost when I need it. Looking at my phone right now, I only have 2 bars, but if I move around a little (close to the smaller unit) I can usually get it up to 5 bars. The main issue is that if I get an incoming call when the signal is weak, I might not be able to get an improved signal even if I move around.

Overall, it was definitely worth it for me. I have MetroPCS and no service in the basement. I used to have verizon and never had a problem, but couldn't stand wasting money anymore. Now I have decent service and I couldn't be happier. Even if it doesn't boost it 100% of the time, it does boost it at least 85% of the time, which works for me. I've actually gotten into the habit of turning the wi-fi off, because it slows down the sending of messages and emails.

reviewText: Worked like a charm

This phone is replacing both an iPhone 6 Plus and a Note 4. I've used the Note 4 for most of the past year, and the 6Plus for over 4 months. Both have great features, great screens, but both are clearly overpriced for what they offer.

Here's a quick comparison between those two and the new Moto X Pure:

Screen:
Note 4 - average brightness, intense colors, sharp, over saturated, great viewing angles, deep blacks, but with terribly yellowed whites. Considered the 2nd best screen on the planet after the Note 5. But I greatly dislike it. Colors aren't real, reading black text against yellow white isn't pleasant. 518PPI.
iPhone 6 Plus - bright, clean, sharp, well balanced, great viewing angles, not so good blacks, TRUE whites. 441PPI. (BEST FOR ME)
Moto X Pure - bright, clean, sharp, well balanced, worst viewing angles, not so good blacks, less yellow than Note 4, but not as white as iPhone. 520 PPI. Aside from the viewing angles (not important for how we actually use a phone - by looking straight at it), it is a terrific screen.

Body:
Note 4 - ugly, fake leather, sharp edges, scratch magnet on the edges, capacitive buttons, protruding camera breaks EASILY, easy to  hold, body to screen ratio is good, perfect thickness. Ugly home button.
iPhone 6 Plus - ugly body, TOO THIN - doesn't feel substantial, slippery, protruding camera, large bezels on top and bottom, extra large phone for a smaller screen. Ugly home button.
Moto X Pure Edition - excellent screen to body ratio, easy to hold, a bit on the thicker side but it actually feels nice. On and volume buttons perfectly placed. No home button as the phone KNOWS when you approach it or pick it up to use it.

Battery:
Note 4 - 10-15 hours + extra battery - BEST
iPhone 6 Plus - 10-15 hours
Moto X Pure Edition - 6-10 hours

Operating System:
Note 4 - TouchWiz Android - Slow, laggy, obtrusive, filled with useless features, only gets worse the more you use the phone. Slow updates or NO updates from Samsung or Carrier. Terrible Support.
iPhone 6 Plus - iOS - Fast, responsive, always up to date, no lag, no slow downs, clean interface, unbeatable support! Great features by apple software.
Moto X Pure Edition - Pure Android - FAST, RESPONSIVE, always up to date, NO LAG, no slow downs, no slow down due to extended usage based on older models, support by Motorola isn't the best based on other reviews; if you buy it from best buy or Amazon and insure the device through them, it should be better. Great, useful features by Motorola Software.

Features:
Note 4 - Pen is phenomenal and works as advertised. Camera is one of the BEST in a smartphone, but it's slow to launch, sometimes taking up to 10 seconds, and you can't review the photo you just took because opening gallery will usually FREEZE the whole phone. Happens often enough! No manual controls. Remote control feature is great. MicroSD. Fast charging. NFC. Low volume output through the earphones.
iPhone 6 Plus - excellent camera. FAST, FAST, responsive, always there when you need it. No manual controls. Very slow charging. Excellent volume output and sound quality via headphones.
Moto X Pure Edition - excellent camera, FAST, responsive, can be launched FAST by twitching your arm twice. MicroSD. Fastest charging available. Excellent volume output and sound quality via headphones.

Overall:
Note 4 - SAY NO to Samsung. Until they make a phone with a decent, fast, reliable OS, don't buy it. It kills the experience. TOO EXPENSIVE.
iPhone 6 Plus - excellent phone. It does everything WELL. It is always responsive and reliable. TOO EXPENSIVE.

Moto X Pure Edition - Excellent phone. It does everything WELL. FANTASTIC Price. Right now, there's nothing that beats this phone for its price. Excellent screen, design, great camera, fantastic OS and software. I see no reason to ever pay over $400 for a phone again.
summary: Buying Something More Expensive Isn't Worth It

The Yubi Power 5200 mAh External Battery Charger is great. I've been using it for a week or so and have powered/charged my two Kindles, iPad3, iPhone4, Samsung camcorder and Sansa mp3 players. It will work with a large variety of devices that are able to be powered/charged via USB. The Yubi Power Bank comes with 4 tips and a short USB cable which the various tips plug in to. You are also able to use your device specific USB cable if you wish. The tips that are included are: psp, 30-pin Apple connector, mini-USB and micro-USB. The Power Bank is charged using a micro-USB connector that can be plugged in to a USB port of your computer or an AC-USB charger. Charging the Power Bank will be faster if it is charged using an AC-charger since the amperage will be higher. It is capable of being charged using up to 1A. The Power Bank also has a LED flashlight which is activated or turned off by a quick double-press of the on/off button. The double-press is a good feature as it prevents accidental flashlight activation. On a full-charge, the flashlight will operate roughly 250 hours. The Power Bank input is 5V DC at 0.5-1A Ourput is 5V DC, 1A maximum. The Power Bank offers protection against over charging, excessive voltage, excessive current and short circuit protection. A 6-month warranty rounds out this nice little battery pack. This is a very convenient, compact and useful battery pack. About the only feature I wish it had would be a complete auto-off function. As it is right now, you have to manually depress the on/off button for 3-seconds to completely power down the battery pack to eliminate battery drain when not in use. Other than that, it's great in every respect.
summary: Compact sized 5200 mAh battery charger is great

reviewText: I ordered this for my 14 year old daughter when she got a new phone. She loves it and gets a lot of compliments. It protects well, so far no cracks in the case or the phone. I like the smooth, matte finish it has. Very pretty.
Another home run for Spigen! This case is amazingly thin but yet feels like it will provide more than enough protection for my S7 Edge. Shout out to Floss for the recommendation!

First off I would like to say that I received this product as a free sample for review by uNu through their uTry program.  While I am glad I received this free, I would gladly pay for one if I ever lost this one.  I really can't say enough good things about this case.  For my birthday earlier this year my son gave me a Mophie charging case (in purple, the only thing I still love about that case) for my iPhone which I used, but soon regretting using.  It was bulky, a bit slippery, somewhat hard to take apart, and the worst part is that I had to fight with the case each time I wanted to sync with my computer (yes, I know I can sync wirelessly but I like to put my pictures into a file on my computer for backup and the easiest way is connecting it to my computer).  That was pretty much the deal breaker; when my son bought a different uNu model for his phone and told me he could sync to his computer with the case ON the jealousy set in.  I looked up uNu and on their website found out about the uTry program.

When I received the case, the first thing I noticed is the "Made for iPhone" label on the box.  It is packaged very nicely, and easy to take out.  After struggling to get my phone out of the Mophie case, putting it into this case was a dream.  It slid right into the back, and then the bumper was quite easy to attach.  I did have to go through and press various parts of the bumper to make sure everything clicked into place.  Once it was clicked together, it was hard to pry it apart again.  I was having some issued with the power button; I couldn't always get it to press properly.  After prying the case apart I noticed that the button on the case only has a piece on the outer part of the button.  If you press it on the inner part then it won't do anything, but if you press it on the outer part (close to the edge of the phone) then it will easily press the phone's button.

I love the blue of the lights in the back, though I did have to read the instructions to figure out how to get the case to start charging (you have to hold the button for a few seconds).  I was very surprised by how thin this case is; it almost feels like there's nothing on the phone even though I can tell it is a bit thick by looking at the camera cutout.  The rubbery texture also makes it easy to grip and you don't feel like the phone is going to slide out of your hand or off the table.  Being able to just place the phone down on the charging pad, without having to plug something into it, makes this case more than worthwhile.  The best part for me is that I can connect it to any micro USB cable on my computer and it automatically syncs!  I haven't dropped it yet and don't plan to (the Mophie did do well in that department in that when I dropped my phone the case had some dings and a crack but my phone was fine) so I can't attest to how well it does in that department.

Overall this is the best case I've ever had for a phone, and I've had many.  I was able to charge my phone to about 90% from a 10% charge, which is better than what I got with the Mophie.  The only negative thing I can think of with this case is that it does not come in purple (or any other colors), NOT a deal breaker.  If any issues come up I will be sure to edit my review.  Another thing I noticed with this case: when charging from the case the phone only gets mildly warm, as opposed to burning hot with the Mophie.  This case is well worth the cost!
summary: Hands down the best case for your phone!

I've been using an inexpensive no-name wallet case for my iPhone for years so I was eager to try out an OtterBox Wallet Case.

The case does easily fold around to make an easel for easy video viewing.

What they didn't get right:
Every cheaper case I've used has room for at least 3-4 cards, and the one I'm using now I can stuff in 5-6 in a pinch. News flash: I'm using this as a wallet replacement-- even a bare bones guy like me needs his driver's license and at least two credit cards and an ATM card. Also, the magnet to hold the case closed--- not strong enough in my opinion, it too easily opens with ordinary handling.  Overall, a disappointment considering it would not have been difficult at all to engineer it to hold more cards.

Received in good time exactly as described.
Haven't used the charger much, but I did finally get to do some testing.  Using this with a Galaxy Note 3, generic 1 amp battery pack, and Poweradd Compact Carmate3 400A Peak Current Car Jump Starter and 4000mAh Power Bank in Arizona.
I used the Ampere app to get an approximate idea of the charging output of the Aukey.
For the Note 3 when I charge my phone from a regular source (wall outlet, high output USB), the phone draws 1200 ma.  When I plug the phone into the Aukey under full sunlight, the app shows I'm getting a full 1200 ma charge.  So that works great for the phone.  The generic battery pack only needs a 500 ma input to charge and the Aukey charges it fully in a couple of hours.  The Poweradd Compact Carmate3 400A Peak Current Car Jump Starter and 4000mAh Power Bank uses a micro USB to charge and so only requires 500 ma input as well.  But it normally takes a long time even plugged into a wall socket and while the Aukey does charge it, I was finding that if direct sunlight is not maintained constantly then the charging fluctuation tends to really slow down the process.  Which means that the battery pack I would want to count on for the highest recharge of my electrical components might not actually charge fully before the last sunlight of the day.  I would get at least a partial charge.  So the Aukey for me in Arizona works great.  But it would be a good idea to be realistic about the time it's going to take to give a meaningful charge to more heavy duty battery packs.  It should work well with most high drain phones though.
The only reason I took off one star, was not quality or function, but mostly versatility.  I happily discovered I could get the full 1200 ma output even through house glass flat against the glass.  In many outdoor situations you can carry it on a pack and get full charging (given direct sunlight).  But it is also sometimes just as useful to be out and be able to have the solar panel on the dash charging whatever electronics from the inside where those items can be locked up.  For whatever reason the windshield glass will block full charging enough that it's just about worthless.  That's a very specific environment so I don't want to take away too much from how good the charger is, but at the same time that's a situation that would come up often that the user may want and it won't work.  The manufacturer does not advertise that the charger is UV dependent (which is what I'm assuming is the issue) so no fault there.  It's disappointing though.  That means that the in outdoor situations the charger is limited then to backpack only or you'll have to be in a position to watch it if worried about theft.
Otherwise the design of the device is nice.  The attachment points are many and tough.  The panels themselves are very sturdy and appear weather resistant.  I don't think that means much since the connector outlets and little storage mesh (for battery packs) definitely are not weather resistant.  You would not be able to leave this outside a tent in the rain (why would you?) because I'm sure the connector box would just fry with any water.
Also the mesh pocket in the back is a nice bonus great for carrying any battery pack and cables.  But in order for the charger to fold and store nicely, if you leave a battery pack in it, the battery pack will have to be small or very thin.  Otherwise a thick battery pack will give the folded panels quite a pronounced hump and be difficult to store.

I've been using wallet cases for years so let me be clear right up front: This one is awesome! I recently purchased a Sony Xperia Z3, and like I always do with my phones, I purchased a wallet case. I've reviewed a few others for the Samsung Galaxy SIII (my old phone) and one of those I loved and one of them I hated.

This one I love. It looks beeeeaaaauuutiful. Seriously, when I opened it up and popped my phone in, I was instantly satisfied. Yes, the leather isn't perfect but it fits the bill remarkably well. It looks professional and clean and keeps the profile slim just like the Xperia Z3. The magnetic clip that keeps the case closed is great and I can even bend the case back onto itself to stand the phone. It's great.

The hands down best feature here though is the system that holds your phone in place. Seriously, folks: What makes or breaks a wallet case is how the actual phone is held. I've had wallet cases that holds the phone cheaply, firmly, too firmly, flimsy, rough and loose and let me tell you, this one is perfect. What you want is the case to hold the phone but not make it impossible to remove but you also don't want the phone slip or slide out. This one lands smack in the middle and again, it's wonderful. I can easily remove my phone if need be and when it's in place, it feels stable and sturdy.

My one tiny, itty-bitty draw back is with the card holders. They are not stacked. What I mean is that the top most card (there are 3 slots) can slide all the way down to behind the first and lowest card holding slot. Which means you could have a card slip all the way down and be extremely difficult to retrieve. Now, I won't remove a star for this because the slots themselves are fairly snug. This means your cards shouldn't slip and slide too much. However, when that top card slides, and eventually it will, it could be something that absolutely infuriates you.

Regardless, this is still, hands down, a great purchase. I intend to buy the other colors as I'm sure I will beat this one to H and back.

I received one of these free in exchange for a review. SUMMARY: * If you want something compact, without messy cables, this is your unit. * If you want more flexibility, or to use your phone while plugged in to this, then it's probably not. THE GOOD: * Compact design * Very strong case * Responsive customer service THE BAD: * The first unit I received was defective (charged 15 seconds at a time). * The output cables are not replaceable, and are too short for pocket/hand use. * The lightning cable end too big for most iPhone cases. * Only 5000mAH, which is good for 2-3 charges of a modern phone. NARRATIVE: I received one of these for free from the manufacturer in exchange for writing a review. I'm writing second impressions now, but will travel with it for a while to see if my view changes. The box is easy to open without damaging, and is secure. Internal packaging is foam, to prevent damage in shipping. All of the printing is clear, proper English, though some of the wording is awkward for US or UK speakers. The device is a small brick with embedded output cables, one on each side, plus an input microUSB port. The built in output cables include one for lightning, and one for microUSB. The cables are not replaceable if they become damaged or are too short. It's rated at 3.7V and 5000mAh. That's overstating capacity a bit. Realistically, it contains two 18650 cells inside. That means 2200mAh, times 2 cells at 3.7V or 16.2Wh. That's 3 charges of an iPhone 5s if you turn off the phone while charging. It puts out 5V at 1A, so it'll keep up with a phone, but if you're using GPS, with the screen on, and playing music, then expect the Skiva 5000 to be drained by the time your phone gets a full charge from empty. If you're playing a really intense game, it might just hold your power even. The input cable is microUSB, and comes separately. The build is similar to an Apple brand cable, with just enough texture to not be slippy. There's strain relief on the USB side, but not the micro side. The built in micro-USB output cable end is very small, and should fit through any case. The built-in lightning cable has a very large end. I have to take the case off of any of my devices to make it work. It's the biggest cable end of any lightning cables I've ever seen. There is a loose, rubber bumper for the cable to dock into, implying there may be other options for the non-micro port in the future. If you plug in the input cable and output cable at the same time, it will wake up and pass-through power for the output cable while charging the Skiva battery. While charging, there are 4 blue lights on the top that will blink from "all" to "some" showing how far is left to charge. Power is not regulated, so when one LED goes on, some of the others go more dim. The angle and length of the output cables are such that you cannot pocket the charger and your phone while connected. The cable is also too short to set the PowerVault down, and pick up the phone. The casing of the device is curved, so it doesn't fit snugly against the back of a flat device for holding both at the same time. This is designed to be used on a desk or table while the phone is not in use. It might be okay in a purse or backpack, but not a pocket or your hand. The first unit I received failed to charge devices for more than 15 seconds at a time. A quick visit to their office near my house, and it was swapped out for a working unit. This was from a sealed box, not a cherry-picked unit, so I think the failed unit was just a random issue that was missed by QA. They noticed my review AND emailed me quickly about it with both suggestions, and an offer to swap out the faulty unit. That's promising, though it was their marketing director vs normal support. YMMV, but I have other Skiva products that work great, including ones I bought a few years ago, before they contacted me. The device arrived at half charge, which is a good thing for storage/longevity of LiIon batteries. There is a button that briefly powers up 0-4 blue LED lights to indicate current charge, then they turn off after 5 seconds. It's not my favorite unit, but it *IS* compact. See also the Skiva Powervault 10000, the Skiva Powervault 15000, or Bay Valley 10000mAh Power Bank.

reviewText: We purchased this phone with high hopes, but it failed to meet our standards.  The volume on the phone is very low, even when you have it turned up all of the way, and the phone is easily scratched and show through to the metal.  The screen is easily breakable and well as the camera.  I would not recommend.

I have tried several different 3D goggles at this point (i.e., cardboard, a metal version of the cardboard kind, these, plus two other pairs similar to these).  These Riversong VR goggles feature a smart design, they are comfortable, they accommodate a wider-than-normal range of devices, and are a very good value for their relatively low price point (currently about $25, although I got mine for free in return for a fair and honest review).  Overall, I can highly recommend them.

******************
*** PROS ***
******************

- Comfortable for many head sizes (comfortable + highly adjustable head strap, comfortable spongy material around the eyes)  Comfort is a main negative in reviews of other goggles, and it really matters, so these were a happy surprise in that respect.

- Not as heavy as come goggles (...which means that these are less likely to slip forward and/or to the side)

- Can fit more types / sizes of devices than most 3D goggle designs, with or without cases.  This model could fit my small iPod 5 and my 6.5" phone, both with and without their cases (although were less likely to jiggle around with the case on, which I prefer anyway, because it saves a step). My iPod case even has a belt clip attached to it, so it is extra thick; I could still pop in these and it clipped in securely.  Overall, it is an IMPRESSIVE DESIGN in terms of how it holds in all different kinds of devices, which can be important.

- The Riversong goggles have more blackout around the sides than most, which can matter a good deal when your device is smaller than the opening.  Your device will rarely be the exact same size as your goggles.  But the fact that the back of these goggles is pretty dark to start with (and even darker when you put in the black insert behind it) means that smaller devices do not end up with a bright, distracting rim around the outside of them in a bright space.

- There is room for headphones to be plugged in, with a hole in each side of the goggles (though if your headphone jack is not at one of the ends of your device, it might not work as well or at all.)  Better yet, use Bluetooth headphones.  Note that no headphones are included with this product; you have to use your own.

**********************************
*** UNABLE TO EVALUATE ***
**********************************

- The packaging makes it look like you can use these as 3D goggles in a movie theater, but I haven't had a chance to try that yet.

- I haven't used them for gaming (I usually use them watch short news clips and artistic videos via the New York Times VR app on my device)

**************
*** CONS ***
**************

- The instructions are better than some that come with similar devices (i.e., they have some, and they do say a few helpful things about adjustments), but they are still more limited than they need to be.  For example, how to use the black insert is not entirely clear.

- The adjustments for nearsightedness and 3D distance are there (which is important, do not get goggles without those), however, they aren't endless.  They are as good as any goggles I have seen so far, but (as with all goggles, it still takes me several minutes of watching to get the two images to merge into one.)

**************************************************************
*** FOOD FOR THOUGHT when buying any 3D goggles ***
**************************************************************

- It is important to understand that nearly all (all?) of the glasses/goggles at this price point are not connected to your your phone / iPod / etc.; instead, your phone just sits inside of these glasses/goggles.  Your phone/device runs the app, and you run your own earphones through your device, not through the goggles.  The goggles are basically just a comfortable "hat" and holder for your own technology, rather than providing any electronic functionality of their own.  So if you do not see your own particular device listed as being compatible with these googles, that really doesn't matter; just compare the size of your device with the devices listed, and if you are roughly in the same general ballpark, you should be fine.

- As I mentioned above, it happens to take my eyes a few minutes to adjust to all 3D goggles I have tried so far.  Despite how I adjust (any) VR goggles, I just keep seeing two images instead of one until my eyes and brain suddenly start communicating.  My optometrist has suggested that some people's eyes  are less adaptable to transitions, whether it is with reference to using progressive glasses, bifocal contacts, or 3D / VR devices, and he has politely implied that I am one of the non-adaptable kinds of people.  It can be kind of a hassle for me with VR as it currently stands, because most VR experiences (aside from video games) are pretty short; as such, once I get visually adapted, the film tends to be basically over.  And once I take it out and start a new video, I then have another (usually briefer) adaption period again.

All that is just to say that A) that isn't the fault of the goggles (though I do hold out hope that I might be able to try a fancier pair with more adjustments; I don't know if that would make a difference or not); B) you might want to temper your expectations that you will personally adapt to the technology quickly.

Either way, it is worth noting that I tend to adapt more quickly by looking way over my left and right shoulders, and back again, until I can get the two images to merge into one.

*********************
*** TIPS TO TRY ***
*********************

--- Try the NYT VR (New York Times Virtual Reality) app.  It has a few mind-blowingly cool short news & artistic VR videos on it.  Tons of fun!

--- Do not forget to turn around, look up to the sky, and look down at your feet.  That is what is totally amazing about VR, but it usually takes people a few minutes to figure out that you have all of those options.

VR is phenomenal technology that everyone should try in some way, whether it is with cardboard goggles, with these, or with a super fancy Occulus Rift!

*******************************
***  BOTTOM LINE  ***
*******************************

These are as good as any 3D goggles I have tried near this point point, and have much to recommend them.

I personally hold out hope that I will find a pair at some point that offers more adjustment options that might potentially allow me to adapt more quickly to the technology when I put them on. But because A) I do not think it is necessary for most people, and B) it isn't really reasonable to expect that level of technology at this modest price point, this is still a "5 star" level product that I can highly recommend.

=== Amazon Customer Review of a Free or Discounted Sample Product Provided for Reviewing Purposes ===
summary: OUTSTANDING, very comfortable 3D / VR goggles, at an impressively modest price

reviewText:
Most reviews of this phone are grounded, but a few seem to have higher expectations than maybe they should have for this type of device.  You're not talking about a $250 Verizon model or an iPhone here, folks.  It's a $29.95 (retail), plastic, BASIC, no-thrills, cell phone.  Frankly, it's amazing that for that price you can get something with a color LCD screen that actually gets cell receptions at all.  So my 4-star rating is based on the features and quality of this phone FOR THE PRICE.

I use Verizion as my main cell provider, but sometimes I like to sell things on Craig's List or Ebay and want to have a way for people to contact me if they have questions about something I'm selling.  I do not however, want to give them my main cell number.  So I got this Net10 phone for that specific purpose - as a more anonymous way of communicating with strangers who I don't know, who call to ask about products.  For that, it's great.

While plastic, overall the phone is pretty sturdy except perhaps for the upper battery door area with is somewhat "creeky" when you hold the camera and press in (it gives, slightly).  The buttons are small and yes, you can accidentally press two at one if you have sausage fingers, but a small amount of paying attention will solve this - it's not designed to be a hard-core "texting" phone, and for that, you should buy a phone with a full keyboard.  They do glow a pleasant Blue color when in use, by the way - another minor but amazing feature at this price. The LCD screen though lower resolution, works fine enough for what it is.  The reception is excellent, actually being better than my LG Dare when indoors.  The ear speaker is just a bit fuzzy, making folks sound like they're talking through a cloth - but still not super bad.  People I talk to say the microphone is great, and they can hear me clearly.  No camera, no 3D video games, no multi-phase transporter... sorry.... not for $29.95!

My only real complaint?  You use your minutes when you check voice mail.  Maybe I'm being cheap, but I figure if you're just calling in to check messages, they should charge a flat 5-cent or 10-cent rate for the entire call, and not a "per minute" charge for it.  So if you tend to ignore calls and let a lot of them to go voice mail, keep this in mind as just checking your messages frequently WILL use your minutes.

Ok, now, I do have to say that I would NOT use this or any cheap prepaid phone as a full time cell phone.  I'm one of those people who feel that cheap plastic and cell signals do equal radioactivity in your brain.  So I prefer to get something built substantially better if I'm going to talk for hours a month on it.  Likewise, if I had teens, I probably wouldn't want to fry their brains ahead of time by letting them use a device such as this as much as they do.  But for occasional use, and for people who don't LIVE on their cell phones (yes, those people still exist), I think this represents a great value for the price.
summary: Keywords:  "For The Price", and for that, it's great.

This is such a cute case with a cute design. I was so hopeful it would turn out well and was so relieved yet excited when it did. I am using this on my iphone 5s.

Inside the case is an embedded plastic enclosure you insert the phone into and it molds around the phone and holds it securely. That part works perfectly and I haven't had a problem. If anything, getting the phone OUT of that part of the case is a little difficult. That rubberized plastic case is very well secured to the outer shell, which is also hard and sturdy. That part is covered by the leather-like material with the print of the cute couple on both sides. There is a separate clasp which folds over the case and is magnetic. The magnet is strong yet easy to lift up. The back of this case folds outward (away from you) and can be propped up, which does work well if you like to watch things on your phone, and sets up well on both hard and soft surfaces. Once the case is opened there are some slots for cards, and a lot towards the spine for cash. The fabric creating these slots is also the leather-like material and stitched evenly and securely and lined with plastic on the inside of the material, making for a good place to stash a couple of things within the case.

The only drawback to this case is the sleep button on the iphone 5s, located in the upper right hand corner, is somewhat difficult to reach through the thickness of the inner case. This is a somewhat "girly" case, so in my head I imagine using your fingernail to hit the sleep button, but that's a bit of an annoying thing to have to do especially since I always sleep my phone in between flurries of texts with my husband. The alternative is using a pen. The indention in the case is fairly shallow but I am used to my old Lifeproof case, in which there is a responsive spring like mechanism covered by a layer of silicone so that, when in the case, the sleep button is raised up outside of the surface of the outer case. For me, that the sleep button is now indented is cause for some annoyance, because I'm used to just running my finger over it and tossing my phone back on the desk or bed.

Now, more than half them time, I find I never slept the phone or dimmer the screen, and since this case closes like a book, I don't know just by glancing at it, if the screen was dimmed correctly. So then I have to pick the phone back up, open the case, look for light, then slip my fingernail into the indention and "make sure." Since my phone is jailbroken, I installed a tweak that allows me to just swipe across the top of the screen to sleep it when I'm done with whatever, and bypass the sleep button completely. I can see this being an annoyance for some people though. For me, it's just a preference and since the indention is so slight, it's not a cause to pull a star off the review just because it's not what I personally prefer.

Other than that, I love the dandelions and the cute design. The artwork is right up my alley and is simple yet romantic. While I received a discount on the product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review, I actually like the case so much aside from the sleep button issue I will buy more cases from Shimu because overall the artwork, stitching, material and design are top-notch for the base price and the perfect design for me.
summary: Great Artwork, Secure Inner Shell, Perfect Level of Magnetism on Closure - My Favorite 5s Vanity Case!

reviewText:

reviewText:
I have a three year old that loves to play on my iPhone 6 plus.  The games she plays makes my battery drain fairly quickly. I decided I wanted to have a wall plug in the main rooms we are in so I can charge it quickly wherever we are.  We do not have a home phone so I need to be sure my phone has a charge if we need it in case of an emergency.  While I was searching to buy wall block chargers, I found out they make the multi port wall chargers. This is even better.  We often have family over and they are always asking to borrow a charger.  Now I have these in the living room and the kitchen.
I have found that to get the best use out of the wall chargers and the portable power banks (shorter cable will also be to use with my portable power bank) you must buy good cables.  If you buy a cheap cable from a company, the wall charger will not work as well.  I had this happen and thought the wall charger was not working.  I tried another cable and the wall charger was working fine.
This product is just the wall charger.  You will need to order more USB cables if you do not have extras to use with this.
I ordered more lightning cables as well as micro cables.  We have been using this wall charger to charge three iphones (two on the new cable and one on the old cable) and a kindle that uses a micro charger.  It has been working just fine to charge all four devices at one time.

I have had great success with this charger and would recommend it to others.
I received this product at a discount for my unbiased review.  I hope that my honest opinion was helpful. I only review products that I am interested in for myself and my family.

I think most of us that use these things have tried several. generally, i really like motorola, but my recent motorola bt ear bud died after 9 months of very light use so i thought i'd give plantronics a try. so far, so good: if feels solid (unlike my motorola commander one). standby battery life is great and the voice prompt that lets you know how much "talk time" you've got left is pretty accurate.
there is a slider on/off, volume control button and the answer/end call button.
my biggest pet peeve is the preset volume levels...there are only 3 available on the headset!?! with my samsung gs3, i can control the volume by increments, but the M165 only gives me 3 volume level options: 1, 5, max.

1. Sound quality is good (due to dual mic), but not quite as loud, clear and crisp as either of my motorola's (hx550, commandone).
2. Size and ergonomics are on par with the commandone. controls are simple and easy to use, and as far as bluetooth earbuds go, this one is very solid
3. Battery life is great for the size
4. Fit is fantastic, and the material they use for those in ear fit thingies are great: they really hold the earbud securely without any pain or excess pressure

I took off 1 star for the inability to step up/down the volume in the same increments as my phone. otherwise i'm pretty happy and as both my motorola's are dead, this is my 'goto' bluetooth ear piece.

One Month later...
Still working great, I really appreciate the quality of the materials that are used in the earbud, it still holds onto the headset very tightly.
summary: great value in a small bluetooth headset

reviewText:
This wallet/phone case caught my eye because it is used for both purposes. My wallet goes everywhere with me same as my phone just like most people. For me, I rotate between my purse and a diaper bag. It has always been easier to use a small clutch to hold my cards, money etc. My phones have never really fit so I always carried that separate which is why I am always misplacing it! With having both combined into one, I haven't lost it yet! During the work week I carry my wallet in my purse but in the evenings and weekends I am always with a diaper bag. The wallet is about 5.5 x 2.5 so I can throw it in the bag and be ready to go! With it being a phone case my phone is secure and not getting beat up like it usually does floating around in my purse or diaper bag.
This wallet has 9 card slots for all my important credit/debit cards, insurance cards, pictures etc. The card slots are nice because my cards actually fit and I don't struggle to pull cards/ID out of the slots. I am sure everyone has had that wallet that takes forever to pull your ID out simply because the slots are the exact size of the cards. With this wallet I haven't had any complaints there! I saw all the different colors, but I went with black. I like the feel and look of the leather like black. Perfect for going out when you're not using any type of purse/bag and the baby is not with you! The black looks dressy enough to go with anything you are wearing. Again, it is perfect because it is still small and you can take it with you just like a small hand purse or clutch.
At first, I wasn't sure if I liked that the phone was really on held by a magnet, but turns out to be a great feature. It is easily accessible to take pictures or to talk on the phone. You still can take pictures why it is in the case but it is simple to remove if you need too.
I will say it is nice having the card side vs the section where you phone is placed is separated and each side has a button so your cards are very secure. Nothing is falling out! I am used to having a zipper but the button has worked just fine.
I received this product at a discount in exchange for my personal, honest review.
excellent quality

Honestly, this is the best smart phone I've ever used. It does everything a blackberry normally does with all the usual efficiency. The camera is the fastest working camera I've ever used on any cell phone. The reception is better even than the 8700 which I loved.

While it does deserve five stars it has a few flaws:

Opening messages is a bit slower than older Blackberry's

For people who want to swap memory cards in and out often having to take the phone apart is a drawback, for the rest of us it doesn't matter.

No video capture (which I don't really miss).

Plus's

You can download files from some email accounts right to the device, as well as files from other places on the web.

It does most websites at very nearly the same level as a desktop.

When in iffy coverage area's it picks the network up faster than older models.

Tip:

Holding down the * key in your message folder and then releasing it after 2 seconds will take you to the oldest unread message.
summary: The best smart phone i've used.

reviewText: I'm very impressed with the phone. In fact I cannot believe how stable, fast and responsive the phone is. The only reason, I've bought the phone, is to try Windows 8.1 system. App store doesn't have much choices, but it won't be long before it expands as we've seen with app stores for both apple and android. The phone is an excellent choice for people just switching to smartphones or to experienced users as well. The phone does have its cons as well, such as low resolution display (not bad as someone may think); absent ambient light sensor and front facing camera; and low resolution rear camera. Those things don't bother me at all, but buyers need to consider those things before making their decision of buying the phone or looking for something else. I would rate myself as an experienced user and I'm very satisfied with all the phone is capable to do.

reviewText: Great product

I have a large family with a lot of cell phones, iPods, iPads, tablets, portable speakers, etc. Of course, none of these are any good to you if the battery is dead, right? I've used a number of portable battery packs and OXA includes some very nice features to go along with the expected functionality.

The OXA Juice Box S1 has a 7,800mAh capacity - which is enough to charge my iPad 2 completely or I can charge my cell phone phone several times or I can charge my phone and a friend or colleague can charge their phone at the same time. Because there are two USB OUT charging ports (one 1A and one 2A), you can charge two devices simultaneously.

The Juice Box is about the size of a deck of cards, but a little thicker. It's made of glossy black plastic and has chrome trim around the sides. The black plastic picks up fingerprints like crazy so if that bugs you, don't buy this. It has 4 blue LED lights underneath the power button which tell you roughly how much juice is left. FYI: The next gen Juice Box (the S2) has a somewhat larger battery capacity, a digital read out of the percentage of battery life left, and an extra mini USB tip, but features the same premium Samsung battery cells.

OXA also included a flashlight for getting your key in the door after dark, finding a pen in your purse, etc. It doesn't put out a lot of light but for tasks like I mentioned, it's fine. To turn the flashlight on and off, push the power button twice in quick succession.

The Juice Box S1 also comes with a USB charging cable which accepts multiple tips for charging different devices. Included are a mini USB tip, a micro USB tip, a 30-pin old style Apple tip and an 8-pin new style Apple lightning tip. Of course, you can also use your own USB charging cables with this battery pack. There is also a microfiber cleaning cloth, a lined velour carrying pouch and an unusable owner's manual (more on this later).

In testing this and a few other portable battery packs, I have been using it once daily for about a month, which is more than I might in normal usage. It has performed reliably in charging both my cell phone and two different tablets, along with Bluetooth speakers and headsets. I charged a different item on each battery pack every night - rotating through the various cell phones, tablets, speakers and hand held gaming systems I have in my house. I do notice that it is somewhat slower to charge than some other battery packs I have used, but it's not so much so that it is a problem.

My only big complaint is the owner's manual. This thing is unbelievably small with print that is so tiny, I couldn't read it. Personally, I find this ridiculous and I hope that OXA reads this and decides to remedy the problem. A folded-up Xerox copy in a readable size would be so much better than this tiny color manual. Save yourself some grief - enlarge and print this manual on your printer or at the local Kinko's if you want to use it. It's the only way you'll read it comfortably.

Fortunately, portable battery packs are all pretty similar so you can figure out how to use it without the manual. So despite the manual, this is a good buy on a solid battery pack. I give it 4.5 stars - I knocked off 1/2 a star for the pitiful manual.

NOTE: I was provided a sample for reviewing purposes but a positive review was neither promised or implied.

reviewText: I purchased a set of Aukey Micro USB Cables (White version) back in Nov 2015. Initial impression was very positive. The cables are significantly thicker than the other cables I own, such as those by Cable Matters and AIFFECT. See the comparison photo I uploaded. I assumed that must be due to the heavy-gauge wires used inside. In my testing, those cables worked well in charging all my USB devices, including Samsung Galaxy S5 and Amazon Fire tablet. Fast forward a few months later: most of those cables I used regularly have developed intermittent charging problems. At first I thought maybe the problem could be from the host devices. But after swapping multiple cables between multiple devices, I have to conclude that the problem is with those Aukey USB cables. I spliced open one bad cable in an attempt to identify the root cause. The wires inside were indeed heavy-gauge, and they were soldered correctly to the plug. The real problem is from the cheaply made micro-USB plugs. The electrical contacts inside appear to have become flattened and hence not making proper contact with the host device. In contrast, the thinner Cable Matters cables (here) purchased earlier in Sep 2015 are still working correctly. Same for the AIFFECT cables (here) purchased in Sep 2016. [Bottom Line] Looks can be misleading. Those Aukey USB cables appear to be thick and sturdy outside, but one by one they all failed within a few months of light use. I am thoroughly disappoint by this product and cannot recommend it. If you are looking for USB cable with better construction quality, get the AIFFECT High Speed Micro USB Cables instead.
summary: Cables looked sturdy, but micro-USB connectors failed within a few months

style.Size:: 5.7-Inch pouch iPhone 7 / SE / 6 / 5 & Galaxy S6 / S5 / S4

reviewText:
First I'll get some discrepancies and misconceptions out of the way.

The product info on Amazon states "Adjustable from 8.5  12.5 arm diameters".  The box shows 8.5" to 15".  So who knows what's more accurate.
Secondly, some people are saying the product doesn't fit their phone or phone with case.  The ClickGo Sports Running Armband comes in 3 sizes; 5.2 inch, 5.7 inch, 6.3 inch.  You should get a size larger than your phone.  I am testing the ClickGo with my 5.5" Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge and it fit...with a little space for the advertised "storage for key & card".  You will be storing any credit cards, cash and key(s) in the back of phone in the pouch.

Construction seems pretty good to me.  The armband features some material design on the side that contacts your skin, which I think aids in gripping your skin when sweaty.  The armband features 2 reflective strips, one on the armband and one at the zipper pull, I think very well designed because you can use the phone pouch as a separate case if need be.  You can separate the phone pouch from the band for ease of use.  And touchscreen responsiveness doesn't seem to be negatively affected in anyway, since I can still swipe on my Galaxy S7 Edge.

I have 18" muscular arms and can only really use the armband at the very bottom of my upper arm.  I would be unable to use this armband any higher than at the crux of my arm bend.

The ClickGo Sports Running Armband in the 5.7" size is perfect for our 5.5" phones and provides enough stretch for a slim case or other accessories.

Well, my phone fell off my bike (my fault for not securing the latch on my phone mount) and landed in the street. I was just hoping it didn't sustain any damage, but before i was able to get to it a van came down the road and ran right over the phone. Yup, nailed it dead on. Lo and behold, the protective screen was shattered. But that was it. Incredibly No other damage at all. For full disclosure, the phone also had a slimarmor case and was inside a bike mount case. But still, it was run over by a van and survived without a scratch.

The cracked protector was also really easy to remove. It stayed mostly in one piece, no glass shards. Obviously happy with it, I just installed a new one.

OMG!!!  If I could give this case 10 stars I would.  Who would think that military grade is really military grade in a consumer market.  So here is my testimonial that I witnessed myself firsthand.  My son has an iphone and he left it on the dash as we were headed out of town for a long weekend.  I had to stop for gas in Sarasota and we were in a bit of a hurry.  We were leaving the gas station at the intersection of Fruitville and Cattleman (see picture) and my son had rolled down the window.  As I was turning East to get back on Interstate 75, his cell phone slid out of the window into the middle of the intersection.  When I say in the middle of the intersection it was smack dab in the middle of the intersection.  I turned around to see if I could get back there before it was rolled over by a car but when I got back there, I realized that if I tried to walk out there I would be killed because it was so centered that at any one time, traffic was driving over that area.  It was rush hour traffic (around 5pm) and there was no break in the traffic.  From the picture you can see it was 6 lanes of traffic or more from any direction.  At this point, all I could see was the case getting rolled over and over by cars going in each direction.  It looked like Mexican jumping bean as trucks and cars of all sizes just rolled over it.  I decided to give up on it since I was in a hurry and because I was convinced that no phone could withstand a 2 to 5 ton rollover once if not more than once.  But I looked up the find iphone app and to my surprise it was still getting a signal.  I called the sheriff to help me hoping that they would arrive soon, but after seeing the sheriff drive by three times, and an hour passing by all I could see was hope flashing by.  The phone was rolled over and bounced from side to side at least 500 times if not more in the hour it took for the sheriff to come.  When they came and picked up the phone, they couldn't believe it that the phone was still working.  I expected the glass to be shattered and the phone severely scratched but when I took it out of the case, the phone was as good as new.  The case looked like it had gone thru a war zone, fully scratched, cracked and broken but the phone was unscathed!!  It was unbelievable.  I've attached photos of the case and the phone after the ordeal.  This case is big and bulky but it did exactly what it was supposed to do and it is worth every penny.  I realize people want skinny and small cases, and this case is big and bulky but I wouldn't use anything but this.  I am heartbroken that Otterbox discontinued this case but maybe they'll reconsider because this case is AMAZING!!  I saw firsthand what it did to protect my investment and it did exactly that.  This is a must buy if you are looking for something to really protect your investment.
summary: MILITARY GRADE AND WORTH EVERY PENNY!! Withstood the onslaught of traffic for over an hour!

So I've had the phone for three months now. One of the three months the screen was broke and I was using another phone, but I ended up fixing this one just because it was so awesome. Its still the amazing tank of a phone that it was before. I've grown to become ignorant to the lacking quality in the speakers and the signal is still "eh" but again I've grown used to it. reviewText:
The item has two components: a thin card inserted inside the phone, which is the receiver and equips the phone to receiver a wireless charge, and the black charging pad which is connected to a power source and should charge the phone when it is placed on it.  The instructions for the receiver were largely absent, but to the extent you could deduce something from the picture provided, they were wrong. Having never done this before I was not certain how the card should be placed and located. A Google inquiry revealed what in retrospect seemed obvious, that the two contacts on the receiver lined up with contacts above and to the left of the battery inside the S4.  The picture never pointed that out and suggested locating the receiver further down in the phone where it would not make proper contact.

In any event, once the receiver was properly installed, that part worked fine.  It did fit inside the phone without causing a problem for the back cover.  And if I placed the phone on my wife's charging pad (she has a Nexus 5), the phone charged fine.  So the receiver  clearly worked.  But the phone would not charge when placed on the charging pad in this package. The S4 displays a message when set on a charging pad, alerting you that you that it is now charging wirelessly.  Put the phone on my wife's pad, and it displays that message and then goes back to sleep and charges.  Place the phone on the pad supplied with this item, and it also displays the message--sometimes.  But even when it does, it keeps redisplaying it periodically, as if one were taking it off the pad and putting it back on, repeatedly.  For some reason, then, it apparently keeps losing and regaining wireless contact, never retaining it long enough to establish a charge.  Clearly, defective.

Some others may have received pads that functioned better; this might be a quality control problem and if you're luckier than me, you might get one that works.  It's also possible that some who found theirs did not work never got the receiver properly installed, given the poor directions.  In any event, all I know for sure is the one I got did not work properly, hence the single star.  I am returning it to Amazon, which as usual gave me no hassle in the return.
summary: Receiver worked but charging pad did not

reviewText: Screen protectors are just that, a screen protector.  How can you be above the competition?  i-Blason is. reviewText: I use this bluetooth headset with my personal cell phone (a Blackberry 8120) and my business cell phone (a Motorola v195s). I frequently participate in conference calls using the headset and battery life is quite sufficient and the voice quality seems to be adequate.  The only complaint I've received from callers is the noise they hear when I answer calls by extending the slide piece, so I just try to answer calls by pressing the button instead.  The volume and mute buttons are easily accessed and work well.  I use the headset without an over-the-ear piece, and although it tends to "droop" a bit during a call, the headset stays well enough in place that it causes no problems for me.  Since this is my first headset, I don't have much to compare to, but it works well for me and I'm not always easy to please.

I'm revising the review.  I love the case, but after a couple weeks of use, I have found that the magnets inside the clasp and case cause interference with the S-pen over time, leaving a "dead zone" where the magnet comes close to the screen.

By leaving the case open and the magnets away from the screen, I was able to recover the S-pen in the affected areas.  However, I have read that over longer exposure to strong magnets, the affected area can be permanently damaged such that the S-pen is unable to register (draw) in that area.  I have since cut the seams open on the clasp and case to remove the magnets.  I will glue on velcro patches on the clasp and case to get closure.

I'm disappointed that the magnets were too strong for the S-pen functionality.
summary: Only thing missing are speaker cutouts -- magnetic issues with S-Pen

reviewText: I bought this for my company use, which nobody said anythinn yet:)

I bought this phone directly from AT&T when the next generation was released and got a great deal.  This is by far my favorite phone ever and I've been using it for years.  I did have the boot loop issue early on, which was very discouraging, however sending it in for a warrantied fix did the trick and I've not had a related issue since.

What I LOVE:
* CAMERA: It's better than many 2017/18 Android phones and when it was first released, it rivaled the iPhone at the time.
* VOLUME/POWER BUTTONS (on back): Although it took some getting used to, I love the placement of these buttons.  I find I am less likely to push them by accident.
* BATTERY: It's replaceable so you can have a spare for emergencies or just replace it when the one you have becomes "not so great".

What I DON'T love:
* OS: No updates after 6.0 without doing it manually
* VOLUME BUTTONS (on back): When using it in the holder in my car the buttons are covered in such a way that I can barely reach the volume up and definitely cannot reach the volume down.  However the holder also covers the sides of the phone, so if the volume buttons were in the typical location I would be unable to reach them too.
* BATTERY LIFE is just "OK": If I just use it for voice/text and minimal data (like browsing FB), it will last about one day.  However if I tried to play games on it all evening, as I once did, it would have to be charged several times a day.  I bought a replacement battery recently and that has really helped since I'd had the other so long.

reviewText:
This is an excellent case if you want to add a reasonable amount of protection and "grip" to an iPhone 5/5S.  It fits snuggly, has a slight lip to protect the screen, is easy to take on and off, and has plugs to cover the headphone and lightening jacks, which is nice.  It's not perfect:  the volume and sleep buttons seem slightly misaligned (but still work fine), and the volume buttons are a bit stiff. Over time I've migrated from heavy duty cases (Otterbox Defender) to highly protective cases (Candyshell) to just simple (Pixelskin HD), and this is a very nice case for the price.  I can't speak for the included screen protector; I use the Spigen Ultra Crystal, which is great.

The criticisms I've read about this case is that it is not grit/dust proof, and once you get grit inside the case, it can scratch the phone itself.  My view is that if that's your concern, get a lifepoof or Otterbox (which now has the same problem because of the TouchID cutout).  I doubt any TPU-based cover is dustproof.

reviewText: This is the first glass screen protector I have used that covers the entire front of the Note 4. It does this by extending the class past the curved part of the Note 4 screen giving the elusion of a flat screen. In my testing there is not a halo ring around the edge of the screen protector that many other screen protectors have.
I did like the concept but the stand broked the second day. It was not really an aluminum but more a cheap plastic. Although the design is great, the materials like the stand is poor quality.

I have been looking for a new brand of screen protector to use on my electronics. I have encountered many products that seem to be good but come off easily, are a pain to install, poor fits, and a variety of other issues.

I prepped the screen as instructed and followed the application instructions.  Super easy to follow and the screen went on just as advertised.  So far it does not appear as if it will come off easily (as many other brands I have tried did).  I am interested to see how these screens hold up.  I have installed them on 10 different electronic devices within my home and family.  They will be exposed to occasional use and heavy use.  They do not have a glare and have not given any problems with the touch screen sensitivity.

Overall I am super happy with the product so far.  If they peel off easily or I notice any other issues I will be sure to return and modify the review to reflect these issues.  As it stands right now these are actually much better than I ever expected them to be, especially for the advertised price.  So far I like these just as much, if not more, than the Invisashields I have used religiously in the past.

I am also a huge fan of the lifetime guarantee this company offers.  I will definitely be buying these in the future for my family and friends to use on their electronic devices.

I did receive the first several protectors as part of a review program.  Thank you to a fantastic company!
summary: I have encountered many products that seem to be good but come off easily

reviewText: Dropped my phone many times and never had any damage with this case.  It does get scratched up like any aluminum case.

This is a versatile charger for those that have a type C charging port. There is some controversy with type C cables overheating and causing fires. Thus far, no fires with this CeeOne cable :)

I own a number of CeeOne products, and they are all very high quality. You can get cables anywhere for $1, but to get something reliable, you have to spend a bit more. In my experiences with CeeOne, I wouldn't hesitate to spend the money on their cables.

This one has a 12V car charger attached to a type C charging port. It has a 2.4A USB port on the back of the charger to charge any other device you'd like. I use it to charge my Samsung Galaxy, and it's considered "quick charging". It literally charges the phone 50% in 30 minutes, which is pretty remarkable.

The cable end is high quality, unlike some other cables I've used that loosen over time. Overall, if you have a type C charging port, this is a fantastic car charger to use.

Note: I received this product at a discount in exchange for an honest, unbiased review. I have no affiliation with this company whatsoever.
summary: Great charger if you have a type C port

If you are in the market for a sleek, nice, and reliable portable charger, the FOXNOV 5000mAh is a good one to look at it. I acquired this charger at a reduced rate for review. I could not be happier. It is very stylish. It is of 4.7 x 2.6 x 0.3 inches. It is almost the same size as my iPhone. I carry it in my front shirt pocket. This is how portable it is.
Functionally, it contains 5000mAh of power -- enough to provide two charges to an iPhone 6s or one charge to a Galaxy S7; smart and fastest charge with speed up to 2.1A. I used it to charge my iPhone 6, my wife Samsung, my daughters iPad, and various other devices without any issues.
The additional feature that I like is the superior safety of the device. It is considered to be safer than ordinary Li-ion cell, Lithium-ion Polymer cell adds extra protection for you. The cell that the FOXNOV device uses is also adopted by Anker portable chargers.
In summary, I highly recommend this charger. I would say it is ideal for a quick charge or emergency. I would only recommend it to be around 10,000mAh instead as this level appears to be the standard these days. It would last longer and would be more appropriate for me who is a business traveler.

I depend very heavily on reviews that are posted on Amazon. I also read what reviewers on Amazon have to say. I want to help others by providing my reviews that detail the product as well as the experience I have with the products that I get on Amazon. I received this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. The review above is my honest opinion. I am not obligated to leave a positive review for this product. I rank each product with 1-5 star rating, below you will find what I personally feel each star represents when I am review a product. I take my reviews serious and will only provide my true feedback.
1 star = Hate the product- will return
2 star = Strongly Dislike the product- will never purchase again
3 star = Indifferent- Neither like or dislike the product
4 star = Like product
5 star = LOVE the product

I hope you find my review helpful in your decision to purchase or not purchase this product.

I am a long time Plantronics user and Voyager user, I have probably purchased 6 over the years.  I am also hard on them, so they usually last about 2 years with me.  I had been eyeing this 5200 for a long time, but bypassed it a couple of purchases.  When my last Voyager broke, I bought an off brand that was much cheaper, because it had lots of good reviews.  I am not saying the reviews were lying, but it just wasn't as good, it didn't sound as good, didn't feel as good.

So, now I decide it is time to spend the big money and buy the 5200.  I was hoping for a few things, an even better fit than before, some extra benefit with BT 4.0, and better sound clarity and noise reduction.

What I received was:  The fit just isn't as comfortable, I can't seem to get it to stay on my ear.  The battery life seems to be less, I thought the BT 4.0 would extend some battery life.  And I can't seem to keep it connected.  It goes back and forth, connecting and disconnecting all day.  I'm hesitant to answer sometimes as I am not sure if I am connected or not.  I can't really tell if it sounds better or not.

So I paid a $35 more for a lessor product.
summary: So I paid a $35 more for a lessor product.

Original Review: Before I got this case I was using the AmazonBasics Protective TPU Case with Screen Protector for iPhone 5 (Frost) which was nice and sleek but quickly became discolored and did not provide much protection. Since I spent quite a bit on my phone I thought it best to protect it a little bit better. I purchased two of these cases, the blue for my husband and the blush for myself, and so far we are both very pleased with them. Pros: *Great protection against drops. *Easy access to buttons. Easy to push buttons. *Makes phone easier to hold on to. *Comes with built-in screen protector, no more annoying stick-ons! *Reasonably priced. Cons: *The blush is very bright pink. It looked lighter in the picture online, and the hard plastic part looked white online. It's actually gray. The blue case was pretty true to color. *Our audio cables for the car did not work with the OtterBox. They were too thick to fit the inner case. We ended up purchasing two of these Mediabridge 3.5mm Male To 3.5mm Male Stereo Audio Cable - 8 Feet - Step Down Design accommodates iPhone, iTouch, SmartPhone and MP3 cases cables to accommodate. Now we can use with our MP3 input jacks in the car. *These cases do make the phone bulky. *The rubber part does attract a bit of purse and pocket lint, but it's not terrible and it comes off easily. After using these for a day we have decided they are keepers. Update 4-18-13 The case fit loose from the start (the outside rubber part) which I did not notice at first. My husband's case is nice and tight. This got so annoying after awhile that I took the case off and got a different brand. Also, the screen protector over time proved to be horrible, both with attracting smudges and scratches, and it is so large that it's hard to fit it in my pocket.

For you science geeks out there, this is a great example of the Inverse Square Rule. For you non-science non-geeks out there, the thicker your case, the harder it is to find a sweet spot. My case is 1/8" (~3.5mm) thick, and my Nokia DT-900 Wireless Charging Plate - Retail Packaging - White would not charge it with my phone in its case. If I placed it bare on the charging pad, then it worked fine, but who wants to pry a phone out of the case every night to charge it? In my case, switching Qi pads worked. I ended up Wireless Charger, PLESON Qi Wireless Charging Dock Station Wireless Charging Pad for Samsung S6/Edge/Plus, Note 5, Nexus 4/5/6/7, Nokia Lumia, LG /G4/G3, HTC 8X / Droid DNA and All Qi-Enabled Devices and it worked fine. The key difference is that I suspect the PLESON charger requiires a USB charger with 2A output. The Nokia isn't powered by a standard USB charger, so I can't be sure, but once I swapped Qi pads, it works great.
summary: Ever Hear of the Inverse Square Rule?
