*Disclosure: I was contacted by Yubi Power and given a sample of this product specifically for the purpose of reviewing it.* Test devices: Google Nexus 7 Asus Transformer TF-101 Kindle Fire HD 7" HTC One Samsung Galaxy Nexus HTC EVO 4G LTE Up until recently, I'd been using a Scosche Dual USB Car Charger or a Satechi Soundfly View with a splitter for charging up the usual devices I carry about. This is typically my phone and one or more tablets, though more than once I've had a friend along that was in need. The 500mA output on the Scosche isn't great, not giving much of a charge during my 45min-1.5hr commute, especially if was using one of the devices during the trip. The Soundfly was a bit better, but still only half what I could get from an AC outlet and charger. And then comes the Yubi Power unit. The construction is solid, and it has a red LED ring along the outer edge to let you know that it's connected to power. The red doesn't go with my blue interior lighting, but oh well. Overall, it looks good and the low profile keeps it from sticking out like a sore thumb. On to the testing. Out of the gate, the Asus Transformer was not impressed with the Yubi. The Yubi isn't the first of charger my Transformer refuses to play well with, so I wasn't surprised. Likely this is due to the Yubi being wired up to match Apple's charging method while the Transformer has it's own ideas. My guess will be that a Samsung Galaxy Tab will having similar issues, as it too is known not to work with Apple's setup. Outside of that device, everything else worked great, both in single an dual charging setups. I used a 2A wall charger to compare the charge rate on each device, then repeated with the Yubi. As expected, the difference in rate was nil. Things got interesting when I started comparing in dual charging mode. What should happen, according to the secs and details on the Yubi, is that each device should charge at half the rate of a single device (2A/2 devices = 1A per device, or, 10W/2 devices = 5W per device). What I found however is that in all dual charging scenarios, the devices charged at the same rate as when they were charged by themselves. To verify that they would charge slower if not given 2A, I tested each with a 1A charger and the Scosche adapater. Sure enough, there was a significantly lower rate of charge. So, what does this mean? The biggest thing is that the Yubi I got was able to charge two devices, at the same time, and at the same rate as if they were plugged into a wall charger. That's huge for me. I don't know if I got an extra special unit from Yubi, or if this is the norm, but it was sealed in retail packaging, and I'm quite happy with my new adapter.

First off, I will say that I received this product SUPER fast so I am happy with the seller! I have seen my share of phone cases, and there are some that I love but they are higher priced. What I am trying to do is keep in mind the price of this iPhone 6S Tempered Glass Screen Protector, TeckNet Premium Tempered Glass Screen Protector For Apple iPhone 6S and iPhone 6 with 9H Hardness and 96% Transparency
 in terms of the quality/value compared with the pricepoint. At this pricepoint, this is an awesome deal. I got another one for my iPhone, and this one for the anti-apple person in my house. I love when products have nice packages. To me, this means that the manufacturer or seller is proud of their product. I usually get my screen protectors from the mall, where they charge anywhere from 15-60 bucks depending on if it is made of plastic, glass, or that crazy bull-proof and drop-a-hammer-on-my-phone-proof stuff. I usually settle for the 15 or 20 buck ones, and I have realized that it's so expensive just because they charge for "labor" AKA 10 minutes of putting a screen protector on my phone and squeezing the air bubbles out with a library card. I decided to try it on my own. I don't have the patience for it so I had my girlfriend do it for me. It was easy enough to install and great that it came with all the tools-of-the-trade. It's a lot thicker than the typical plastic screen protectors, making feel like it's more protected. If you have the patience to install this by yourself to save a few bucks, then this is the screen protector for you. It is easy enough to apply yourself, seeing as each step and sticker is labeled for you. It comes with all the tools of the trade.

Packinging=A+
Ease of installation=A+
Coverage=A+
Price=A+
Does it protect my screen?=A+

I really have zero complaints for this pack! It feels durable, was easy to install, and fits perfectly. What more could you ask for?

I received this product at a promotional price for my honest review.
summary: Nice thick screen protector for a lower price than the mall!

I absolutely love this adapter; I honestly think its something all phones and mobile devices should come with nowadays because its such a smart little device.

Extremely straightforward to use, just simply plug in your iPhone Lightning cable and then plug the adapter into your phone, then you're good to go. Ive tried out a cable one before that was magnetic like this, but this simple adapter is so much better of an idea in my opinion, because all I have to do is keep the magnetic tip plugged into my iPhone at all times and I can simply throw the little adapter piece in my pocket so that I can always use it no matter where I go, no matter whos Lightning cable I borrow if Im visiting somewhere, and I don't have to worry about lugging around a special cable to use, I can just use any cable I want.

The idea of having it magnetic has two awesome benefits as far as I see it; the most obvious one is that touted by the Magsafe cable Apple uses on its Macbooks, that if you ever trip over the wire if safely breaks away without pulling your device down with it and crashing into the floor (and this adapter works exactly as youd expect in that regard). But also the other added benefit is that if you keep the tip always installed in your iPhone like I mentioned I do, then all you ever have to do to plug it in is hold the cable with the adapter nearby to your phone and it will quickly just plug itself in with a satisfying snap using the magnetism. And by the way, I also love keeping the tip installed because I always have my iPhone in my pocket, and the charging port collects way more lint than you think (seriously, next time you have a pin or toothpick swipe around in there, youll pull out a TON of dust), and so keeping the tip installed means I never get any dust, lint, or dirt if I drop it falling into the port (now if only they made something like this for the headphone jack).

I did receive this product at a discounted cost in exchange for an honest review, but I was not compensated or instructed to leave a positive review; the opinion stated is that of my own. I hope my details provided illustrate that I honestly enjoy this product and take pride in helping with an accurate, unbiased review.
summary: Neat Little Adapter; It Was Exactly What I Hoped!

reviewText:
I do not recommend this kit.  The replacement screen is very poor quality and cracked within 24 hours.  The precut Pro-Adhesive does not fit well and the included tools are very poor quality.
Amazon was very gracious and credited my account and I ordered this screen: Original Samsung Galaxy S3 SIII Pebble Blue Front Glass Replacement - D&R electronix
It is much better quality and fits the S3 like the original.  I also used the thin 3M dual sided adhesive tape.  This combination worked out quite well.
Make sure you have the right tools to tackle this job.  I used a Porter Cable variable speed heat gun and an IR Temp gun.  You need to get the original screen heated to 160-175 degrees F and slowly separate the screen starting in one corner.  If you go over 200 degrees it will cook the digitizer.  Do not pry upward on the glass as it will in turn put pressure on the digitizer and damage it.  I used a safety razor blade to get it started.  The guitar pick from the $12.00 ProKit just melted.  Watch the You Tube videos and take your time and the phone will look as good as new.
Best of luck!
summary: I do not recommend this ProKit

reviewText:
Because I carry what you would call a tactical backpack with me almost everywhere I go, this Case was a nice fit to go with my day bag. The Case comes in 4 different colors, I chose the Army green because it fits me better. You can also get the case in black, tan, and the older BDU camo pattern.

The build Quality of the pouch is very nice, all the stitching is tight and straight. There are quite a lot of thread ends that could have been cut off, or burned down, but those are easy to take care of. The outside of the pouch seems to be made out of the same materials as the old Military Molle gear, but can still be used with current Army OD green gear, and it would look just like a piece of issued gear.  All of the Fasteners seem to be very well attached to the Case. The inside of the Case is made of a softer Nylon material so that it should not scratch your phone. The pouch comes with a Aluminium locking Carabiner that can be attached to the D-ring on the top of the pouch if you want it to hang from your bag, or attach it to the strap of a messenger bag. The Clasp on the front that keeps the top flap secured sees to be made of a good Hard plastic and has a nice design that makes it easy to open and close

The pocket area of the pouch is a good size, My note 5 with a Slim case will fit in the pocket with a little extra wiggle room, but this in no way would allow the phone to come out of the pouch, a friend of mine has a note 5 in a life proof type case and his phone fit in the pocket very snuggley.

The straps on the back of the pouch can be set up in a few different configurations, so that it can be attached to a variety of belts,  bags, and other gear. All you have to do is use the slots on the back of the pouch slip the straps through the slots and it changes the length of the belt loop to stay secured to your side.

Couple problems arise with this pouch, first if you are looking for a pouch that is waterproof this would not be for you, as the pouch is open on both sides at the top and bottom, so it will not keep your phone from getting wet, so if you're like me and only have a slim case on your phone it will not stop the rain. Second problem would be if you use wired headphones for hands free calling or to listen to music, This case would not work for you, as there is no way to have wired headphones plugged into any phone that has the headphone jack on either the top or bottom of the phone (which is wear most headphone jacks are located). So for purposes of hands free operation without a  Bluetooth device would be difficult. I personally use a combination of Bluetooth and wired listening options as I cant always have one or the other all the time. So for me at work I would not be able to carry my phone on my belt with this Pouch as I would not be able to use my wired earphones.

Overall this pouch has a very durable and rugged design and works great for my phone, for a tactical phone pouch it will work great as it will be attached to the strap of my backpack so that I can have my phone near enough that I will hear it when it goes off.  I would recommend this Pouch to anyone that spends a lot of time doing outdoor activities like Hiking or Camping as it is a great way to carry your phone without having it in your pocket or in a clip on belt case that has a chance of coming unclipped and possible damaging the phone.

I received this product for free or at a discounted price.
summary: Great Tactical Pouch for larger Phones

To start... I've had the opportunity to review MANY many many many of these types of tempered screen protectors now. I'm generally in love with them, but when it comes down to these reviews I'm splitting hairs a bit. Many of my reviews will sound similar, but note that I'm basically using a rubric to rate these.

So this item from TECKNET is very very nice. I'm digging the 2.5D aspect of many of these (compared to the eBay ones). These are tapered a bit at the edges such that, hopefully, if you hit it wrong on the edge it is much less likely to break. That said, hitting glass, of any sort, on the edge is going to be the easiest way to break it. The protector has a few other things going for it... for one, 3 for 6 bucks is unheard of cheap... very nice to have.  It also has a cutout for the front camera... which is actually hard to find in these things.

Now, I won't know for a while whether or not this particular protector holds up better or worse than others... and frankly I'm not expecting it to last forever...

To be perfectly honest... I do have a hard time telling most of these apart. Thickness and the beveled edges tend to be the defining factors. If it works, it'll work, and if you hit it, it'll probably break at some point... for most of them that is.

This all being said, tempered glass is absolutely the way to go. If you haven't tried them, these basically look like the screen of your phone, basically respond the same, and will take the bulk of the damage if you hit it wrong etc., and crack before your screen does. I've used these for the last few years and generally, up until recently, grabbed cheap ones from eBay. Also, tempered in general tends to go on bubble free! total bonus!

I received this item at a discounted price for a fair and unbiased review. I was not otherwise compensated. Additionally, I do take these reviews seriously. I do take into consideration price at the time of the review and if I think something is overpriced I do dock them for that, or note it where necessary. If a product is BAD, I do not hesitate to give it 1 star.
summary: Very very good for the price.

reviewText:
Most if not all screen protectors are purposely made slightly smaller than the screen, why? Because it allows slightly misaligned screen protector. Not this one, you have to be perfectly align other wise it will not fit. This can be a good thing if you have superb installation skills. So most people will just have to realign over and over again and introduce dusts along the way and you will have to remove partially and realign again and more dusts. So you see where this is going now.

But the good part of this CitiGeeks screen protectors are they include dust removal sticker and touch up tape which is a great addition. Normally I would just use a scotch tape, but for some reason, the screen protector on the lower part of the screen is almost impossible to remove once it's installed if you see any dusts. So their touch up tape are better than scotch tape, as they are more sticky but I still need to let it sit on the screen for a few minutes to get the adhesive to bond with the screen protector other wise the touch up tape will not left the screen protector either.

My recommendation to CitiGeeks is cut the screen protector slightly smaller and this will be a 5 Star product.
summary: The Screen Protector is Exact Match of The Screen - Bad Thing!!

reviewText: This case feels and looks amazing, it has a nice smooth yet grippy texture. As seen elsewhere, it is very flexible and rubbery, not a hard case by any means. From a style perspective, it's sleek and all kinds of purdy. From a protection perspective, I can't imagine this stopping anything more than moderate daily bumps and pocket use. Coming from a Unicorn Beetle on my old LG3 to this and a OnePlus Two, it's like the difference between an armored up Colossus and a spandex-clad Deadpool. Definitely going to need a tempered glass screen protector to balance things out a bit. If your hands are constantly emitting grease or your mutant power is clumsiness, you might want something tougher. If you want sleek and moderately effective, this baby kills on that front.
summary: Do you need Colossus or do you want Deadpool?

reviewText: Love it

In February, I purchased two Motorola T325 Wireless Bluetooth Car Speaker Portable Vehicle Visor Mount with Auto Pairing For All Cell Phones and Smartphones- BLACK- Non-Retail Packaging. for my wife's and my vehicles and gave those units a 5-star review. I requested a review unit of this T225 because the limitation of our T325 per-vehicle solution has been that if my wife and I swap cars, we don't have hands-free calling unless the first person out remembers to also swap the speakerphone units. This T225 speakerphone pairs with multiple cell phones so that more than one person can use it hands-free. The extra people might be in the vehicle (which would be a little weird, as the microphone would typically be on the driver's sun visor). But, in a multi-driver household, any driver would have hands-free operation. What's not to like? Well, all of the features of the T325 that this speakerphone does not have which make the T325 more "hands-free" than the T225. This is a very basic, 'dumb' unit. When a phone rings, it announces that the call is for Phone 1, Phone 2, etc. If two paired phones are in the car, you have to have some idea which phone is 1 or 2 (etc) to know if it is your phone that is ringing or someone else's. Doesn't sound like a huge deal, but... What about when only one of multiple paired phones is in the car? This phone simply rings and says that there is an incoming call. You have no idea who it is from. The T325 announces the caller by name. If you don't want to answer the call on this T225, you have to somehow press both the volume UP and DOWN buttons at the same time. With the T325, you just press a single button. How about dialing? Both support voice dialing using your phones own voice-dialing feature. So, the intelligence depends on your phone itself. But, what about calling your 'favorites' or frequently called numbers? The T225 offers nothing. The T325 memorizes a list of favorite contacts and easily lets you scroll through the list with one button, listening to the name being announced and then pressing the dial button when the name comes up. Entering the car, the T325 announces "Connected to John Smith's iPhone. Battery level is high" (e.g.) - while the T225 announces "Connected to Phone 1. Battery level is high." Receiving a call, the T325 announces "Call from David Jackson". The T225 announces "Call for Phone 1". The T225 is so limited - its only real feature is the ability to pair with multiple phones - that I just cannot recommend it, when I consider how powerful and useful the T325 is. I've posted a photo showing both the T225 and T325 clipped to the sun visor to compare their sizes/shapes.
summary: Could have been great, but limited feature set

reviewText:
Bought a new phone, bought a new holster.  The description said it would work for a Galaxy NOTE 5 smartphone even with a thin case.  I have a clear, thin case on my [very expensive] phone in order to protect it.  The case is just thick enough to protect the camera from touching the floor / ground, and so too the screen.  While I can get my phone into and out of this holster WITH EFFORT, I would prefer if I could just slide my NOTE 5 into and out of it.

I believe the listing also said '... for the NOTE IV and  NOTE 5.'  These two don't have quite the same dimensions, and I suspect this holster was designed for the NOTE IV, thus explaining the awkward fit for the NOTE 5.  (Couldn't this manufacturer just make another holster, even if it meant raising the retail price 50 cents?)

While the tight fit is tolerable, the clasp, which should offer some flexibility in order to slide it over a belt, has been more like an 'immovable object', making it difficult to put on, and worrisome that it might damage my nice leather belts (as happened with my last holster, but only after extensive use - see below).

From what I saw when I went looking on Amazon, and with the two holsters I purchased (I promptly returned one to Amazon and wish I had done the same with this one) I got the impression that a goodly number of companies just thought they'd make a quick buck with an inexpensive product, perhaps even thinking that at such a minimal cost most disappointed customers wouldn't bother to return the item?

P.S.  A couple years ago or so, I purchased a similar style holster for my NOTE II.  I used it for over 2 years with that phone (and have used it satisfactorily, if a little loosely, with my NOTE 5, as well.  However . . .  My NOTE II slid easily into and out of that holster, with the magnetic closure providing the protection it was designed for - even when I went jogging.  In addition, the clasp provided a small amount of flexion, enough to make it relatively easy to slide the holster onto my belt.  (Sadly, over the 2 years, with the rubbing of the leather covering of the clasp against my belt(s), it wore thin; and then the rough edges of the underlying metal began scratching my belts.)
summary: Not really for the NOTE 5, and what's with the rather tight clasp?

reviewText: Great fit and quality.  My daughter removed the plastic front cover because it had a rainbow glare, but everything else is great.

::Background::
I've been searching for a case that is thin and at the same time protects my phone.  Most of the ones I've bought were a bit bulky and I didn't like the "feel", and style.  Finally, I found one.

::Product::
It came in a plastic container.  The color is matte black and the texture is smooth.  Not much padding but I like the slim look; I hope it protects my phone.  Just slide your phone in and you are done!

::Shipping::
Came a day early.

::Overall::
I like it. The real test is when I do accidentally drop my phone.
this protective cover is a must. I really wish I would have bought this case sooner, you can not go wrong going with zerolemon on their protective cases, great quality and great price as well
NICE!
I'm switching the batteries at least once a day, my daughters games kill my batteries really fast.

Yeah, I am asking you to take my word that this is one of the best cases you can buy for your Galaxy S3 if you are looking for something low-profile that won't add much bulk to your beautifully thin phone, and, will enable better grip when you grab the phone from your pocket.

I poured over case reviews for about a week before settling on the Seidio Surface Case.  I picked this case because I had also bought the Samsung GS3 Multimedia dock and I wanted a case that would enable me to fit the phone into the dock without removing it.  A YouTube video I watched verified that this case would be perfect with the dock.  When I received the case I was delighted to see the fit was perfect.

The case comes in two halves, a top and bottom piece that slide into the appropriate ends of the phone rear.  Once the two halves are locked, you can be assured they are secured.  In fact, it's quite difficult to remove the casing (though not impossible) once locked.

The case provides a nice lip around the front of the phone that should help protect the screen if it falls straight down.  The back of the phone is entirely protected, and it has a nice slightly "rubbery" feel that gives the hand a better grip on the phone.  I like the way the phone easily slips in and out of the pocket.

This is a quality case, and as I noted in my review title, the one that you will most want to consider for your Galaxy 3.  When I move up to the Note 2 in November, I am hoping surface cases will be made available for that phone.

Good luck in your hunt for the perfect case.  Consider this one a candidate.
summary: You want this case for your Galaxy

I have had good luch with zerolemon batteries... I was tired of switching batteries midday however so I thought I'd try this "superbattery"

Unlike other extended batteries which are basically 2 batteries together, putting a big bump in the back of your phone, this is one long battery attached to the normal size battery with a bigger smooth case.

In the time that I used this, I never loved the thicker case...which is substantial...but I got used to it.  If everything else was good, I'd be satisfied.  But it wasn't.

1.  Like others have said, it definitely interfered with my phone signal.  Areas where service was sketchy in the past were now definitely places where my call would drop.  Other areas that were formerly ok were now areas where I lost reception.

2. I didn't get the huge boost in longevity I thought I would get.  It should be nearly 3 times a normal battery... but I still found myself out of juice by the end of the day.  This meant I needed another battery in my pocket which defeats the purpose.  Also, this battery was very hard to get in ...which isn't a problem if I didn't have to change it out.  I expected at least 2 days on this battery.  Getting less than one wasn't acceptable.

During the use of this battery, my S3 bricked.  I don't think it was related to the battery necessarily.. but the phone is dead.  I didn't drop it.. I didn't root it...  so it makes me a little leary.
summary: Extends battery life but there is a cost.... and the benefits are not as expected

reviewText:
Summary: Perfect fit, durable, "grippy", nice Android pattern.

Cons: The case in person is more translucent than I expected. I was hoping for a dark grey, and it's more of a lighter grey. Not really a big deal, but something to be aware of if you're picky about the color being an exact match to the photo.

Pros: I've had the case for a couple of weeks now, and it's not showing any scuffs or marks. Looks as good as the day it arrived. Now, I'm not stupid enough to keep it in my pocket with keys and loose change (It amazes me that so MANY people do!), but I'm not particularly careful of it otherwise. It gets tossed onto the desk. Knocked off of the desk onto the concrete floor by the cats. Tossed onto various pieces of furniture and knocked off the night stand. So far so good.

The fit and finish are pretty much perfect. Snug, but not too tight to get on and off easily, not so lose that it'll fall off on it's own. Buttons are easy to locate and push (they're exposed, not covered) No visible seams or marks from the mold. The Android logo looks very nice and because it's "indented" slightly adds some grippyness to the case.

The teenager I sold my phone too chose to use this case over the Poetic Slim case, liking the extra protection and grippyness. He also liked having the Android pattern rather than the plain Poetic black.

Nicely made and fits very snug. It has a great design that almost gives a 3D look to it. My only criticism is the case has holes to put a wrist strap on it. Not a feature I would use so now the case has hole on the back that are not necessary.

reviewText: Own Iphones or other fast charging devices then this is for you. Charges my family's Iphones in less than an hour from 0%-100%. Great for travelling.

I've had good experience with iSmooth products in the past, so I opted to buy 2 of these cables based solely on the advertising claims. I have two genuine Samsung S4 chargers that charge my S4 phones at a minimum of 1200 ma with the cables from Samsung. When I use the iSmooth cables I can only get 700 ma charge maximum and consequently my phones take an unacceptably long time to charge.

Also, both cables fit poorly in the phone. They don't seem to grip at all and they become unplugged from the phones very easily. The original Samsung USB cable seems to gently latch into the phone and hold securely in place. This iSmooth cable does not.

While I was willing to put up with the loose connection which was evident from the start, it took me a few weeks to realize that the charging performance was so poor. I thought I had bad batteries. It turns out it was just the cables. When I replaced these cables with the original Samsung cables the charging performance was back to normal.

It's too bad because these feel like quality cables and have the same look and feel as the Samsung cables. Their performance is too poor to justify their cost.

These might work fine with other phones, but if you have an S4, you might want to heed my story.

Update:
Amazon refunded my payment based on my complaint to the marketplace seller. No hassle involved at all. I didn't have to return the cables but I threw them into the recycle bin. They work poorly and I don't want them around to get mixed with my good cables.
summary: Poor charging with Samsung Galaxy S4

I bought this light a few months ago, along with a comparable Eddie Bauer lantern and a no-brand lantern.  Hurricane Sandy rolled through this week, and we had our first real test of the lanterns when the power went out (and stayed out).  The Eddie Bauer lantern was not as bright and lasted only about an hour before going dim.  The no-brand lantern lasted a bit longer but was very difficult to use -- it wasn't configured to put the light where needed.  Our d.lights, on the other hand, performed flawlessly.  We used both the area lantern (the d.light S10) and also this task light (d.light S1).  The area lantern (the S10) kept large (15x30 foot) living spaces lit well enough to work (preparing dinner, etc.).  And the task light (S1) was fantastic for reading, doing paperwork, etc.  All of the d.light lanterns lasted from sundown to bed time at full brightness -- the S10 lanterns were on the whole time (about 6 hours), while the S1 task lights were used intermittently (probably 3-4 hours).  Both the S10 and the S1 are designed for functionality -- the area lantern is very easy to hang, and the S1 task light puts light right where you need it.  Last but not least, they recharged the next day with only partial sunlight and were ready to go for a second night.

Long and the short of it:  D.light lanterns are awesome!  Hands down, these are the best power outage lanterns available, and at a great price.  I just placed an order for a few more.  These are far more valuable than battery-eating flashlights when facing a sustained power outage.

05-Nov-2012:  Important Note.  If you're looking for a whole-room lantern, as opposed to a task, light, you'll probably want to get the d.light S10.  The S1 (this product) is a task light, for reading, etc.  Both are great products -- just designed for slightly different uses.
summary: The light that beat Hurricane Sandy

The front of the case sits higher than the screen, even with a tempered glass scren protector on it, so the case will hit instead of the screen if it is dropped on a flat surface.  The corners have some kind of different cushion to them to help protect those as well.  I tend to drop my phone regularly, although I haven't so much since I upgraded a year ago to the 6s Plus from a 5s (the 5s had a death wish, but it never succeeded despite regular attempts.). I only ever had a thin plastic case with a tempered screen on the 5s. Although the 6s Plus is a larger heavier phone I'm figuring a similar setup should work, which it has on the two occasions I dropped it (different case from this one).  My one concern with this case is that it is very smooth and pretty slick. I still haven't dropped the phone with this case on it, but the grip is not as good as with a more textured case. It is too pretty not to use and I trust it to protect the phone.

As for aesthetics, this case is much prettier (and I do mean prettier, it has a very femine look) in person than on my computer screen.  I have a rose gold iPhone and debated between the clear with gold glitter and the pink/purple with glitter. The orchid one accents the phone beautifully, and looks fabulous.  The photo shows the Apple logo and the Speck logo. I didn't realize until I sat to write this review that the Speck logo is even there. I.e. it is not obnoxious.
summary: Beautiful case, very snug fit, seems to offer really good protection

reviewText: This case is holding up great.

I have a fairly big arm, and was worried that it wouldn't fit, but it did and is comfortable.  I LOVE the pocket to hold a credit card, id, or key.  You cannot put your phone in it's case (even a super thin case) in the sleeve.  And the first time, the plastic stuck so hard I was afraid I was going to break my phone getting it out.  And it lifted the glass screen protector off one corner, and never quite went back to right.  That got better as I used it more.

I have tried a wide variety of iPhone cases over the years- this one has always been one that I looked into based on reviews- but decided against due to the 2 piece design. After giving it a shot, I have been really pleased! It offers a great balance of slim profile and adequate protection. The case feels very nice in your hand- it has a suede like finish that is smooth and soft but not slippery. It adds minimal bulk but still offers good protection of the corners and even the front screen. The camera lens is protected as well. The power and volume buttons work well and the vibrate switch is more easily accessible than most other cases I have tried. The access to the charging port is fantastic- I have multiple after market cables- and every single one works without removing the case. I am also able to plug into my docking station without removing any part of the case (this is a rare find!). If you do have a docking station that is not compatible- the gold section slips off easily for full access. It is certainly one of the easiest cases to put on and remove. I was concerned that this would get "caught" in my pocket and leave my phone at risk, but it seems to be quite secure and I have had no issues with unintentional slippage. The price point is great and I will likely buy another in a different color to have some variety. Overall- really pleased with the quality of this case.

I received a this product for free in exchange for my honest, unbiased review. I am very pleased with my experience and highly recommend this case!
summary: Great balance of slim fit and sturdy protection

reviewText: Good replacement part: It fits and looks like original and once installed you can't tell it from the original. Included tools are cheap but usable for a repair or two. Opening up an iPhone isn't for the technically challenged but if you can handle small parts and can follow ifixit.com/youtube instructions you should be ok. Having done dozens of these repairs my tips are: - Cover the broken face with wide packing tape to keep it from shedding glass shards. - You'll need a heat source like a hair dryer, a heat gun or a reusable heat bag. The heat bag is great for small devices like iPhones, though not as good for tablets. - Make sure to have an IR thermometer, like this one for under $10, so you don't bake the LCD and other delicate electronics. - A B00792JJK4 thin, flexible metal separator tool is much more useful than the plastic ones that come with the kit and will make this job significantly easier. It can also be used to pop out the display module since broken glass is almost impossible to grab with a suction cup. - You'll need tweezers. Antistatic tweezers like this one for under $2 are best but any good household pair should be fine. Just be careful if they're metal so you don't scratch the logic board or tear a wire. - The screws look alike when removing them but they're slightly different lengths, profiles and head sizes so make sure you're careful to put them back in the same place. - The best thing you can do to make this a successful repair is make a map on a piece of corrugated cardboard: As each component and screw comes out draw a sketch of the part on the cardboard roughly where it goes on the device, number it and poke holes in the cardboard to hold the screws where they belong on the sketch. (The pentalobe screwdriver is perfect for making those tiny holes). That way you'll know where the parts go and in what order, not to mention you won't risk losing screws to a breeze or curious child.
summary: Good screen. Looks & fits like original. Repair requires some skill and diligence - read this for tips

reviewText:
I bought this device from Freedompop as a refurbished Virgin Mobile device.  Surely a mixture doomed to some sort of disaster.  But its working okay for me.  Someone in the 'refurbishing' process crossed out the VM logo with a sharpie.  You can still see it though.

First off, this has gotten a LOT of firmware updates in the last year, so many problems you see from 2014 to early 2015 may have been fixed by those.  Second, this is a lot to set up for someone not familiar with doing manual setup on a router.

Once you have it set up and on, you can connect to it like any other wireless router from your phone or tablet and go to 192.168.1.1 and then log in with the default password (seems to be either 'admin' or 'password' or blank, depending on the device.  Once in, you can change all of the wireless settings like SSID, password, other wifi configuration, to lock it to use LTE only, etc.  Its got about a dozen pages of configuration stuff to tinker with.  I set mine up to use a hidden SSID so nobody can even see it unless they know the name and password, to show the SSID and password on the main screen, and to show how much data I've used.  You can reset the data manually from these setup screens.

First thing your device will want to do is gobble up about 140-150MB of firmware updates and I don't see any way to do that over another connection, but its possible.  Update your profile and PRL databases while you're in the menu, this will give you the latest information about Sprint's network, such as it is.

Here's the good.  This is a "Sprint Spark" device, in fact it was one of the first if not THE first.  Spark is Sprints latest triple band network enhancement, which is being rolled out but is still in limited availability.  One of the bands is particularly good at penetrating into buildings, so that Sprint "lost inside" effect is minimized if you're in one of the areas they've implemented the new network bands.  Its their intention to build out the Spark capability in the future, so the good news is LTE connectivity with this device should continuously improve, especially in urban areas and near major highways.  If I recall right, Spark is capable of realistic speeds in the 50-60Mb/s range.

The device has a good wifi capability, although my devices only connected with it at 65Mb/s which is okay because in a best case scenario I'm not going to get close to that in real world LTE throughput.

It has two external connectors for small to enormous antennas but be advised that while an antenna improves your chance of reception (download), it doesn't do a lot for transmission (upload).  If you look for 'netgear mingle external antenna' you'll see that there are models from $10-100 and up.  I don't think I'd spend a lot of money for a giant antenna, but a pair of smaller cheaper ones would probably improve fringe connections.  Two of the three Spark bands (and they may be all you get) don't do well with penetrating walls, so putting this in a window might help, especially if you can put it in a second or third story window facing the nearest tower.

It has a replaceable battery, so you can get a second or third one.  Nice feature.  The case itself is flimsy.  It has a ridge all around that enables you to pop it open very easily although so far it hasn't happened to me by accident.

The device also appears to have a GPS inside, giving you basic latitude and longitude and has a button to start and stop tracking.  There doesn't seem to be much about what this does or how to use it.  Perhaps when the device is tethered to a PC with a usb connection and in conjunction with a mapping app that supports external GPS devices it can act as a standalone GPS.  It might be my imagination, but the device seems to acquire an LTE signal better when GPS feature is turned on.  I'd bet that depletes the battery fast.

I've used this for a few hours here and there and it gave me decent email/web browsing even at one LTE bar.  I haven't seen it give me more than 1 bar, but I'm in a suburb and not a Spark area.  Freedompoop gives me .5GB of data a month for free.  My plan is to have my elementary age son keep this in a hidden pocket of his backpack so he can download a few books a week to his e-reader in class, since the school won't allow use of their wifi and his e-reader doesn't have a way of doing anything other than wifi.

What I wouldn't do is buy this as a tether for a general purpose computer like a Windows/Mac machine.  While a phone/tablet/chromebook sips data, a full feature operating system can gluck down a GB or two in short order, doing updates and all sorts of background stuff.  I've seen some people have Windows 10 background update over their hotspot/LTE device and run their bill up into triple figures, or lock them out if they hit a monthly cap.
summary: Capable hotspot I got very cheaply, may be better now with updates to firmware and Sprint Spark network than early reviews show

reviewText: good bargain priced replacement phone
What can I say. I am one happy customer. Very good price and fits the Huawei Ascend Y300 perfectly. For the price it seems to be made quite well.
Exellent
Excellent

UPDATE: I received a new one from the ebay seller that fits the OEM cord. But that is it. The opening is not tall enough to fit any other cord. The OEM cable is incredibly thin, and I can't find any that thin.

Two huge problems. The charging port opening is not big enough for any of the chargers in my house. It should at the very least work with the one that comes with the phone! I also have a very slim one from Monoprice and it doesn't work either. They all are too tall, too low, or too wide. Such a bummer because I really liked this case until I needed to charge it. See picture.

It does work with wireless charging. So that's definitely an option. So I gave it 2 stars, instead of one.

Second issue. The screen protector has the infamous "halo effect." Essentially, the screen protector is not made to fit the screen correctly. Therefore, the screen protector doesn't stick to any of the edges all the way around. It's probably about a 1/4 of an inch all the way around. Not only does it look bad, but I'm sure it will be a dirt magnet. See picture.

A side note. I wish they would have stated how much lip they give the front of the phone. It's barely enough with the screen protector. I'm just curious to know how much it is to compare it to other cases. It does help with thinness, and so I might find i like the size. I just wish I'd know the exact amount, because lots of other cases say the exact height so you can compare.

I will contact Ghostek to see if they are planning to fix these two problems and offer replacements (Sometime in the future). Who knows, maybe they will contact all of their customers once they realize their mistake.

BTW: I got mine on ebay for cheaper.

PRO's: Real metal. I was worried it was plastic coated in something that 'contained' aluminum. But upon tapping it on metal, it gave a nice long "ring" and not the plastic short "ding." The metal seems to be very rigid. I don't expect it to bend. My guess it that they leaned towards high Yield strength, so it is more likely to crack then bend. This is actually a good thing, I hope they did. It means it less likely to get scratched.  It also means that if you were to sit on it, it will try to 'hold up' and try to protect your phone, instead of just bending, and putting all the stress on your phone. Also, it fits really snug, and for that reason I don't think it will ever snap under normal drops.
 I was worried about the real metal hurting the signals. But it doesn't hurt the wifi signal (I have a wifi network my note5 can get, but it's about 500 feet away, it gets it with zero bars, so I use this to test between phones and cases- if it can pick up the signal, then it's uninhibited).
summary: Real customer who bought this for the note5

reviewText:
After having smart phones for a while, it became obvious that you need proper protection for the massive screens that they put on them. Why spend so much money on a device only to leave it susceptible to shatters, dents, and scratches? With that, I ordered from Skinomi. You may ask, why Skinomi? Well, my experience with them in the past has been great. They provide excellent customer service, they care about customer satisfaction, and they honor their warranty; replacements have always been provided if something happened to their products.

The overall fit and finish of this product was fantastic. Installation was very easy and the glass provided more than adequate protection. While having a conversation with someone, their hands became a little too animated and hit my phone out of my hands. The phone landed face down, resulting in a sinking feeling; I knew the screen had broke. I picked up the phone only to realize that the phone screen was not what broke, it was the protector!! This screen protector saved my phone from shattering the screen or possibly even more damage. Following the incident, I contacted Skinomi and their customer service promptly replied; they sent me a replacement. Within just a few days, I had a new glass protector on my phone. Skinomi has proven themselves to me and has earned a long-time customer! My experience with them has only been continued and I have order several more products from them because of it.
summary: Fantastic protector, Even better customer service

I really enjoyed my new Henoda Royal Blue 20mm Replacement Rubber for Samsung Gear S2 Classic Smart Watch. It was a great length for a larger wrist. I really liked the rubber feel of the  band as it is very comfortable. It is a really nice blue color and fits my watch correctly.

The leather strap that comes with the S2 classic has a much more classic look but it will not last as long as this new band.  This band seems to be extremely durable. I like how sturdy it is compared to other rubber watch bands. The rubber seems too be made from a good quality so it doesn't have a cheap feel to it.  All of these qualities and staying flexible too, now that is something to be proud of.

While I have all the watch tools that I need so I can change any band on any watch this comes with a little band changing set that I used so I could tell you how well it worked. While not the easiest to use it was still pretty simple.  The tool that comes with the band will get the job done, so no worries.  Most of the time when something comes with a tool like this, it is not made to be kept after the initial change but this tool can be kept in a drawer or added to your tool collection for future band changes.

If you are in need of a new band for your Samsung Gear S2 Classic Smart Watch I would recommend purchasing this Henoda Royal Blue 20mm Replacement Rubber Band.

Just last spring, I spent $38 on a solar charger with half the charging capacity.  Thanks to advances in technologhy, you can now get twice the mAh for less money!!!  I wanted my wife to be able to carry one at all times, so I needed to get another one for myself.

--Like all solar chargers, the solar function is NOT going to be
  your main source of charging on a daily basis.  The solar
  charging ability is a back up feature for emergencies.
--I plugged it into my USB charger at 9:00 PM and it was
  fully charged when I got up to go to work at 4:00 AM.
--It charged up my iPhone to 97% at about half the speed as
  my factory charger.
--The flashlight is good enough for navigating around the
  house in a power outage.
--The compass is small but spot on with two other
  compasses that I own.
--It feels rugged and shock resistant.  This one almost (not
  quite, but almost) has the feel of an Otter Box protector.
  A semi rubbery non skid type of plastic.

CONS

--USB ports are not labeled.  There is one for cell phones and
  one for tablets.  Better instructions with device are needed.

--My flashlight remains glowing dimly when turned off.  My
  fear is that this will drain the charge.  No instructions on
  how to turn it fully off.  **I contacted the company about
  this and they are having their engineer take a look at the
  issue.  They issued a replavement at no charge and it
  works correctly.

Update:  We had a power outage last week and my phone was at 14%. It was really nice to be able to recharge it without electricity.  We highly believe in solar chargers in our family and being prepared for power outages.

A discount was provided for me to evaluate and review this solar charger.
summary: Twice the mah for nearly half the price!!!

When it comes to solar panels, there is a lot you can say about them. I've owned a couple and I know they vary from manufacturer to manufacturer on how they are made. That may be obvious but portable solar panels are somewhat of a new trend. Because of this, they can be wildly different in the way they achieve their results. If you are one of those people who like unboxing videos, including myself, give my video a try. I don't really get into any details, though. I'll cover that in my review below. So let's talk about the performance. I could whip out my multimeter and measure the actual performance of the solar panel but that's kind of pointless. The reason is that we are using it to power and charge USB devices. That's pretty much a constant voltage and amperage needed for that. So that means I'm looking for a couple of things. First is, does it work? I should be able to hook up my USB device and be able to charge it in a decent time. Second, how big is the actual solar panel? I want maximum coverage so that if the sun is not that bright, there are more panels to pick up the slack. Again, I'm not looking for overall wattage, just the more cells the less amount of light has to be present. Imagine it like a camera for those who are familiar with one. It's not necessarily about the Megapixels. The sensor size plays a much bigger role in capturing light than just straight up MP. I'll tell you right now. This solar panel fits both of those requirements for me! It was sunny outside with a quite a bit of cloud coverage and I was able to charge my battery pack in a matter of hours. Had it been one of those battery packs with the built-in solar panel, it would have taken twice as long. Again, more cells mean better low light performance. So if you are in the market for a compact solar panel to charge your USB devices, look no further. This thing works awesome! To maximize your results, get a high capacity battery pack on top of this. At least 10,000 milliampere hours should do! This solar panel was given to me at a discount for my fair and unbiased review. This in no way shape or form affected my review.

reviewText:
I have tried several different types of cellphone car mounts, but this style of air vent mount is my favorite. Before ordering this phone mount, I usually just kept my phone in one of the the cup holders. That is usually fine, unless I have passengers and we need multiple cup holders. Now since I have been using this car mount, it is not an issue.

It arrived unassembled and did not include any instructions. If my husband hadn't been with me when I was putting it together, it's possible that I would have broken in. I was trying to force the ball joint into position. My husband took it from me & unscrewed a nut (?) and was able to easily position it without any force at all. I felt a little stupid at that point, but I was happy it didn't break. The part that goes into the air vent uses a spring loaded feature that is easy to insert into the air vent. I had to try out a few different positions before settling on the center passenger side vent because the center one on the drivers side blocked the clock in my car.

My phone is held very securely when in the mount. It grips it well and keeps it from sliding out. It does require both hands to put the phone in place, but once in there, it doesn't budge.

*I received the Haweel car mount phone holder free of charge for the purpose of trying it out & reviewing. My thoughts & opinions are my own.
summary: Love the Air Vent Style Phone Car Mount!

This little gizmo is just what I needed! A couple of years ago, my son gave me one of those phone holders with the suction cup that mounted to a window. It was okay, but the positioning was never exactly what I wanted and obviously never the same since I couldn't leave it stuck to the window when I left the car. Some idiot would have broken my window for it. But this little gadget is isn't even  noticeable in the car and my phone sticks to it like glue. I have a navigation in my car but I like Google and Wayz better, so I always use those. The voice syncs with the audio but the map I'm looking at is just a regular car map. I've even tried using both the car navigation (which is annoying to set up) and the phone navigator, but they inevitably take different routes and then talk over each other. Now I can glance at my phone to I'll know which way I'm heading in the next 1/2 mile or so without looking down or fumbling with it in the console. The only "downside" is that I now have to create a new habit to retrieve it from the magnet because today I left it in the car while I ran in the store. Also, it comes with two stick on metal plates that you can attach to your phone case if the case impedes the magnetic force. I put one on the outside of my case because I have a thick, plastic case that stores my driver's license and a credit card so it didn't have enough pull. Super handy and a great price. Shout out to Tim Ferris for the recommendation!
summary: But this little gadget is isn't even noticeable in the car and my phone sticks to it like glue. I have a navigation in my car ..

I applied a Skinomi TechSkin to my wifes Droid X when she got it and she had a cheap rubbery e-bay case for it that protected the rest of the phone. 2 years passed and her contract was up and it was time to upgrade. She went with the Samsung Galaxy S3. I was very satisfied with how the skinomi protected her Droid X and I would have purchased one for my Droid X as well, if I didn't already have mine in an Otterbox defender.

I put her X on Ebay and posted some pictures showing just how immaculate the phone was - the screen obviously in a large part due to the skinomi skin. I included a couple extras and ended up getting over $100 for the phone, so the investment definitely paid for itself several times over.

Alright...on to my review of the Galaxy S3 skinomi skin review.

At this point I was familiar with Skinomi's packaging and their application instructions. Anyone that's ever applied one of these things on a phone knows that the first thing you have to do is create a completely clean and dust-free environment. The way I do this is to construct a room encased with plastic sheeting with a fan pulling air out, and one pulling air in through a filter. If you've ever seen the showtime hit Dexter then it's basically like his kill rooms with fans added to it. This is basically the only way you can put one of these damn things one without ending up with those little bubbles with microscopic specs of dust when you're done.

Anyway...the spray they send with it - spray your fingers with it. Spray the face of your phone with it (not too much, or it'll be too slippery slidery!) and spray the back of the skinomi with it. I've become pretty good at this with experience.

HOWEVER - even when I had the skinomi position perfectly I would allow it to dry (I just put it in front of a fan for a bit until that hazy look behind the screen goes away, indicating that it has dried - the left side of the skin started to "lift" away. Thinking that this was because I didn't have it properly positioned I tried again, and again. To no avail...each time it ended the same.

This was just a slight annoyance, and it's something that the wife's newly purchased case would cover up....so I just let it be.

BUT THEN!! Some time later (on a camping trip in Acadia, actually!) my phone rang. It was an unknown caller - not a call I typically answer. The individual on the other end of the line identified herself as a Skinomi representative. Oh great. Now these people are harassing me with phone calls!? Ugh! .....only....not. She was just calling to follow up with my recent purchase to see how things went. I explained the issues I had with the application and she indicated that this shouldn't happen, and offered to send me out a replacement skin.

I received the replacement and gave it another shot and this time it was flawless.

I had experience Skinomi's awesome products, but until now I hadn't experienced their amazing customer service. Perhaps I should knock off a star for the hassle, but it wasn't a big deal and I wasn't even going to worry about it. But because they went the extra mile to touch base and then send a replacement? 5 stars all day. Thanks Skinomi, you guys rock!

reviewText:
I got two protectors for my wife's and my two new Samsung Galaxy SII.  They went on easy enough.  After putting them on, I noticed the package advertised the following features:

1. Crystal clear-Check-There was no difference between having the screen protectors on then before I put them on.

2. Oleophobic (means oil resistent)-Check, I tested this and they do repel oil.

3. Anti glare-Haven't checked this out yet.

4. Anti fingerprint-Not as advertised. I have seen just as many fingerprints on the screen as when there was no screen protector.

5. Privacy protection-Not as advertised. My son actually noticed this before I did. I turned my phone in several angles to see if he could read it and he read it easily every time.

I'm giving 3 stars and I'm giving realook the benefit of the doubt by taking for granted that the anti-glare feature will work tomorrow when I get in the sun and we have tons of sun here in socal.

I got a comment from Crystal Clear which stated:

"JayFdz says:

I'm sorry to tell you but judging by the picture provided here alone I can tell you're a bit confused. All of those are listed because all of those are the one's available but the highlighted one is Crystal Clear, which is what you paid for. As far as I know there is yet to be a screen protector with all those qualities given, the hardest to do would be combining Crystal Clear with Anti-Glare since Anti-Glare usually deals with a matte finish screen which dims the screen a bit, hence, it's not Crystal Clear. (Privacy Protection also falling into the same reasons). So really, what's advertised is what's available, what's shown and what you received is the one you paid for, Crystal Clear."

So, I stand corrected.  I am revising my review to only rate this item on the "Crystal Clear" aspects, but I will state that the packaging is confusing.  Since "Crystal Clear" is highlighted, it could be confused as the best of all the features. I should have read everything a little better before purchasing. So I give 4 stars for being crystal clear and will definately be reading labeling and advertising a little better in the future. Sorry if I misled anyone reading my review.

reviewText: On que!

I've been using this Que phone as my primary phone for a little over a week now, so I have a pretty good idea at this point what I like and don't like about this phone.

Overall it's a great phone for how low the price is. I wouldn't personally use it long term as my primary phone because I miss some of the features and higher specs my Galaxy S5 has, but it is a great budget phone to get for your kid, on a vacation, for temporary use, or even as a primary if you simply can't afford one of the big-name flagship phones.

It is running Android 4.4.2 (KitKat), which isn't the latest OS but still fairly recent. I don't see any way to natively update the phone's OS from the system settings, so I wouldn't get this with the hopes that it will someday be updated to Android 5.0 (Lollipop). But for most people, you wouldn't notice the difference, or even necessarily care. It still is a fantastic operating system and works well.

The tech specs are good for the price. You get a decent-sized screen (5 inches), a dual core 1.3ghz processor, and front (VGA/640x480) and rear (5 Megapixel) cameras. Both work decent enough, just don't expect to get fantastic low-light photos. The screen looks great and is bright enough to easily see it while outside in direct sunlight. It isn't full HD resolution (QHD), but it's enough to easily make out text and graphics and just about any app.

I was able to download and run most every app I typically use on my S5. It is a little bit more sluggish on 3D graphics-intensive apps, but runs all the basic ones flawlessly. There is a little bit of noticeable lag sometimes when dragging through large menus or the "all apps" drawer, but nothing terrible.

The sound and audio out work great for all music apps I tested, and the Bluetooth connected to several devices I tried without issue. GPS also worked well when testing a basic Google Maps navigation.

The dual SIM support is an awesome feature so you should be covered under most any GSM band and don't have to switch SIM cards around if you travel often or use more than one for whatever reason.

My favorite thing while first setting this phone up is how it came with a screen protector pre-applied. Why don't the big name phones do this? Brilliant. It's perfectly applied with no bubbles, perfectly straight and in flawless condition. So I don't have to worry much about minor scratches since I can always just swap out the screen protector.

Battery life has been good so far. I would still plan on needing to recharge it each night, but with minimal use, I could get through a day with more than half its life left. With heavy use, it will be dead by night time as is common with most gadgets.

Fortunately, this features a removable battery and micro SD card support, which makes swapping for a full battery very nice, and allows you to expand the storage greatly by adding in an SD card. The SD support also makes data transfer much easier, so this is a huge plus for me.

The only major negative I have after using this phone for a long time is sometimes the dragging action doesn't work right when scrolling through menus. Instead of gripping your finger to drag, it will think you meant to just tap. So it will select a menu option instead of drag/scroll through the menu.

My general conclusion on this phone is it's about as good as you can get for the price range. If you are used to using a high-end phone, you will quickly notice its shortcomings, but as a backup, secondary, travel, budget, or kid's phone, this is a fantastic buy. Review sample provided by manufacturer.

*Summary*

Pros:
[+] GREAT price, you definitely get a good bang for your buck here
[+] Includes most core smartphone features you have grown to expect (GPS, Bluetooth, front & rear cameras, wi-fi, ambient light sensor, etc)
[+] Screen is bright and vibrant, though not full HD
[+] Sound and audio out works well and provides sufficient volume for most tasks
[+] Includes perfectly-preapplied screen protector out of the box
[+] Features removable battery for fast switching for a full (separately purchased) battery
[+] Features expandable storage through micro SD card support
[+] Provides me a strong wifi signal and wireless (GSM) signal, though your mileage may vary
[+] Dual SIM card support, which is something you can't get in mainstream phones
[+] Doesn't include a ridiculous amount of bloatware like most flagship phones
[+] Fantastic as a budget travel phone when paired with a prepaid SIM so you don't have to worry as much about your phone being lost/stolen/damaged
[+] Includes USB cable, AC adapter, 3.5mm earphones, and micro SIM card adapters

Cons:
[-] OS is not latest version and sometimes gets a big sluggish under moderate to high CPU usage
[-] Scrolling/dragging actions can be kind of finicky, leading to frustrating accidental taps
summary: Fantastic budget phone with plenty of features

*update*
My comply isolation TX 200 ear tips came in and definitely made the ear buds much more comfortable and enhanced the bass through the more secure seal.  The sound is a bit warmer with the new ear tips.  Loving the headphones even more! Let one of my friends who has a pair of beats headphones and he was a lite jealous with the quality/cost and general value of my headphones.

****

So I definitely love these headphones. I was pleasantly surprised by both the battery life and the audio quality. My main headphones are a wired pair of Shure e315s and interestingly enough I am not at all disappointed by the sound quality. I saw a few other reviews saying that they experienced limited bluetooth range, but I'm not experiencing that with these at all. I am in a hotel with a lot of metal and solid doors, so much so that my cell phone signal isn't that great when I move too far from the window, but even while moving through different areas of the suite they hold a steady connection to my source. Granted, sometimes that depends on the phone you're using as the source tends to change bluetooth strength. The only thing I'm slightly weary about is the fit of the ear tips. I switched to the smallest and they became much more comfortable. I did though buy a pair of memory foam tips from comply to make my listening experience much more enjoyable. I didn't take a star away from the headphones as I don't expect a pair of headphones that I purchased for 24.99 to include 25-30 dollar ear tips. I won't lie though, the medium set of ear tips were uncomfortable. I'm definitely looking forward to my comply ear tips (Isolation 200 Tx).

Lastly, Aukey has a great warranty policy. I had an order with them once that didn't go so well and they replaced several units overnight for me until they got a product to me that worked as promise. Since then I've ordered several other products from them without fear of failure as they're great with their 24 month promise!
summary: Great value! Decent build and better than average audio quality!

This is a backup battery for devices that use a micro-USB plug, i.e. most mobile telephones.  It includes a small black box (2" x 1.5" x .75") and a short standard USB to micro-USB cable.

The sealed black box includes a small, rechargeable battery, a standard USB port, a micro-USB port, a button, and a 4-bar LED battery gauge.

If you connect the USB cable to the micro-USB port and connect the USB connector to a laptop, PC, or a USB power source, the unit will charge.  If you reverse the connector, you can then use the micro-USB connector to charge your cellular phone or any other device that accepts micro-USB power.

The short USB cable includes magnets on either end, and those magnets will allow you to wrap the cable around the black box and hold it in place.

Overall, a great, portable backup battery for micro-USB devices.
summary: Great backup battery for micro-USB devices

style.Color:: Black USB Type C to Type C Cable 3.3ft

reviewText: Full disclosure right off the bat : Velesco provided a promotional code to cover the cost of their new Black Squid Type-C cable. What follows is my honest and unbiased review. Benson again with a USB Type-C to USB Type-C cable review. Today I am reviewing BlackSquid's "USB Type C Cable (3.3ft/1m) - Type C to Type C Reversible - USB 3.1 Super Speed - Fast Data Sync & Charging Cord" Today I am starting something new. This cable is not a legacy USB cable like the majority of my previously reviewed products. Instead, this is a pure C-to-C cable meant to be used with newer accessories such as Type-C chargers, Type-C hard drive enclosures, or Type-C docking stations. This cable from Black Squid is a Full-Featured Type-C cable, meaning that it not only supports charging capabilities and basic USB 2.0 data, it also supports USB 3.1 SuperSpeed for much faster data transfer with supported devices (5gbps), and also allows for the extra wires to be repurposed for Alternate Modes such as VESA DisplayPort. All told, this cable should have 10 more wires than a standard USB 2.0 Type-C to Type-C cable to support the extra functionality. My test setup today include my trusty Chromebook Pixel 2015, and a Chromium OS USB-PD Sniffer (codename Twinkie). Please check it out by searching google for "Chromium USB-PD Sniffer". This product is also available on Amazon here : Plugable USB 3.1 Type-C (USB-C) Power Delivery Sniffer I will be testing this cable with the following 3 available chargers to cover a wide range of possible Type-C chargers. * SONEic - USB Type-C (USB-C) Rapid Wall Charger & USB Type-C to Type-C Cable, 15 Watt/3.0 Amp for Nexus 5X/6P, LG G5, Nextbit Robin, Lumia 950/XL and All USB-C Devices - Black (Charger+Cable Included) -> Type-C charger up to 5V 3A. * Apple Apple 29W USB-C Power Adapter -> USB PD capable. Up to 14.5V at 2A. * LG Electronics 4K UHD 27UD88-W 27" Screen LED-Lit Monitor -> Advanced 4K display/docking station with Type-C port. Supplies up to 57W at 3A. Let's test the SONEic Type-C charger with the Chromebook Pixel using the Black Squid cable. Pixel's ectool output : localhost ~ # ectool --dev 1 usbpdpower Port 0: SNK Charger Type-C 4618mV / 3000mA, max 5000mV / 3000mA / 15000mW Port 1: SRC Twinkie analyzer data : > tw vbus VBUS = 4698 mV ; -3062 mA > tw cc CC1 = 0 mV ; CC2 = 1691 mV This looks good. The Black Squid cable is allowing the SONEic Type-C charger to advertise 3A capable (indicated by the 1691 mV reading on CC2), and Pixel is drawing 3A at 4.6V. The next charger, the MacBook 29W charger, will show a different result because it is a USB PD capable charger, and Pixel will attempt to negotiate over PD to a higher voltage. Pixel's ectool output : localhost ~ # ectool --dev 1 usbpdpower Port 0: SNK Charger PD 14403mV / 2000mA, max 14800mV / 2000mA / 29600mW Port 1: SRC As you can see, Pixel has negotiated 14.4V at 2A over the BlackSquid cable to the MacBook charger. Let's take an even more detailed look at the negotiation process. Using Twinkie's tracing function (tw trace 1), I can decode the CC communication on the fly to the serial console : 965415.351337 SRC/0 [2161]SRCCAP 5000mV/2400mA 14800mV/2000mA 965415.352976 SNK/0 [0041]GOODCRC 965415.354247 SRC/0 [0161]GOODCRC 965415.355646 SNK/1 [0241]GOODCRC 965415.357082 SRC/2 [0566]PSRDY 965415.358336 SNK/2 [0441]GOODCRC 965415.359645 SNK/3 [0641]GOODCRC 965415.360980 SRC/1 [0361]GOODCRC 965415.362336 SRC/4 [196f]VDM Vff00:DISCSVID,INI:ff008002 965415.363836 SNK/2 [144f]VDM Vff00:DISCSVID,NAK:ff008082 965415.916464 SNK/3 [1642]REQUEST{2} 200320c8 [965415.918361 PD TMOUT RX 581/582] RXERR SOP 965415.919653 TMOUT 965416.009340 SNK/6 [0c41]GOODCRC The two interesting lines above are the SRCCAP, which is "Source Capabilities" where the charger sends to the Chromebook the list of available voltage and current limits it supports. Secondly, the "REQUEST{2}" from the sink is the Chromebook Pixel choosing the second voltage level from the menu of the sources' capabilities, indicating it is requesting the 14.8V level. As we can see, Twinkie confirms that the charger is supplying 14.4V at 2A through the BlackSquid cable to the laptop: > tw vbus VBUS = 14407 mV ; -1989 mA > tw cc CC1 = 941 mV ; CC2 = 0 mV The final charger is actually LG's Type-C docking station + 4K monitor. Let's plug it in via the Black Squid cable and see what Pixel thinks : localhost / # ectool --dev 1 usbpdpower Port 0: Disconnected Port 1: SNK Charger PD 17612mV / 3000mA, max 19000mV / 3000mA / 57000mW It's negotiated to 17V charging with this display at 3A. > tw vbus VBUS = 17652 mV ; -3001 mA At the same time as fast charging, the display also turned on and Pixel drove the external display at full 4K resolution (3840x2160) at 60Hz. I also confirmed that a keyboard and mouse attached to the display's integrated USB hub work too. For a USB 2.0 High Speed data test, Ive hooked my Nexus 5X to my Chromebook Pixel via the BlackSquid Type-C cable to test large file transfer via MTP. It just works, no problem! For a USB 3.1 SuperSpeed data test, I've hooked up my Chromebook Pixel to a SuperSpeed Type-C external drive enclosure :ORICO Aluminum Tool Free Type C USB 3.0 to SATA III External Hard Drive Enclosure for 2.5 inch HDD/SSD [ Optimized For SSD, Support UASP ] Silver (2598C3) I confirmed when attached to my Chromebook Pixel via the Black Squid cable that it enumerates at SuperSpeed, indicating that the cable definitely has the required extra wires to support the faster operation. I have also done a 4-wire measurement of impedance on Vbus and Gnd using a bench LCR meter to see if this cable is within spec for IR Drop (Section 4.4.1 of the Type-C spec) : Vbus : 0.132 -> 0.396mV Gnd : 0.071 -> 0.213mV These are within the limits of 500mV for Vbus and 250mV for Gnd! Very good! This cable will not cause excessively slow charging. For other more subjective judgements of this cable : Just like the last BlackSquid cable that I reviewed, I am impressed with just how thin this cable is considering it has, at a minimum, 15 separate wires inside. The actual cable diameter is even thinner than some USB 2.0 cables I have seen, and the cable is still very flexible. Both Type-C plugs are of the stamped kind, which is good, but not great. Other cables including ones from Google and Apple use a deep-draw extrusion method to build the plugs, which is stronger and nicer looking. Overall, I am impressed with Black Squid's fit and finish with this cable. In conclusion, Black Squid's Full-Featured Type-C cable is an excellent full featured cable that shows the promise of Type-C use cases to come. Using this single cable, I was able to fast charge my laptop while simultaneously displaying 4k60 video to and accessing a USB hub on an external display. Well done!
summary: Black Squid's 3ft Full Featured Type-C cable is spec compliant and excellent for docking use cases!

I also folded a Fedex notice in there the other day, when I had to go the local depot and pick up a missed delivery.

I am truly pleased with this case! I just ordered a magnetic phone mount, so I will update if there are any problems with it.

Anyway, I was surprised at how easy to put on it was, I always see people struggle to install this kind of stuff (people in cellphone accessories stores who are supposed to have some experience) but this product was installed quickly by me with just the instructions and tools supplied in the package.

The package contains 3 screen protectors, installation instructions and tools which come in different envelopes.

As noted, installing it was really easy, it took me longer to clean the screen after taking off the previous protector that never stuck completely (and was more expensive!).

This anti glare, anti fingertip protector looks great and feels better than the "normal" one I had before. The screen feels softer and not sticky like with the product I was using before.

I'll buy this brand for my next phone (I doubt I'll need to buy a second set for this same phone as the package includes 3 screen protectors and they look like they will last long).

Thanks for a really good product, nicely packaged and delivered fast.

reviewText:
There must be several color hues available because I listened to the reviewer who stated it was more transparent than purple.  This was what I was wanting and expecting.  What I got instead was indeed a vibrant purple.  On my monitor the color pictured has a slight blue tint, but still very much purple.  My case actually is more purple with no hint of blue.  I will see if I can post a picture.

As far as the case itself, its a great value.  For under $3 this can't be beat.  It fits well, and is a true rubberized case (Although I doubt its made of actual rubber).

Comming from a harder 'gel'type case (hard plastic bottom with softer sided that were still fairly unflexibly)this case allows me to use the buttons very easily.  Sometimes too easy. I find myself accidentally turning on my screen when pressing the volume or power button.  By contrast, my old case I has to delibertly press with some force to press the buttons.

Although it doesn't fit as snug in all areas, such as in the opening for the charger port and headphones (there is an air gap between the case and the phone itself), the case is secure and protects the phone OK.  I wouldn't reecommend drop testing it however, but the occational hishandling resultin in it falling a foot or so should be OK.

The material seems to not collect dirt so much and is easy to clean.

The dealer shipped this FAST.  I was surprised to have it at my door in about 2 days.

Its sad you have to wait until a product such as the Samsung I500 reaches the end of it's service life to see deals like this on accessories.
summary: Well worth the price, vibrant purple color.

reviewText: I got this for myself and I love it!

I won't repeat all of the features/specs in the product description and reviews here, but I'll list the top 3 things I love about this phone: Viewable screen under a hot Texas sun: --------------------------------------- One thing that has plagued essentially every smartphone I've owned is that I can't view it under direct sunlight. This is true of my old Samsung Focus and a friend's new Samsung Flash. We were at a car show and while I was tapping the screen of my Lumia 900 (with 8mp Carl Zeiss lens) and focusing and seeing what I was taking pictures of, he was blindly pressing his camera button and tapping his screen, in hopes that he actually took a picture. Then, we wanted to see what the date was in 2 weeks. He absolutely could not view his screen and see his calendar. My Nokia was easily readable and we had to use my phone to look up a date, settle a bet on the amount of horsepower the Ferrari we were snapping pics of and find the closest Starbucks to redeem the bet. :) Faster than my Samsung Focus: ------------------------------- We have an IP camera over the crib of our newborn. I used to use my Samsung Focus as a baby monitor and 50% of the time, the app that I use would give timeout messages and or take a few seconds to start streaming a picture. With my Nokia Lumia 900, not a single timeout message and the app streams a picture immediately (we know this because it displays the current hour-minute-SECONDS). I double-know this because my wife also has a Samsung Focus and she has the same timeout issues. 3G (Focus)/4G (Lumia900) is not a factor because both phones use the same WIFI network in the house. Speaks Caller ID/Spoken Text Messages and DICTATION: ------------------------------------------------------ Okay, this may not be exclusive to the Nokia Lumia 900, but rather, Windows Phone 7.5 that bring spoken caller-id (can be turned off) when someone calls you as well as spoken text messages as part of the phone, not an app you have to buy. It's like having Ford Sync, without having to buy the car! With my great, but fairly inexpensive SuperTooth HD Bluetooth Car Speakerphone I'll hear, "New Text Message from Bill G - do you want me to read it or ignore?" I can say "Read it!" and the text message will be read aloud. Then, it will ask "Do you want to call this person back, or reply or ignore" I can then reply and dictate a text message and send back a true text message. Combined with a little peace of mind in a new phone case: Diztronic Matte Black Case for Nokia Lumia 900 I really love this phone!
summary: Viewable in bright sunlight, faster than my Focus!

I do have a Zagg glass screen protector as well, and this fits fine with that.
summary: Mute toggle button is a problem
